	<item>
		<title>The aims of the Scheme</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/the-aims-of-the-scheme/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 17 Aug 2005 16:03:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?page_id=4</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/forum/images/logo.jpg" alt="Portable Antiquities Logo" />
The Portable Antiquities Scheme is a voluntary scheme to record archaeological objects found by members of the public. Every year many thousands of objects are discovered, many of these by metal-detector users, but also by people whilst out walking, gardening or going about their daily work. Such discoveries offer an important source for understanding our past.

<ol>
<li>To advance knowledge of the history and archaeology of England and Wales by systematically recording archaeological objects found by the public. </li>
<li>To raise awareness among the public of the educational value of archaeological finds in their context and facilitate research in them. </li>
<li>To increase opportunities for active public involvement in archaeology and strengthen links between metal-detector users and archaeologists. </li>
<li>To encourage all those who find archaeological objects to make them available for recording and to promote best practice by finders. </li>
<li>To define the nature and scope of a scheme for recording portable antiquities in the longer term, to access the likely costs and to identify resources to enable it to be put into practice. </li></ol>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2005-08-17 17:03:10</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2005-08-17 16:03:10</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-aims-of-the-scheme</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>2</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>Treasure Act Summary</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/treasure/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 19 Aug 2005 11:09:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/treasure/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The following finds are Treasure under the Act, if found after 24 September 1997 (or, in the case of category 2, if found after 1 January 2003):

1. Any metallic object, other than a coin, provided that at least 10 per cent by weight of metal is precious metal (that is, gold or silver) and that it is at least 300 years old when found. If the object is of prehistoric date it will be Treasure provided any part of it is precious metal.
2. Any group of two or more metallic objects of any composition of prehistoric date that come from the same find (see below)
3. All coins from the same find provided they are at least 300 years old when found (but if the coins contain less than 10 per cent of gold or silver there must be at least ten of them). Only the following groups of coins will normally be regarded as coming from the same find:

<ul>
	<li>hoards that have been deliberately hidden </li>

	<li>smaller groups of coins, such as the contents of purses, that may been dropped or lost </li>

	<li>votive or ritual deposits</li>
</ul>


4. Any object, whatever it is made of, that is found in the same place as, or had previously been together with, another object that is Treasure.
5. Any object that would previously have been treasure trove, but does not fall within the specific categories given above. Only objects that are less than 300 years old, that are made substantially of gold or silver, that have been deliberately hidden with the intention of recovery and whose owners or heirs are unknown will come into this category.

Note: An object or coin is part of the ‘same find’ as another object or coin if it is found in the same place as, or had previously been together with, the other object. Finds may have become scattered since they were originally deposited in the ground.

What should I do if I find something that may be Treasure?

You must report all finds of Treasure to a coroner for the district in which they are found either within 14 days after the day on which you made the discovery or within 14 days after the day on which you realised the find might be treasure.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>13</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2005-08-19 12:09:11</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2005-08-19 11:09:11</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>treasure</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>4</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>British Sign Language videos on the BM website</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?page_id=601</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?page_id=601</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The British Museum has undergone some extensive work over the last year or so. One of the latest additions are British Sign Language videos which were produced by students from Frank Barnes Primary School for Deaf children. They worked with Museum staff to give their own interpretations of African masks and headdresses, the Assyrian lion hunt reliefs and the Parthenon sculptures.

You can see the videos at the links below:

<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/learning/schools_and_teachers/school_projects/bsl_project.aspx">http://www.britishmuseum.org/learning/schools_and_teachers/school_projects/bsl_project.aspx</a>

HIGHLIGHT OBJECT VIDEOS
You can now watch BSL translations of 18 of the Museum's highlight objects.

See the full list of videos:

<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/about_this_site/accessibility/bsl.aspx">http://www.britishmuseum.org/about_this_site/accessibility/bsl.aspx</a>

Lewis chessmen
Probably made in Norway, about AD 1150-1200 -
<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/t/the_lewis_chessmen.aspx">http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/t/the_lewis_chessmen.aspx</a>

Rosetta stone
From Fort St Julien, Egypt Ptolemaic Period, 196 BC
Watch:
<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aes/t/the_rosetta_stone.aspx">http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aes/t/the_rosetta_stone.aspx</a>

Feather bonnet of Yellow Calf
Arapaho, about AD 1927, from the American West
Watch:
<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aoa/f/feather_bonnet_of_yellow_calf.aspx">http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aoa/f/feather_bonnet_of_yellow_calf.aspx</a>

Bronze figure of Tara
Found Sri Lanka, 8th century AD
Watch:
<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/asia/g/gilded_bronze_figure_of_tara.aspx">http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/asia/g/gilded_bronze_figure_of_tara.aspx</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>map</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/07/09/embed-map/map-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Jul 2010 12:53:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/07/map.png</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

You can create as many pages like this one or sub-pages as you like and manage all of your content inside of WordPress.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>An experience not to be missed Monday 15th August</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/18/an-experience-not-to-be-missed-monday-15th-august-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Aug 2005 18:21:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>venicone</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=8</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="462" caption="A fragment of gold runic inscription"]<img title="A fragment of gold runic inscription" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/images/cmcdonald/medium/dscn0195.jpg" alt="A fragment of gold runic inscription" width="462" height="354" />[/caption]<strong>Monday 15th August</strong>



One of the forum members from Croatia posted the comment "Surely those are runes on the sides?" , Another poster said "the runic symbols on there seem to say that it was a gift to Odin and Tyr for a safe journey".........




There were suggestions it could be Viking Hack Gold, a part pommel cap, a votive offering to the Gods, a talismanic piece, amulet or charm, part of a finger ring, part of a Bridle. The academics on the Portable Antiquities Forum were also very complimentary about the find offering suggestions of what it could be - now this was getting to be exciting to say the least.

After a phone call to my local museum, I find that my Finds Liaison Officer isn't in today. I decide to take half a days holiday tomorrow morning and hope that she is "in the office" and not out and about.

I need to hand this in to her as soon as possible because I am away from this weekend. The possibility of the find being Treasure means that I have to get it reported within 14 days..

There appears to be a great deal of interest in this little find - and I still have no idea what it is.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>An experience not to be missed Tuesday 16th August</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/18/an-experience-not-to-be-missed-tuesday-16th-august/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Aug 2005 18:25:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>venicone</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=9</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Tuesday 16th August </strong>
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="462" caption="A fragment of gold runic inscription"]<img title="A fragment of gold runic inscription" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/images/cmcdonald/medium/dscn0195.jpg" alt="A fragment of gold runic inscription" width="462" height="354" />[/caption]

Arrive outside the museum at 9am only to find it doesnt open till 10am ......... so I head off to the shops instead for an hour. I'm back at 10am and ask if I can see Caroline McDonald and the answer is yes - she will be with me in 5 minutes. Wey Hey!

Caroline arrives in the museum - she has been up very early this morning as she has been on local radio for a session about metal detecting and has only just got back. She hasn't even had a chance to read her emails - so doesn't know I have a Treasure item to give to her.

Was she surprised? <strong>Yes! </strong>
Was she pleased? <strong>Yes! </strong>
Was she excited? <strong>Yes! </strong>

We go to Carolines office (after signing in, getting a chocolate from reception and traipsing up 4 flights of stairs). Here we sit down and complete the Treasure Act 1996 form - this is a receipt for objects of potential treasure reported to the coroner. I need to give my name, address, phone number,details of the owner of the land I was detecting on, the date it was found, the circumstances of the find (found in ploughsoil whilst using a metal detector), the location of the findspot. Caroline then completed a brief description of the find as follows:

<em>Gold fragment with runic inscription
Length: 8.18mm
Width: 8.22mm
Thickness: 5.06mm
Weight: 3.10g </em>

I then signed the form and officially handed over the wee find I'd found just 36 hours ago. <strong>T'was Easy Peasy. </strong>

Caroline explained that the Treasure Process can take some time to complete - in some cases up to a year but that I will be kept informed every step of the process.

I was then lucky enough to be introduced to the museum conservator, Emma, who was busy working on some crotal bells found by detectorists on a development dig.  She allowed me to view my find under her powerful microscope - have to say it made it look even better! And it also showed all the dirt which is still in place.

It was back to work after that, but by 3pm I received an email from Caroline advising that she had faxed the Coroners Office and that she had received confirmation that they had received the paperwork - and that I was now officially "In the system".

Now I have to be patient and wait and see.................]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>An experience not to be missed Thursday 18th August</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/18/an-experience-not-to-be-missed-thursday-18th-august/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Aug 2005 18:27:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>venicone</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=10</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Thursday 18th August</strong>


A number of people have been emailing me regarding my wee find.

Kevin Leahy, who is a Finds Adviser – Early Medieval metalwork, for the Portable Antiquities Scheme, is actually on holiday painting the fascias on his house (some holiday!) but has been following the discussions online and he has sent details of the runes to an expert in Germany to see what she makes of it.

I’ve also heard again this morning from Caroline, my FLO, that Barry Ager, the Viking specialist at the British Museum, was informed of the find the day she saw me. He has suggested to her that it was a job for the BM Anglo-Saxonist’s headed up by Leslie Webster.

Normally, to speed up the process Caroline would write the treasure reports for the British Museum, which are then used by the coroner at the inquest, but on this occasion she feels this is beyond her expertise and is requesting that the British Museum curator does the full report. She is now just waiting for the various expert opinions to come back and then will keep me posted.

Otherwise I now just have to wait for the Inquest to be scheduled – but this can only happen after the report is written and my wee find is with the British Museum which is likely to be in early September.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>&#039;Henry VIII hunting whistle&#039; unearthed - allegedly!</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/24/henry-viii-hunting-whistle-unearthed-allegedly/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Aug 2005 17:35:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/2005/08/24/henry-viii-hunting-whistle-unearthed-allegedly/14/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://news.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2005/08/22/nwhist22.xml">Telegraph | News | 'Henry VIII hunting whistle' unearthed</a>
A silver huntsman's whistle, which may have belonged to Henry VIII (according to the finder), has been unearthed during a metal detectors' club gathering.
The record will eventually appear under - IOW-954403 and as Treasure item 2005 T96

		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/24/guardian/</link>

		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/2005/08/24/guardian-unlimited-books-by-genre-review-gold-gilt-pots-pins-by-david-a-hinton/15/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://books.guardian.co.uk/reviews/history/0,6121,1547863,00.html">Guardian Unlimited Books | By genre | Review: Gold &amp; Gilt, Pots &amp; Pins by David A Hinton</a>
Gold &amp; Gilt, Pots &amp; Pins: Possessions and People in Medieval Britain - The review of this book highlights the fact that some people in the Heritage profession, do not comprehend the nature of the Scheme.
Jane Morris states -
[...]while Hinton remains ambivalent about the Portable Antiquities Scheme - the fund that now pays detectorists for finds to stop Wanborough-type incidents[...]
Now I think that she's slightly confused by the Treasure Act and the functions of the Scheme....
<img src="http://image.guardian.co.uk/sys-images/Books/Pix/covers/2005/08/11/gold_final.jpg" alt="David Hinton's book" />
This book actually contains a high number of images provided by the Scheme!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Enamelled bronze pan</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/24/trulla/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Aug 2005 19:45:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>

The Staffordshire Moorland's pan has finally made it into Compass. 	<item>
		<title>MIDAS XML Schema - PAS</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/25/midas/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 25 Aug 2005 09:33:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=17</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Scheme engaged OAD to write the XML Schema for the transfer of data from our database into regional Historic Environment Records. Documentation can be found here:
<a href="http://heritage-standards.org/midas/docs/object/">http://heritage-standards.org/midas/docs/object/</a>
And an example can be found here:
<a href="http://heritage-standards.org/midas/examples/object_example.xml">http://heritage-standards.org/midas/examples/object_example.xml</a>
This is still in the drafting process and will be formalised soon.....]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>17</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2005-08-25 10:33:02</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2005-08-25 09:33:02</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>midas</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

		<category domain="category" nicename="techie-stuff"><![CDATA[Techie stuff]]></category>

		<wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>An experience not to be missed 19th August</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/27/an-experience-not-to-be-missed-19th-august-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 27 Aug 2005 12:17:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>venicone</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=18</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="462" caption="A fragment of gold runic inscription"]<img title="A fragment of gold runic inscription" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/images/cmcdonald/medium/dscn0195.jpg" alt="A fragment of gold runic inscription" width="462" height="354" />[/caption]

The farmer has mentioned the possibility of the land where the find was made being scheduled - this is obviously a concern to farmers where small finds are made as they have a business to run and land to plough and farm.

I have emailed him to tell him I do not think that one small find will mean that this particular field would be scheduled but have also asked Caroline the FLO if she is able to put his mind at rest. She emailed him too - this is part of her email to him:


<em>"Corinne Mills find is very exciting and interesting, but please let me reassure you that such a small find, even of gold, will not lead to your land being scheduled. Scheduled Ancient Monuments are exactly that - monuments, and stray finds alone will not lead to this sort of action. Scheduling is an extreme reaction in exceptional circumstances and very little has been scheduled in the past 10 years.</em>

<em>It is also unlikely that any archaeological investigation will take place, and should anyone express an interest in this (again this is unlikely), nothing can happen on your land without your permission and you are well within your rights to say no.</em>

<em>Miss Mills has acted very responsibly in reporting the find, as there is a legal requirement for her to do so within 14 days of discovery. I am very impressed with Miss Mill's quick reaction to the find and how she is tracking the process on the website so that other finders can be made aware of their legal responsibility.</em>

<em>Let me reassure you once again that this find is unlikely to cause you any bother and encourage you to take heart that you have such a responsible person detecting on your land.</em>

<em>If you have any further queries please do not hesitate to contact me. You will of course be updated by letter at each significant stage of the process</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>An experience not to be missed 26th August</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/27/an-experience-not-to-be-missed-26th-august/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 27 Aug 2005 12:19:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>venicone</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=19</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Friday 26th August 2005


Another update from Caroline today:

<em>
Hi Co,</em>

<em>I have now had a response from Leslie Webster at the BM who has been away. She is deferring judgment until she sees the widget, but has passed details over to another expert at Nottingham University, so there are lots of people on the case now!</em>

<em>hope all is well with you,</em>

<em>regards</em>

<em>Caroline McDonald
Finds Liaison Officer, Essex</em>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Roadmap</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/roadmap/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 22 Sep 2006 10:51:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/roadmap/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[New Features

<em><strike>Crossed out items</strike> are those which have already been implemented by the developers (that's on our database) or by Dan (on the other websites).</em>

<em>Main Scheme websites</em>

<em><a title="PAS website" href="http://www.finds.org.uk">finds.org.uk</a></em>
<ol>
	<li>Add more help documentation for searching database</li>
	<li>Finish Medieval coins identification guide</li>
	<li>Add county roundup pages for each FLO, these will initially focus on Roman coins, with Sam Moorhead providing synthesis and analysis</li>
	<li>Add more information to Roman coins guides - biography and contextual information</li>
	<li>Finish integration of microformats to pages</li>
	<li>Integrate flickr images to other areas of the website</li>
	<li>Add mod_rewrite module for clean urls (gallery, blog, wiki)</li>
	<li>Add some AJAX scripting for form validation</li>
	<li>Finish custom built cms for all areas or transfer to
a) The new BM cms
b) New version of textpattern</li>
	<li>Integrate more RSS feeds from database to coin pages.</li>
</ol>
<a title="Pastexplorers website" href="http://www.pastexplorers.org.uk">pastexplorers.org.uk</a>
<ol>
	<li>Add more lesson resources</li>
	<li>Integrate more rss feeds</li>
	<li>Keep CMS version (txp) up to date</li>
	<li>Integrate flickr images</li>
</ol>
<a title="Finds database" href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk">findsdatabase.org.uk</a>
<ol>
	<li>Integrate with google maps</li>
	<li>Enhance search functionality</li>
	<li>Add browsable history function for registered users</li>
</ol>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>New British Museum website launches</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/24/bmsite/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 24 May 2007 14:43:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/297</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href='http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk' title='New BM website launched'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/bm.thumbnail.jpg' alt='New BM website launched'></a>The British Museum launched its new website today, which is the culmination of over 14 months of work. The website is built on the <a href="http://www.immediacy.co.uk/">Immediacy</a> content management system (a .NET product), implemented by <a href="http://www.atkinsglobal.com/news/25360/6941229_Internet">Atkins</a>. The overall design and information architecture were formulated by <a href="http://www.cogapp.com">CogApp</a> and implemented by many talented people who form the BM web team, Information Systems team and various other individuals around the Museum.

There are some invalid HTML sections which will be ironed out post launch. The homepage currently has some inline styles due to the CMS stripping out empty divs, which I found slightly infuriating when trying to implement the HTML and CSS styles that the designers came up with. It will be interesting over the next few days to watch the analytics and see how post launch activity changes and what people have been looking for.

So check it out at <a href="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk">www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Welcome to the Scheme&#039;s blog</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/17/welcome-to-the-schemes-blog/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 17 Aug 2005 14:51:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=2</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This blog was started to allow members of staff to add links to sites that they liked, comment on news and for our friendly finders to talk about their experiences with the Scheme and the Treasure process.
The content will increase over time. If you fancy joining in, then contact me at the BM.
For more general discussion, please visit our <a href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/forum">forum</a>
That's all for now folks.
DanDan]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_id>670</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>An experience not to be missed</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/08/17/an-experience-not-to-be-missed/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 17 Aug 2005 15:48:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>venicone</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/?p=3</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Sunday 14th August </strong>

corinne_mills/Treasure_act/Dscn0180.jpg

After a days solid rain yesterday, I woke up at 6.30am to find the sun had come out in earnest. Just what was needed as I had planned to go for a days metal detecting with my colleague Terry. After loading up the car with the equipment and making sure I hadn't forgotten my flask of coffee I set off and picked up Terry from his home. Earlier in the week I had a new car delivered but it seems that even this one isn't spacious enough inside as Terry's head still reaches the roof........

We arrived at the farm and Terry jumped out and went to see the farmer to let him know we were there and to ask which fields were available for us to detect on. After much discussion (i.e. me dithering) we decided to detect on a large field which had recently been ploughed and although uneven wasn't too bad. Terry headed along the edge of the field and I decided to walk across the field upwards towards a rise. At the brow of the rise I was lucky enough to find a decent Rose farthing and then just a few metres away up popped a not so decent Roman sesterius coin

<img src="http://www.ourpasthistory.com/md/rose_farthing.jpg" alt="Rose Farthing" />

Considering I live in the heart of Roman East Anglia I have to say that my roman finds have been - well, almost non existent - so I was very happy to find this. Terry made his way up the rise towards me to ask how I was getting on - I showed him my finds and asked what he had managed to detect. "Coke and buttons" he said.

After a while on this field we decided to move to one on the other side of the road. It had been a field of barley - and now the majority of it was stubble about 10 inches high. Now Terry's a big lad and can handle swinging his detector against stubble - but me? I'm a 5ft 2in female and within 20 minutes had had enough.

At the other end of the field was an area which hadn't been harvested and in front of it was a fair sized barren area with virtually no stubble - guess where I headed ! I decided that as the area was not too big, to cover it extensively - I started to walk very slowly in lines, turn and then walk back overlapping the area I had just covered. This paid off as I quickly found a bag seal and then shortly afterwards a small lead token.

<img src="http://www.ourpasthistory.com/md/token.jpg" alt="Small lead token" />

I had covered about half of the ground when I saw Terry walking back over to where I was from the other side of the field. At that moment I got a strange and iffy signal from my detector .....not bad but certainly not the "good signal" we all listen out for...hmmm I thought......is it worth digging this? Well, curiosity got the better of me so I dug a small spadeful of the soft soil and placed it to the side of the hole. A quick sweep of the detector told me the item was in the removed soil - so I picked up some in my hand and swept it over my detector coil just as Terry arrived next to me. "What have you got there" he said. "Dunno" said I

I broke the soil in my hand apart and there staring at us was a tiny, shiny gold coloured object.

"Its <strong>Gold!</strong>" said Terry.

Well....... I don't take my specs with me when I'm out in the field detecting so I passed it straight to Terry to have a look at.

"<strong>Ooooooooooooooooh!</strong>" he said.............

It looked like someone's foot in a roman sandal - but only the front half of one - what on earth could it be?

<img src="http://www.ourpasthistory.com/md/top.jpg" alt="Roman Sandal?" />

We made our way to see the farmer and tell him of this find and that it would need to be declared as potential treasure. He was intrigued by the find and like us had never seen anything like it before. I promised to keep him informed with what happens and what the outcome would be.

This farmer is really interested in the finds from his land - but many of the individuals who detect there do not make the time to pop along and show him their finds.

Terry and I have told him that once finds have been recorded we will make sure they are given back to him to keep. Unfortunately this won't be the case for this wee gold find I doubt!

<strong>Sunday evening</strong>

When I arrived back at my home, I took some photo's of the find and posted them on a couple of the online detecting fora as well as the Portable Antiquities Forum to see if anyone was able to identify what this very small artefact was. Also emailed my Finds Liaison Officer to let her know I had found an item which could fall under the Treasure Act.

<em>I had no idea what was about to develop within a few hours.......</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="online-detecting-fora"><![CDATA[online detecting fora]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="roman-east-anglia"><![CDATA[Roman East Anglia]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="treasure-process"><![CDATA[Treasure process]]></category>

			<wp:comment_id>2</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[DanDan]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>dpett@british-museum.ac.uk</wp:comment_author_email>

	<item>
		<title>Using Theyworkforyou to query the finds database</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=882</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=882</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the last couple of years, I've been playing around with the Theyworkforyou API, which provides a huge amount of information from the UK Parliament. Specifically, I wanted to use archaeological data to provide a simple way of flagging public archaeological discovery and known monuments within Parliamentary constituencies, or to capture times when MPs or Lords have mentioned a predetermined phrase in any of the Houses. To do this is relatively straightforward once you have worked out how to use the API and I've created a series of <a title="My github repository for YQL tables for TWFY" href="http://github.com/portableant/yql-tables/tree/master/twfy/">YQL Open Tables</a> to make using this more straightforward.

If you want to use the APIs talked about in this article, TWFY, the Guardian and geoPlanet all need API keys.
<h4>Getting geographical information from TWFY</h4>
The api provides a simple method for obtaining geographical coordinates in decimal degrees for most of the Parliamentary consituencies in the UK (there are some limitations as outlined in their API docs - Northern Ireland for example only gets a centroid). To obtain the data pertaining to a constituency, you need to know the name. So for example, as I live in Battersea, I would call this API  method as such:

[bash]http://www.theyworkforyou.com/api/getGeometry?name=battersea&amp;key{yourkey}&amp;output=xml[/bash]

Which produces this XML response:

[xml]&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;iso-8859-1&quot;?&gt;
&lt;twfy&gt;&lt;name&gt;Battersea&lt;/name&gt;
&lt;centre_lat&gt;51.4640547349&lt;/centre_lat&gt;
&lt;centre_lon&gt;-0.166039426385&lt;/centre_lon&gt;
&lt;area&gt;0&lt;/area&gt;
&lt;min_lat&gt;51.4422499056&lt;/min_lat&gt;
&lt;max_lat&gt;51.4858456051&lt;/max_lat&gt;
&lt;min_lon&gt;-0.205807374368&lt;/min_lon&gt;
&lt;max_lon&gt;-0.126233632176&lt;/max_lon&gt;
&lt;parts&gt;1&lt;/parts&gt;
&lt;/twfy&gt;
[/xml]

However you can also call this by using my TWFY opentable command:]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Experimenting with dbpedia for numismatic enrichment</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=941</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=941</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We've been working on numismatic guides to assist with the identification of coins for around 4 1/2 years now; following the decision to completely rebuild and integrate the Scheme's websites (finds.org.uk and findsdatabase.org.uk). It was decided that we needed to enrich the site thoroughly with multi-period and far reaching information for the issuing monarchs or emperors. We initially tried to do this by volunteers producing some text from a variety of sources and then adding these to our website. This was only really successful for Roman coins and was extremely frustrating for the other periods. To get round this, we turned to wikipedia about 6 months ago to see whether we could use their data to provide numismatic biographies; the answer was yes!

So how did we get the data from wikipedia to redisplay onto our website, well the simple answer was through the SPARQL endpoint for dbpedia, an amazing useful resource. So to begin with the explanation, let's take a look at the information that we could get from this resource, using Richard III of England as an example. The relevant page on wikipedia is: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_III_of_England">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_III_of_England</a> and contains a mass of peer reviewed information that we could make use of. So let's now look at the data contained within the current dbpedia.org repository. This is located at: <a href="http://dbpedia.org/page/Richard_III_of_England">http://dbpedia.org/page/Richard_III_of_England</a> and allows you to retrieve data programmatically. There are a range of fields that I was interested to ingest and redisplay on our website page relating to Richard III. These were:
<ol>
	<li>Abstract [dbpedia-owl:abstract]</li>
	<li>Birth date [dbpedia-owl:birthDate]</li>
	<li>Death date [dbpedia-owl:deathDate]</li>
	<li>Father</li>
	<li>Mother</li>
	<li>Depiction</li>
	<li>Thumbnail [dbpedia-owl:thumbnail]</li>
	<li>Wikipedia link page [foaf:page]</li>
	<li>Name</li>
	<li>Type</li>
	<li>Place of death</li>
	<li>Imagewidth</li>
</ol>
If you look at the dataset presented on the dbpedia page, you can see that this pulls out quite alot of the required fields!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>941</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-11-29 17:06:27</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Using YQL for museum api queries</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=1053</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=1053</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the last few months, I've been turning a variety of museum APIs into YQL open tables to make them more easy to query via Yahoo!'s YQL service. You can now do SELECT * FROM museums on the following via the tables I created:
<ol>
	<li>British Museum - query their Opensearch module for collections data, 1 table</li>
	<li>Brooklyn Museum - needs an api key, 6 tables or methods of querying</li>
	<li>Digital NZ - needs an api key, 4 tables or methods of querying</li>
	<li>OpenContext - not strictly a museum, but has great content, 1 table</li>
	<li>Museum of London - 11 tables or methods</li>
	<li>Black Country History - 1 table</li>
	<li> Victoria and Albert - 3 tables or methods</li>
</ol>
There is also a set of tables for the Theyworkforyou api, which I'll go over in another post.

Jim O'Donnell, formerly of the National Maritime Museum created the following tables:
<ol>
	<li>NMM</li>
	<li>NMSI</li>
</ol>
So you now have 9 different museum datasets that you can play with. So how do you use it if you are unfamiliar with YQL? Below I'll outline what each of these tables can do, but if you're using the YQL console, you can explore what parameters you can send via your statement and whether they are constants, required or optional. One thing that you always need to remember, is that these tables are community tables, so in the YQL console, you need to have "show community tables on" and any remote calls you initiate will need:
<blockquote>&amp;env=store://datatables.org/alltableswithkeys appended (urlencoded)</blockquote>
<h4>The British Museum table</h4>
The BM table queries the collections opensearch module and parses the RSS feed that is returned. You have 6 parameters that you can query the feed via - placeName, searchText, fromDate, toDate, fromADBC, toADBC; and you can page through results as well using an offset. Default records returned is 25. To use the paging method add for example (2,45) directly after the britishmuseum.opensearch syntax below.

An example query:

<blockquote>select * from britishmuseum.opensearch(2,45) where placeName="Egypt";</blockquote>

This returns page 3 (i.e. 1st page is 0 like an array) of the <a title="BM response for the query on Egypt" href="http://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql?q=select%20*%20from%20britishmuseum.opensearch(2%2C45)%20where%20placeName%3D%22Egypt%22%3B&amp;diagnostics=true&amp;env=store%3A%2F%2Fdatatables.org%2Falltableswithkeys">results set</a> and 45 items per page. You can filter and limit queries by amending the  YQL statement, but I won't go into that here.
<h4>The Brooklyn Museum tables</h4>
To use these tables, you will need to obtain a key to access their API, without this they are useless. There are 6 different areas of their api you can query:

1. Get rights types for content - there is actually a missing 's' in the current table, I've submitted the correction but it hasn't been pulled in yet. To query this once fixed:

[bash]select * from brooklyn.Collection.getRightsTypes where format='xml'  and api_key='YOURKEY';[/bash]

2. Get collections

[bash]select * from brooklyn.collection.getCollections where api_key='YOURKEY';[/bash]

Which returns:

[xml]
&lt;results&gt;
&lt;collections&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;21&quot; name=&quot;Arts of Africa&quot; short_name=&quot;African&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/african_art&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;23&quot; name=&quot;Arts of the Pacific Islands&quot; short_name=&quot;Pacific&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/pacific&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;9&quot; name=&quot;American Art&quot; short_name=&quot;American&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/american_art&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;10&quot; name=&quot;Arts of the Americas&quot; short_name=&quot;The Americas&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/arts_of_the_americas&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;20&quot; name=&quot;Arts of the Islamic World&quot; short_name=&quot;Islamic&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/arts_of_the_islamic_world&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;2&quot; name=&quot;Asian Art&quot; short_name=&quot;Asian&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/asian_art&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;8&quot; name=&quot;Contemporary Art&quot; short_name=&quot;Contemporary&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/contemporary_art&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;4&quot; name=&quot;Decorative Arts&quot; short_name=&quot;Decoratives&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/decorative_arts&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;5&quot; name=&quot;Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art&quot; short_name=&quot;Egyptian&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/egyptian&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;7&quot; name=&quot;European Art&quot; short_name=&quot;European&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/european_art&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;3&quot; name=&quot;Photography&quot; short_name=&quot;Photography&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/photography&quot;/&gt;
&lt;collection id=&quot;22&quot; name=&quot;Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art&quot; short_name=&quot;Sackler Center&quot; uri=&quot;http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/eascfa&quot;/&gt;
&lt;/collections&gt;
&lt;/results&gt;
[/xml]

3. Get geolocations

[bash]select * from brooklyn.collection.getGeoLocations where start_index='20' and api_key='YOUR KEY';[/bash]

4. Get images

[bash]select * from brooklyn.collection.getImages where item_type=&quot;object&quot; and item_id=&quot;4174&quot; and api_key='YOURKEY';[/bash]

5. Get item data

[bash]select * from brooklyn.collection.getItem where item_type=&quot;object&quot; and item_id=&quot;1687&quot; and api_key='EpXR2G4xzD';[/bash]

6. Search collection

[bash]select * from brooklyn.collection.search where keyword=&quot;Egypt&quot;and api_key='EpXR2G4xzD';[/bash]</code>
<h4>Digital New Zealand</h4>
These tables also need you to obtain an API key so that you can access the data they hold. There are 4 methods that you can call on this set of tables, each represented by their own table.

1. Get content partners

[bash]select * from digitalnz.contentpartners where format='xml' and api_key='c01d2eed7f914a8d08833da5b364ce49';[/bash]

2. Get metadata for an object

There is currently a spelling mistake in this table (extra d!), which I submitted a fix for, not taken up yet. So for now:

[bash]select * from digitalnz.getmetdadata where record_id='34522' and api_key='c01d2eed7f914a8d08833da5b364ce49';[/bash]

3. Get records in DNZ

[bash]select * from digitalnz.records where search_text='social welfare' and api_key='c01d2eed7f914a8d08833da5b364ce49';[/bash]
<h4>An example of more powerful use</h4>
One of the awesome things to do, is perform a multiple API query using the multiquery syntax; so for example, I want everything from each of these Museum collections where the keyword search is Egypt.

[bash]
select * from query.multi where queries=&quot;
        select object.images.image.uri,object.images.image.thumb_uri, object.uri, object.classification,object.label
 from brooklyn.collection.search where keyword='Egypt' and api_key='KEY';
        select * from britishmuseum.opensearch(0,50) where placeName='Egypt' ;
        select description,title,link,enclosure,image.url from blackcountryhistory.search(0,100) where q='egypt';
        select source-url,object-url,title,thumbnail-url from digitalnz.records where search_text='egypt' and api_key='KEY';
        select title,link,enclosure.url from nmm.collections.search where searchterm = 'egypt';&quot;
[/bash] ]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_name>yql-museums</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>GLAMwiki at the British Museum</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=1106</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=1106</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last Friday and Saturday saw the Galleries, Libraries, Archives and Museum sector come together with the Wikipedia community for a two day conference in the British Museum entitled '<a title="The Glamwiki website" href="http://uk.wikimedia.org/wiki/GLAM-WIKI">GLAMwiki</a>' - hashtag #glamwiki. This event was organised by Liam Wyatt, who was recently the British Museum's 'wikipedian' in residence (you can find out lots about this on his blog and from his various presentations that he has since made) and was attended by around 120 people, with perhaps a larger delegation from the Wiki world, mainly due to the overlap with the MCG conference at the Museum of London.

Presentations I attended were:
<ul>
	<li>Cory Doctorow "Being a beloved institution will get you through times of no money better than money will get you through times of being an irrelevant one."</li>
	<li>Joscelyn Upendran: Creative Commons and the Cultural Sector - Exercise Your Copyright to Help Build a Shared Culture</li>
	<li>Jill Cousins: Europeana and Wikimedia</li>
	<li>Unconference sort of organisation session (this was probably the weakest part of this conference)</li>
	<li>Funnily enough I went to - Daniel Pett: Integrating volunteers and Experts - examples from the Portable Antiquities Scheme</li>
	<li>The panel discussion (went to the pub and didn't get back for the address by Dr Crew's. Panelists: Director of Europeana Jill Cousins; Head of Digital at the BFI Paula Le Dieu; Chief executive of DACS Gilane Tawadros; Presenter of BBC's Digital Planet Bill Thompson.</li>
	<li>And then I came back for the afternoon tech session in the unconference and disappeared off to work afterwards.</li>
</ul>
The central premise of this conference was collaboration or cooperation; wikipedia has a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Advice_for_the_cultural_sector">page of advice</a> on how to interact with their platform and many of their members will help if you ask them. The Hoxne hoard challenge at the British Museum, showed how much can be achieved with collaborative efforts, but also, highlighted how much needs to be done to achieve the high quality article that would achieve featured status.

The permeating theme throughout the conference, I felt veered too much towards the perils of copyright, something I think GLAMs need to get over and move on from. There's a wider array of bigger issues that are out there for them at the moment. The digital work that we do is just an adjunct to the holistic offering that each institution; yes it is becoming more and more important, but we need to look at the bigger picture. This sector produces content, paid for out of public money or from grants and donations from funding bodies, which needs to be used and consumed by as many people as possible. The National Portrait Gallery's obstinate position on the wikipedia argument left many with a very dim view at the end of their presentation. Just licence your work to allow people to use it with proper attribution, produce content for the Wikipedia community that they can use and your revenue stream will be protected (not that they make much money as highlighted in the FOI request that can easily be retrieved.)

[slideshare id=5961465&amp;doc=wikipediafinal-101129053720-phpapp01]
My presentation

[slideshare id=5960281&amp;doc=wikipediaandthebritishmuseum-101129034329-phpapp02]
Matthew Cock's presentation on the Wikipedian in residence project]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>An experience not to be missed 5th September</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2005/09/06/an-experience-not-to-be-missed-5th-september/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Sep 2005 23:16:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>venicone</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/2005/09/06/an-experience-not-to-be-missed-5th-september/20/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Caroline the FLO is delivering the wee find to the British Museum in person on Tuesday 13th September - and it will be looked at by David Parsons , from the University of Nottingham on the 15th - so we might have some info soon.


<a href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/english/staff/parsons.htm">David Parsons</a>

He thinks the runes are Anglo Saxon and not Viking, but he needs to see it in the flesh really.

I have also posted more images of the find on the Portable Antiquities Image Gallery - you can see them here:

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/gallery/Treasure_act">More Images</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_utw_tags_0</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>Roman hoard unearthed</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2006/10/05/hoard/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 05 Oct 2006 09:13:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/172</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This article of news has been passed to me by our FLO Andrew Richardson

<a class="imagelink" title="Spade and coins" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/coins_spade.jpg"><img height="96" alt="Spade and coins" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/coins_spade.thumbnail.jpg" /></a> <a class="imagelink" title="Roamn coins" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/coins_situ.jpg"><img height="94" alt="Roamn coins" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/coins_situ.thumbnail.jpg" /></a> <a class="imagelink" title="The coin hoard" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/roman-hoard-press-image.jpg"><img height="96" alt="The coin hoard" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/roman-hoard-press-image.jpg" /></a>

A rare hoard of 3,600 late Roman coins has been unearthed on a Kent building site.

Archaeologists from Kent County Council's Heritage Conservation team recovered the coins and a pot in which they had been buried after being called to the Medway Valley site.

Workmen digging trenches with an excavator made the latest discovery when the digger arm caught the pot, spilling the coins.

Maidstone Museum Officer Laura McLean said:
<blockquote>"They saw all these coins come pouring out of the digger bucket. It made a sound like tinkling glass. When we got there they had two spades with the coins on the top. It was absolutely unbelievable."</blockquote>
The bronze coins date from 330 to 348 AD and the hoard is one of the largest to have been found in eastern England.

Kent County Council's Finds Liaison Officer Andrew Richardson, who was called in with a small team of volunteers to safely excavate them, said:
<blockquote>"The developer did absolutely the right thing. They stopped the work immediately and contacted us at Heritage Conservation.
This is a very exciting find. In four years of dealing with all the treasure in Kent I have never dealt with anything on this scale."</blockquote>
The coins show heads of the Roman Emperor Constantine and others in power at the time. It is thought they may have been deliberately buried in 348 or 349 AD following a major Imperial currency reform.  Some of the earlier coins in the hoard commemorate the foundation of the new Imperial Capital at Constantinople in 330 AD.
<blockquote>"The remarkable thing is that someone has gathered these coins together and stashed them because they were no longer legal tender," Dr Richardson said.</blockquote>
The coins are being kept safe by KCC at County Hall, Maidstone, before being transferred to the British Museum for cleaning and recording. The find will be reported to Mid Kent Coroner Roger Sykes and it is likely that he will call an inquest in the next few months to determine whether they can be declared as treasure.

It is hoped the hoard will be returned to Kent to go on display in a local museum.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Google maps and PAS data</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2006/10/15/maps/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 15 Oct 2006 19:19:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/173</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img alt="Google maps badge" title="Google maps badge" class="dec flow" src="http://www.google.com/intl/en_uk/images/maps_results_logo.gif" />I've been monitoring Andrew Larcombe's work on his demo site for a while to see what he comes up with next for his geomapping techniques. Tonight I found this demo:

AJAX map of finds from <a title="AJAX maps" href="http://www.andrewlarcombe.co.uk/index.php/pas">Surrey</a>

Andrew's implemented this by a combination of taking a freely available RSS feed from our <a title="Finds Database" href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk">database</a> (register so that you can do this) and the use of screen scraping. I think it is quite a good way of displaying map point data from our database and is something I'd like to see more people trying to do. I guess it helps that Andrew is part of our development team at OAD though!

Anyone else want to see what they can manage to do? I'm sure Steve White at <a title="Online Archaeology" href="http://www.online-archaeology.co.uk/Default.aspx">Online Archaeology</a> will see this and try and raise it.....]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Scheme makes National Geographic</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2006/10/23/whistle/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 Oct 2006 21:32:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/176</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I was just flicking through the National Geographic (November 2006, Archaeology snippets - no page numbers!) and saw that the hunting whistle (found in the Shalfleet area) mentioned in this very <a title="Hunting whistle post" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/14">early post</a> on the blog (and mentioned in the Telegraph) had just been featured. As far as I can remember, this is still going through the treasure process. The finder has attributed it to Henry VIII, but I think this is rather tenuous. Nice story none the less and lovely object. The IOW museum is hoping to acquire it. If anyone wants publicity photos, please get in touch.

<a class="imagelink" title="Hunting whistle" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/whistle.jpg"><img class="dec flow" alt="Hunting whistle" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2006/10/whistle.thumbnail.jpg" /></a>

Here's an excerpt from Frank's description on our <a title="Record on database" href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/hms/pas_obj.php?type=finds&amp;id=00142495659017BE">database</a>:
<blockquote>Incomplete silver huntsman’s whistle of Post Medieval date, probably early sixteenth century. Length 65.5mm. Weight 9.11g. The weight includes soil within the body of the whistle.

The whistle, cut from silver sheet, is folded and joined along the underside with a soldered seam. It increases in diameter from the mouth-piece, where it is 7mm in diameter, to the open end where the diameter is 9.5mm.
Two collars composed of spiralled silver wire divide the whistle into three sections. Threaded through each spiral is a silver wire core of the same size as the spirals. The first section has an obliquely angled mouth-piece (as viewed from the side) and a D-shaped sound-hole (as viewed from above). The second section is decorated with a grid of small punched squares. Upon this background are two chevron-shaped-panels which contain alternating motifs of roses and pomegranates. Each of the motifs is separated by a single or double pellet. The third section has a stamped and very worn maker’s mark. This mark is probably a letter B within a shield. Adjacent to the open end of this section is a cabled band around the body. Soldered over the seam, on the underside, is a small silver wire loop that secures a free running silver wire ring to facilitate attachment. This ring is 10mm in diameter and is made of wire which is slightly thicker than the wire forming the spirals. The whistle is slightly dented in places.</blockquote>
This will probably appear in the Treasure Report 2005 which will appear in late 2007, the report from 2004 is forthcoming this December at around the same time as the Scheme's Annual Report for 2005-2006. Treasure reported for the financial year so far is well ahead of previous figures with projected figures extrapolated at around 700 finds!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>whistle</wp:post_name>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="iow-museum"><![CDATA[IOW museum]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

			<wp:meta_key>tags</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_utw_tags_0</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[s:293:"a:5:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:11:"antiquities";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:11:"archaeology";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:24:"Archaeology-in-the-media";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:20:"portable-antiquities";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:16:"Treasure-process";}}";]]></wp:meta_value>
