	<item>
		<title>Metal gurus - Guardian article</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/02/13/frankyboy/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 13 Feb 2007 10:41:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/257</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Scheme has featured today in the Guardian, with a <a href="http://arts.guardian.co.uk/art/visualart/story/0,,2011990,00.html" title="Metal gurus">long article</a> on metal detecting and the work that we do. Frank Basford, FLO for the Isle of Wight features strongly in the print version.  Franks is praised for some aspects of his work below:
<blockquote>Basford is a sign of the new entente cordial between archaeologists and detectorists. An archaeologist, he is one of 36 finds liaison officers across England and Wales. He helps detectorists identify their finds and encourages them to report discoveries to the Portable Antiquities Scheme. Crucially, Basford has also persuaded the island's detectorists to log the location of every find with handheld GPS devices, which provides valuable distribution data for professional archaeologists.</blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">The GPS logging of these finds has been really precise, and we've been able to produce some really great multi period maps of the finds that Frank has recorded.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Conference programme</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/02/14/conferenceprog/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 14 Feb 2007 14:41:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/258</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The provisional programme for our conference has been drafted and it is laid out below. I doubt anyone will want to turn up to listen to what I have to say!   I'm personally looking forward to the Schadla-Hall talk as they are always worth listening to.

Conference tickets are available from Claire Costin (<a href="mailto:ccostin@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk">ccostin@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk</a>) - £10 for 1 day, £15 for both (concessions available).
<h3>Tuesday 17th April</h3>
Chair  – Sally Worrell

10.00: Welcome – Roger Bland
10.10: Dan Pett - "The Portable Antiquities Scheme's database: its development for research since 1998"
10.35: Clive Bond - "The Portable Antiquities Scheme: the contribution of lithics and lithic scatters"
11.00: Coffee
11.30: Richard Bradley - "Bronze Age hoards: their contribution to landscape archaeology"
11.55: Mark Lodwick - "Searching for Context: Cauldrons, Feasting, Axes &amp; Death in Later Prehistoric South Wales"
12.20: Duncan Garrow - “The technology of enchantment and the enchantment of technology? Iron Age Celtic Art, GIS analysis and the PAS"
12.45: Discussion
13.00: Lunch

Chair - JD Hill

14.00: Fraser Hunter - "Across the Divide: Iron Age Sty;es in Roman Britain"
14.25: Tom Brindle - "The Portable Antiquities Scheme and Roman Northamptonshire: Some Work in Progress"
14.50: Rob Collins - "Finds from the Roman Northern Frontier: Patterns from PAS Data"
15.20: Discussion
15.30: Tea
16.00: Sam Moorhead - "Extending the frontiers – how the PAS Roman coin database expands our knowledge of Roman coin use in England"
16.25: Jude Plouviez - "Counting Roman brooches"
16.50: Discussion
<h3>Wednesday 18th April</h3>
Chair – Leslie Webster

10.00: Welcome, fire exits etc
10.00: Mary Chester-Kadwell - "Patterns of Life and Death in the Early Anglo-Saxon Landscape of Norfolk"
10.25: Andrew Richardson and Laura McLean - "Early Anglo-Saxon Brooches in southern England: the contribution of the Portable Antiquities Scheme"
10.50: Martin Welch/Sue Harrington - "Beyond the Tribal Hidage: using portable antiquities to explore early Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in southern England"
11.15: Discussion
11.20 Coffee
11.45: Martin Biddle - tbc
12.10: Tania Dickinson - "The changing face of saucer-brooch distribution, 1912 - 1977 - 1997 – 2007"
12.30: Gabor Thomas - "The Missing Dimension: the circulation and production of Carolingian-style metalwork in Anglo-Saxon England"
12.55: Discussion
13.00: Lunch

Chair – Helen Geake

14.10: Mark Blackburn and Rachel Atherton - "Torksey: finds from a Viking winter camp"
14.35: Geoff Egan - "Widespread Devotion: New Insights from the Portable Aniquities Scheme into Pilgrim Trinkets"
15.00: John Cherry - "tbc"
15.25: Discussion
15.30: Tea
16.00: Anne Boyle - "What’s The Point? The Value of Find-Spot Data to Studies of Material Culture."
16.25: Tim Schadla-Hall - "tbc"
16.50: Discussion
17.00: Close]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What&#039;s goin&#039; on?</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/03/22/goingon/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Mar 2007 21:34:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/259</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It has been a little quiet around here for a while, but that is down to various factors! I've been catching up on some leave time - Skiing in France and some time in the Souks of Marrakech. However, things are changing within the database of the Scheme. Over the next few weeks, certain changes are underway; these include:

<ol>
	<li>Larger thumbnails on the finds page</li>
	<li>Removal of border from around image thumbnails on the image lister</li>
	<li>Introduction of newer counties - Worcestershire, Herefordshire, Rutland etc (we've finally caught up!)</li>
	<li>Introduction of regional attribution - you can now do a search for East Anglia or Wales. Quite useful?</li>
	<li>Javascript tying of region: county: district: parish</li>
</ol>
To come:
<ol>
	<li>User interface enhancements</li>
	<li>Numismatic interface overhaul</li>
	<li>GIS overhaul</li>
	<li>And a few more things that I'd rather wait and see if they work.</li>
</ol>
On other fronts, the Conference is now booked out and development of other data sets and resources are well underway. You may see a preview of these at the Conference. Should be a good couple of days. Off to Philadelphia straight afterwards and the World Cup Cricket after that. We're also seeing how we can contribute to the Pleiades project at UNC and the various numismatic projects we are signed up to. There's also a PhD in partnership with UCL and the AHRC that will be announced shortly. Go for it!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>More database improvements</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/04/08/updates/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 08 Apr 2007 22:47:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/260</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This is just an update on database improvements over the last week:

Coin forms have been introduced for each period (Iron Age, Roman, Early Medieval, Medieval, Post Medieval.) The choices that can be made on data entry are now tied to the correct choices. This should therefore limit the amount of errors that are made by accident due to clicking the wrong option in a long list of rulers/denominations/ etc
Reece periods have now been assigned to Roman coins, geographic areas will be added for Iron Age coins, categories and types for coins that fall under the EMC jurisdiction etc.

Once all database changes have settled down on the numismatic front, these tied dropdowns will be released and made available for others to use. These choices have been influenced by the revamp of the CCI, RPC and the EMC. There is also a new addition to the period list (just to accomodate these coins) with the appearance of Greek &amp; Roman Provincial coins, which uses dropdown data generated from the SNG. There won't be many of these.....

The tidying up of counties is now underway, therefore you can find artefacts from Worcestershire and not just from Hereford and Worcester.  This will take time as we check validity of grid references to parish level, but will be finished soon (then you start all over again with the new data!)

To come over the next week or so - expansion of results to show thumbnails if present, better data editing fields, new search screens, rss visibility enhanced, better metadata on image screens and a few more subtle changes. This should aid navigation of this site. We appreciate that this has been an issue, but we have been limited due to development funds being minimal. The site now has over 1/4 million objects recorded and 135,000 images. We have also added 11000 coin records from Norfolk in the last month from spreadsheets. Other improvements that we hope to roll out include enhanced map client and some more HER improvements. It is getting more usable slowly....]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>New PhD announcement</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/04/09/docdoc/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 08 Apr 2007 23:35:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/261</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/images/ucl0029.gif" alt="UCL logo" class="dec flow" />Collaborative PhD in Roman coin finds in Britain: The Institute of Archaeology, University College London and the Portable Antiquities Scheme, The British Museum

<img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/images/small_logos/BMpuk.jpg" alt="British Museum logo">This AHRC funded PhD will support a student in researching the 45,000 or more Roman coins that have been recorded by the Portable Antiquities Scheme (<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk" title="Scheme website">www.finds.org.uk</a>) since 1997.  The Project will start at the end of September 2007 for three years.  The successful candidate will develop and apply a range of research methods to the data and present a coherent analysis of the PAS finds against existing published material.  The student will be based at the Institute of Archaeology and the British Museum where the Portable Antiquities Scheme is administered.  Knowledge of and interest in Roman archaeology is important and candidates must be prepared to learn and apply statistical techniques.  Applicants must be either UK residents (full studentship) or EU nationals (fees only).

They should normally have, or expect soon to be awarded, a Masters degree.

For further information, contact the project supervisors:

Kris Lockyear (<a href="mailto:k.lockyear@ucl.ac.uk" title="Email the womble">k.lockyear@ucl.ac.uk</a>) or Sam Moorhead (<a href="mailto:smoorhead@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk" title="Email Sam the man">smoorhead@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk</a>)

Information on Research Degrees at the Institute of Archaeology is available at: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/resstud/index.htm">http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/resstud/index.htm</a>

Downloadable application forms are available from: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate-study/application-admission">http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate-study/application-admission</a>

Applications are due by May 18th.  Short-listed applicants will need to be available for interview on June 6th.   Completed applications including proposed research design should be sent to:
Lisa Daniel,
Graduate Programme Administrator AHRC IOA/PAS PhD
Institute of Archaeology
University College London
31–34 Gordon Square
London WC1H 0PY
United Kingdom]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Conference day tomorrow</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/04/16/day1/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Apr 2007 20:36:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/262</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Scheme's tenth anniversary conference is on at the British Museum tomorrow and Wednesday. This is a chance for the Scheme to demonstrate the impact that the Scheme and analysis of collected data, has made upon the archaeological world.  There's an extremely varied lineup, some great speakers and some really interesting research to be demonstrated. The two day conference covers all periods that the Scheme records and draws directly from the database that we have now been filling for over 5 years. I'll be outlining how this has developed since I joined the Scheme and also speaking about some forthcoming developments that we're rolling out. I'll also discuss the forthcoming revamp of the Celtic Coin Index, a new and enhanced database with various web 2.0 methodologies encapsulated - tagging, ratings, downloads, KML, XML, REST. It's a big job and probably the best thing I have programmed so far.

Tickets sold out for this nearly 3 weeks ago, and we're inundated with requests from disappointed people. The proceedings will be published and if I get the chance, the powerpoints will be made available as pdf documents on this website. This may not happen until the start of May as I'm off to see the Cricket Semi-final in St Lucia (Australia vs someone)!  However, I'll add any photos that I get and if you attend and take any, please do share them. We'll be glad to post them here.

If you're coming, the day kicks off at 10am and there's some added bonus things in the delegate pack  - 10% off at the British Museum bookshop and buy one, get one free main meals at a local Wagamama's restaurant.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_id>63</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Alan Radley]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>alan@alanradley.plus.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>87.113.8.31</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-04-19 16:05:45</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-04-19 15:05:45</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I really enjoyed this latest conference, thanks to all involved in making this a great couple of days. There are so many questions I would have liked to ask at the end, but time wasn’t on our side.
The talks went a long way to explaining what happens to the data collected by FLOs, and why it is important to people undertaking research. I wonder though  if it’s possible to have “Data Overload”. In as much as someone takes years collecting records of various types of finds, which is fine in theory, but does it always have an end application. In much the same way that most museums have boxes of finds in storage, which never see the light of day,  with staff not knowing what they have or haven’t got in storage.  In years to come will people forget that a lot of this data exists. I may not have put this very well, but I hope you get what I am trying to put across.
I found the use of graphs and bar charts a little overwhelming, one of the perils of using Powerpoint  methinks ? I’m sure there must be a better way.
Thanks to the lovely Mary for putting my picture up on the screen (I’ll get even)  
What a lovely chap Tim Schadla-Hall is, I hope he is at PAS 2008
Lots more I’d like to say, it’s a great shame that we still don’t have the open forum, to discuss these things.
Alan….  Essex Detector Society
AKA    Deetektor… UKDN
AKA    Tetricus ….Ch4 forum and Corinne’s Time Team forum]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>New A-level spec - archaeology</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/04/16/new-a-level-spec-archaeology/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Apr 2007 21:27:55 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>Conference papers</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/04/17/conference-papers/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Apr 2007 11:33:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/264</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'll be adding the conference papers as and when I get access to them.

To recap, here's the first day's speakers:

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/dan.pdf" title="Dan Pett's talk">The Portable Antiquities Scheme's Database: Its Development for Research Since 1998</a>
<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/06/dp_pas_conf07.pdf' title='Unedited proceedings write up'>Unedited proceedings write up</a>
Dan Pett, British Museum

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/bond.pdf" title="Clive's talk">The Portable Antiquities Scheme: the Contribution of Lithics and Lithic Scatters
</a>Clive Bond, University of Winchester

Bronze Age Hoards: Their Contribution to Landscape Archaeology
Richard Bradley, University of Reading

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/lodwick.pdf" title="Mark Lodwick's talk">Searching for Context: Cauldrons, Feasting, Axes &amp; Death in Later Prehistoric South Wales </a>
Mark Lodwick, Museum of Wales

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/garrow.pdf" title="Duncan's talk">The Technology of Enchantment and the Enchantment of Technology? Iron Age Celtic Art, GIS analysis and the PAS</a>
Duncan Garrow, University of Oxford

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/hunter.pdf" title="Fraser Hunter's talk">Across the Divide: Iron Age Styles in Roman Britain</a>
Fraser Hunter, National Museum of Scotland

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/brindle.pdf" title="Tom Brindle's talk">The Portable Antiquities Scheme and Roman Northamptonshire: Some Work in Progress</a> Tom Brindle, King’s College London

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/collins.pdf" title="Rob Collin's talk">Finds from the Roman Northern Frontier: Patterns from PAS</a>
Data Rob Collins,University of Newcastle

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/sam.pdf" title="Sam's talk">Extending the frontiers: How the PAS Roman Coin Database Expands Our Knowledge of Roman Coin Use inEngland</a>
Sam Moorhead, British Museum

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/jude.pdf" title="Jude's talk">Counting Roman Brooches</a>
Jude Plouviez, Suffolk Archaeological Service]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Codex game show recruiting people</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/04/30/codexcontestants/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Apr 2007 08:33:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/265</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hosted by Tony Robinson CODEX is back for a second series – but this time two teams will compete every week to win the history quiz series!

Are you interested in history? Are you brave enough to spend the night in a Museum? Can you make up a team?

We are looking for teams of 3 people, who need to know each other, work together or have shared knowledge to make up a team. Teams can be made up of colleagues, family members or friends all with a connection to history, through a shared profession or a hobby. Maybe you’re brewers or traders, artists or engineers, students or sailors, potters or politicians ... we’re open to ideas!.

We will be auditioning round the country in the next couple of weeks so please get in touch as soon as possible for an application form. We will be filming with the chosen contestants before the recording so there will be advertising possibilities for teams taking part. We are filming the series at the British Museum in London in June, 2007.

Teams will compete in a series of quiz rounds, based around some of the most famous historical artefacts in the British Museum.

Contact us now!

EMAIL: mailto:codex@diverse.tv or call 0207 855 7463]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Data Sans Frontières: web portals and the historic environment</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/01/data-sans-frontieres-web-portals-and-the-historic-environment/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 May 2007 12:20:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/266</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The British Museum is hosting a conference outlined below on 25 May 2007. I'm speaking about the benefits of RSS in various flavours and the syndication of content, only a 10 minute talk. I'll also talk a bit about Pleiades and the CCI revamp.

Organised by the Historic Environment Information Resources Network (HEIRNET) and supported by the AHRC ICT Methods Network and the British Museum, this one-day conference takes a comprehensive look at exciting new opportunities to use portal technologies and Web 2.0 approaches to disseminate and integrate historic environment data. Bringing together speakers from national organisations, national and local government and academia, options for cooperation at both national and international levels will be explored.

The aims of the conference are:

* To raise awareness of current portal and interoperability technologies
* To raise awareness of current developments in the online dissemination of Historic Environment Data
* To set developments in the historic environment sector in a wider national and European information context
* To create a vision for a way forward for joined up UK historic environment information provision

This conference should be of interest to heritage professionals, researchers and data managers from all sectors.Places are now filling up for this conference, it costs £12 and a full programme, online registration and payment facilities are available at <a href="http://www.britarch.ac.uk/HEIRNET/">http://www.britarch.ac.uk/HEIRNET/</a>. It is also possible to pay by cheque or cash on the day, but please reserve your place by email at dsf@britarch.ac.uk  We look forward to seeing you there. Stuart Jeffrey (ADS) and Dan Hull (CBA) dsf@britarch.ac.uk]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>More conference papers</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/02/conference2/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 02 May 2007 09:24:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/267</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img width="150" height="120" align="right" class="dec flow" alt="Beausejour stadium St Lucia" title="IMG00068" src="http://www.7pillarsofwisdom.co.uk/gallery/d/14605-2/IMG00068.jpg" />Apologies for the slow posting of the conference papers that I have located. I've been on leave watching cricket and scuba diving in St Lucia. I know, it is a hard life!

<a href="http://www.arch.cam.ac.uk/~mec31/" title="Mary's website">Patterns of Life and Death in the Early Anglo-Saxon Landscape of Norfolk</a>
Mary Chester-Kadwell, University of Cambridge

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/mclean.pdf" title="Andrew and Laura's talk">Early Anglo-Saxon Brooches in Southern England: the Contribution of the Portable Antiquities Scheme</a>
Andrew Richardson and Laura McLean, Kent Heritage Conservation

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/welch.pdf" title="Sue's talk">Beyond the Tribal Hidage: Using Portable Antiquities Data to Explore Early Anglo-Saxon Kingdoms in Southern England</a>
Martin Welch/Sue Harrington, Institute of Archaeology, UCL

Winchester and the Anglo-Saxon Settlement of the Itchen Valley: a PAS Perspective
Martin Biddle, University of Oxford

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/tania.pdf" title="Tania's talk">The Changing Face of Saucer-Brooch Distribution, 1912-1977-1997-2007</a>
Tania Dickinson, University of York

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/gabor.pdf" title="gabor's talk">The Missing Dimension: the Circulation and Production of Carolingian-Style Metalwork in Anglo-Saxon England</a>
Gabor Thomas, University of Kent

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/blackburn.pdf" title="Mark and Rachel's talk">Torksey: Finds from a Viking Winter Camp</a>
Mark Blackburn and Rachel Atherton, Fitzwilliam Museum and Derby Museums &amp; Art Gallery

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/egan.pdf" title="Geoff's talk">Widespread Devotion: New Insights from the Portable Antiquities Scheme into Pilgrim Trinkets</a>
Geoff Egan, Museum of London

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/cherry.pdf" title="John's talk">Personal and Impersonal Impressions: Identity Revealed Through Seals</a>
John Cherry, formerly British Museum

<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/documents/conf07/boyle.pdf" title="Anne's talk">What’s The Point? The Value of Find-Spot Data to Studies of Material Culture</a>
Anne Boyle, Archaeological Project Services, Lincolnshire

"No, No, No, Everything is Reported by Law, There is no Problem". The Difference a Decade Makes... 10 Years On is There a Better Solution? Tim Schadla-Hall, Institute of Archaeology, UCL]]></content:encoded>

		<title>New photography book</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/03/photos/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 May 2007 15:05:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/268</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://homepage.mac.com/ian.cartwright/.cv/ian.cartwright/Sites/.Pictures/Ians%20Bookcover%20copy.jpg-thumb_121_91.jpg" alt="Front cover">There's a new book that has just come out on photographing archaeological small finds. I'm not sure how good it is as I haven't seen a copy. However, it could be useful for many of our intrepid readers and even some archaeologists.

You can obtain copies directly from the author via his website:

<a href="http://www.learn2photo.com">http://www.learn2photo.com</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Musical PAS staff</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/03/muzak/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 May 2007 15:11:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/269</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/buyitnow1.jpg' alt='Silver lakes ep'>Our Scheme brethren are a talented lot. Current FLO, Adam Daubney of Lincolnshire or thereabouts, has just released a cd on itunes and in your local stores. He's in a band called "The Silver Lakes", you can read more about him and his friends on their <a href="http://www.thesilverlakes.com/">website</a>. Their latest single is called "the Wait", could be apt as that is what you do when you interrogate our database.

Secondly, former FLO and now PhD student, Tom Brindle esq, is in a band called "Men in Caves". What a top name. Troglodytes are us. You can read about Tom and his exploits at their <a href="http://www.menincaves.com/">website</a> or on their myspace site. They also have the tallest rock star in the world.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>269</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2007-05-03 16:11:01</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2007-05-03 15:11:01</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

	<item>
		<title>Google analytics presentation</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/03/analyse-that/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 May 2007 20:53:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/271</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.google.com/analytics/images/logo_ga.gif" alt="GA logo">I presented a talk to some of the Museum's staff today on the data that we're collecting on the Museum's family of websites. I'm not officially involved in the BM's web team, but I've provided them with a lot of help over the last year and a bit as they work towards the new release in May.

The talk showed what our marketing, IT and visitor services staff can gain from the usage of analytical reporting software. Perhaps the thing that made them listen most was the idea that we're missing out on presenting ourselves to vast audience chunks of the world. The lack of Far Eastern visitors, and especially Australia and Japan, was a bit mystifying for many.
As we move towards our new website structure, what becomes very apparent is that the Ancient Civilizations websites are widely used outside England, with very little prominence on the BM site. If these were promoted more regularly, they may well be better used.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/ga.pdf' title='The Museum and Google Analytics'>The Museum and Google Analytics</a> - if you find any glaring errors let me know!

As far as the Scheme is concerned, what I would really like is more prominence for our web presence within the BM structure and else where. We're now starting to add more web banners to partner sites to try and draw in more visitors from other areas and trace our marketing campaigns. As we can offer our content for others to use, it might well be attractive. Our webstats are still on the up. I now need to get our database to use the analytics codes as well and maybe buy into click density from BoxUK.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Worst hobby?</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/03/beeep/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 May 2007 22:58:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/273</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://img.slate.com/media/1/123125/2077893/2078443/2086908/030812_metalDetector.jpg" alt="MD image">This story  might amuse some of our readers. Mike Heyworth from the CBA, sent me a link to this article - <a href="http://www.slate.com/id/2086909/">"The world's worst hobby"</a>. Have a read and see what you think! So the challenge is find something that is better and pokes fun at anything to do with archaeology.



Whilst we're on this, the Indy ran an article on working as an <a href="http://education.independent.co.uk/careers_advice/article2502650.ece">archaeologist</a> (do I still get to say I'm technically an archaeologist?) I got out of digging holes as soon as uni finished and went to work in the City. I think that was a smart move.....

Other things that you may also be interested in include the new BBC series "The Museum". The BBC website says:

<blockquote>The British Museum has thrown open its doors to allow BBC Television cameras to go behind the scenes for the very first time. The result is a revealing, 10-part documentary series which finds out the real highs and lows of life at one of the most famous and revered institutions in the world.</blockquote>

<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.co.uk/Product.aspx?ID=1256"><img src="http://www.britishmuseum.co.uk/images/products/39131_web_240.jpg" alt="BM BBC book"></a>Thankfully I avoided all cameras for this programme, but colleague Ian Leins even features in the new book with week old stubble. Nice.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Search screen redesign</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/04/search/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 May 2007 14:13:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/274</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As part of the database overhaul, it is planned to overhaul the database's advanced search facility. This is the area where we have had most problems with our users. Therefore the attached pdf shows a greyscreen schematic of how we would like to make our search interface look.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/search.pdf' title='Search form redesign draft'>Search form redesign draft</a>

By way of explanation:

* Artefacts are still searched separately to coins.
* Coins are split into: Iron Age, Greek and Roman Provincial, Roman, Early Medieval, Medieval, Post Medieval
* These search screens are designed so that you fill in as much or as little of the form as you want. Therefore you can design a simple or complex search.

Some of the database fields will use javascript links to enable the search boxes to be more intelligent. For example, you have to choose the county to get the parish as there is some duplicity in parish name around the counties.

So what we need is some feedback. Would these make the database easier for you to use?
Add comments below, no registration needed.]]></content:encoded>

<a href="http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article1738468.ece">Behind the scenes at the British Museum-Arts &amp; Entertainment-Visual Arts-TimesOnline</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>National Archaeology Week</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/08/national-archaeology-week/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 May 2007 15:33:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/277</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Portable Antiquities Scheme Archaeological Finds Roadshows 2007

Throughout National Archaeology Week, the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) will be running a series of archaeological finds identification and recording sessions at local museums and other venues: often these will include a variety of other activities for adults and children.

14 July – National Finds Roadshow
There will be at least one Finds Roadshow in every part of the country in conjunction with experts at the British Museum and local museums, who will be on hand to identify and record archaeological objects found by the public.

15 – 22 July – Finds Days across England
Throughout National Archaeology Week there will be further finds days as part of programmes in local museums – look under the county listings for further details.


The Portable Antiquities Scheme is a voluntary scheme to record archaeological objects found by members of the public in England and Wales. Every year many thousands of objects are discovered, many of these by metal-detector users, but also by people whilst out walking, gardening or going about their daily work. Such discoveries offer an important source for understanding our past and are published on the Scheme’s website – www.finds.org.uk.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>277</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2007-05-08 16:33:58</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2007-05-08 15:33:58</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>national-archaeology-week</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="archaeology"><![CDATA[archaeology]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="british-museum"><![CDATA[British Museum]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="metal-detector-users"><![CDATA[metal detector users]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="museums"><![CDATA[Museums]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="united-kingdom"><![CDATA[United Kingdom]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="wales"><![CDATA[Wales]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="www-finds-org-uk"><![CDATA[www.finds.org.uk]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_utw_tags_0</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>Web stats</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/13/grrrrr/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 13 May 2007 15:13:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/278</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm in a strop at the moment as our providers at <a href="http://oxarchdigital.com">Oxford ArchDigital</a> have managed to lose our log files to a corruption and no backups have been made. Luckily, we've been collecting data via Google Analytics for the last year for this site. However, I've not got data for our database site, which is exceptionally annoying when we need to submit stats for the current Comprehensive Spending Review to ensure full funding.

The attached file includes all the data from May 06 - May 07. It does show some interesting things up - Roman coins is our most popular content and we get far less visitors from the States than our log files demonstrated previously.
I've now got the BM staff more interested in analysing data provided by GA, which is great as now they realise the benefits of targeting audiences.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/finds.pdf' title='Download the stats document'>Download the stats document</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Changing recording patterns</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/15/changing-recording-patterns/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 May 2007 17:13:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/282</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm not sure how interested you'll be in the below, but I've just been plotting some GIS of the changing picture that the recording of objects through the Scheme has given to our national chance find distribution.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003.jpg' title='Finds from 2003'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Finds from 2003' /></a> <a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_4.jpg' title='Finds from 2003 - 2004'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_4.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Finds from 2003 - 2004' /></a> <a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_5.jpg' title='Finds from 2003 - 2005'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_5.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Finds from 2003 - 2005' /></a> <a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_6.jpg' title='Finds from 2003 - 2006'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_6.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Finds from 2003 - 2006' /></a>

From left to right, the plots are:
a) All finds for 2003
b) All finds for 2003 to 2004
c) All finds for 2003 to 2005
d) All finds for 2003 to 2006

I then plotted two other GIS outcomes using the CCI data that I have been manipulating for Phil de Jersey and another set of recently released data, the Guest and Wells "Roman coins from Wales" data. This can be downloaded direct from the ADS website.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/conference.jpg' title='CCI data set plotted over PAS data set'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/conference.thumbnail.jpg' alt='CCI data set plotted over PAS data set' /></a> <a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/guest.jpg' title='Guest and Wells’ dataset over PAS'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/guest.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Guest and Wells’ dataset over PAS' /></a>

The above maps are ordered as left - CCI over PAS and right - Welsh Roman coins over PAS.
This can then be zoomed in to show just our Roman coins compared to Guest's Roman coins from Wales. Quite a discrepancy!
<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/guestvspas.jpg' title='Guest Vs PAS'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/guestvspas.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Guest Vs PAS' /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>National Archaeology Week events</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/19/naw2007/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 May 2007 14:28:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/289</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Throughout National Archaeology Week (14 – 22 July) the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) will be running a series of archaeological finds identification and recording sessions at local museums and other venues: often these will include a variety of other activities for adults and children. On the 14 July, in conjunction with experts at the British Museum and local museums, there will be at least one Finds Roadshow in every part of the country.


<strong>14 July (national event)</strong>

North of England
Grosvenor Museum, Chester, Cheshire - 10.30-16.30 (contact: Frances McIntosh - T. 0151 478 4259).
Museum of Antiquities, Newcastle-upon-Tyne - 10.00-16.00 (contact: Rob Collins - T. 0191 222 5076; <a href="mailto:robert.collins@ncl.ac.uk">robert.collins@ncl.ac.uk</a>).
Museum of Lancashire, Preston, Lancashire - 12.30-15.30 (contact: Dot Bruns - T. 01772 532175; <a href="mailto:Dot.Bruns@mus.lancscc.gov.uk">Dot.Bruns@mus.lancscc.gov.uk</a> ) (educational event only).

West Midlands
Roman Alcester Heritage Centre, Alcester, Warwickshire - 11.30-14.30 (contact: Angie Bolton - T. 01905 721130; <a href="mailto:abolton@cityofworcester.gov.uk">abolton@cityofworcester.gov.uk</a>).

East Midlands
Chesterfield Museum, Chesterfield, Derbyshire - 11.00-15.00 (contact: Anja Rohde – T. 01332 716665; <a href="mailto:anja.rohde@derby.gov.uk">anja.rohde@derby.gov.uk</a>).
Jewry Wall Museum, Leicester, Leicestershire - 11.30-16.00 (contact: Wendy Scott – T. 0116 265 8325; <a href="mailto:wscott@leics.gov.uk">wscott@leics.gov.uk</a>).
Wooton Hall Park, Northampton, Northamptonshire - 10.00-15.00 (contact: Steven Ashby – T. 01604 237249; <a href="mailto:sashby@northamptonshire.gov.uk">sashby@northamptonshire.gov.uk</a>).

East
Museum of Archaeology &amp; Anthropology, Cambridge, Cambridgeshire – times tbc (contact: Philippa Walton – T. 01223 717573; <a href="mailto:philippa.walton@cambridgeshire.gov.uk">philippa.walton@cambridgeshire.gov.uk</a>).
Verulamium Museum, St Albans, Hertfordshire - 11.00-16.30 (contact: Julian Watters – T. 01727 751 826; <a href="mailto:j.watters@stalbans.gov.uk">j.watters@stalbans.gov.uk</a>).

South West
Royal Albert Memorial Museum, Exeter, Devon - 10.30-16.00 (contact: Danielle Wootton – T. 01392 665858; <a href="mailto:danielle.wootton@exeter.gov.uk">danielle.wootton@exeter.gov.uk</a>).
Salisbury Museum, Salisbury Museum, Wiltshire - 10.00-16.00 (contact: Katie Hinds – T. 01722 332151; katiehinds@salisburymuseum.org.uk).
Wimborne Minster, Dorset - 10.00-16.00 (contact: Ciorstaidh Hayward Trevarthen – T. 01305 224921; c.h.trevarthen@dorsetcc.gov.uk).

South East
Havant Museum, Havant, Hampshire - 10.30-15.30 (contact: Rob Webley – T. 01962 848269; RWebley@winchester.gov.uk).
Guildford Museum, Guildford, Surrey - 11.00-13.00 (contact: David Williams – T. 01737 247296; david.williams@surreycc.gov.uk).
Maidstone Museum, Maidstone, Kent - 10.00-16.00 (contact: Andrew Richardson – T. 01622 221544; andrew.richardson@kent.gov.uk).
tbc Michael Faraday School, Southwark, London – times tbc (contact: Kate Sutton – T. 020 78145733; ksutton@museumoflondon.org.uk) (educational event only).
Newport Roman Villa, Newport, Isle of Wight - 10.00-16.00 (contact: Frank Basford – T. 01983 529963; frank.basford@iow.gov.uk).
Risborough Festival – Risborough Community Centre, Risborough, Buckinghamshire - 14.00-17.00 (contact: Ros Tyrell – T. 01296 624519; rtyrrell@buckscc.gov.uk).

15 July
Archaeological Excavation, Bigbury-on Sea, Devon – times tbc (contact: Danielle Wootton – as above) (educational event only).
Grosvenor Museum, Chester, Cheshire - 10.30-16.30 (contact: Frances McIntosh – as above).
Roman Town House, Dorchester, Dorset - 11.00-16.00 (contact: Ciorstaidh Hayward Trevarthen – as above).
Maritime Museum, Lancaster, Lancashire - 14.00-16.00 (contact: Dot Bruns – as above) (educational event only).
Verulamium Museum, St Albans, Hertfordshire - 14.30-16.30 (contact: Julian Watters –as above).

16 July
Burton Family &amp; Local History Centre, Burton-upon-Trent, Staffordshire – 10.00-12.00 &amp; 13.00-15.00 (contact: Caroline Johnson – T. 0121 303 4636; caroline_a_johnson@birmingham.gov.uk) (educational event only).
Gosport Discovery Centre, Gosport, Hampshire - 10.30-15.30 (contact: Rob Webley – as above).
Wakefield Museum, Wakefield, West Yorkshire - 14.00-16.00 (contact: Amy Cooper – T. 01924 305359; acooper@wyjs.org.uk).

17 July
Rickinghall Church, Rickinghall, Suffolk - 14.00-18.00 (contacts: Faye Minter &amp; Jane Carr – T. 01284 352 449; faye.minter@et.suffolkcc.gov.uk).
St Chad's Church, Stafford, Staffordshire - 10.30-14.30 (contact: Caroline Johnson – as above).

18 July
Clifton Park Museum, Rotherham, South Yorkshire - 14.00-16.00 (contact: Amy Cooper – as above).
Museum of Archaeology, Southampton, Hampshire - 10.00-15.00 (contact: Rob Webley – as above).
Museum of Lancashire, Lancaster, Lancashire - 14.30-16.30 (contact: Dot Bruns – as above). (educational event only).
Rugby Museum &amp; Art Gallery, Rugby, Warwickshire - 13.00-14.30 (contact: Angie Bolton – as above).
Swindon Museum, Swindon - 10.00-12.30 &amp; 13.30-16.00 (contact: Katie Hinds – as above).
Warrington Museum, Warrington, Cheshire - 13.00-16.30 (contact: Frances McIntosh – as above).

19 July
Lancaster City Museum, Lancaster, Lancashire - 14.30-16.30 (contact: Dot Bruns – as above).
Mansfield Woodhouse Library, Mansfield Woodhouse, Nottinghamshire - 10.30-14.00 (contacts: Rachel Atherton &amp; Anja Rohde – T. 01332 716665 ; rachel.atherton@derby.gov.uk).
tbc St Chad's Church, Stafford, Staffordshire – times tbc 09.30-11.30 &amp; 12.45-14.45 (contact: Caroline Johnson – as above)  (educational event only).

20 July
Alton Museum, Alton, Hampshire - 10.30-15.30 (contact: Rob Webley – as above).
Museum of Lancashire, Preston, Lancashire - 14.30-16.30 (contact: Dot Bruns – as above).
Norton Priory, Halton, Merseyside - 12.00-16.30 (contact: Frances McIntosh – as above).

21 July
Andover Museum, Andover, Hampshire - 10.30-15.30 (contact: Rob Webley – as above).
Buckinghamshire County Museum, Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire - 11.00-16.00 (contact: Ros Tyrell – as above).
The Roman Baths Museum, Bath, North East Somerset - 10.00-16.00 (contact: Kurt Adams – T. 0117 9222613; kurt_adams@bristol-city.gov.uk).
Bolton Museum, Bolton, Greater Manchester - 10.00-16.30 (contact: Frances McIntosh – as above).
Donington Manor House, Donington Le Heath, Leicestershire - 11.00-16.00 (contact: Wendy Scott – as above).
Guildhall in Priory Park, Chichester, West Sussex - 10.00-13.00 &amp; 14.00-16.00 (contact: Liz Andrews-Wilson – T. 01273 405731; flo@sussexpast.co.uk).
Chippenham Museum, Chippenham, Wiltshire – times tbc (contact: Katie Hinds – as above).
Kirton Living History Festival, Kirton, Suffolk - 11.00-17.00 (contact: Faye Minter &amp; Jane Carr – as above).
Lancaster City Museum, Lancaster, Lancashire - 10.30-15.30 (contact: Dot Bruns – as above).
Leatherhead &amp; District Museum, Leatherhead, Surrey - 10.00-16.00 (contact: David Williams – as above).
Museum of London, London – times tbc (contact: Kate Sutton – as above).
Millgate Museum, Newark, Nottinghamshire - 10.30-12.30 (followed by an educational event only from 14.00-16.00) (contacts: Rachel Atherton &amp; Anja Rohde – as above).
North Lincolnshire Museum, Scunthorpe, North Lincolnshire - 11.00-15.00 (contact: Lisa Staves – T. 01724 843533; lisa.staves@northlincs.gov.uk).
Royal Cornwall Museum, Truro, Cornwall - 10.00-16.00 (contact: Anna Tyacke – T. 01872 272 205, ext 219; anna.tyacke@royalcornwallmuseum.org.uk).
Wells Museum, Wells, Somerset - 12.00-16.00 (contact: Naomi Payne - T. 01823 320200; NCPayne@somerset.gov.uk).
Oxfordshire Museum, Woodstock, Oxfordshire - 10.30-16.30 (contact: Charlotte Burrill – T. 01635 519534; cburrill@westberks.gov.uk).

22 July
Devizes Museum, Devizes, Wiltshire - 11.00-16.00 (contact: Katie Hinds – see above).
Museum in the Docklands, London – times tbc (contact: Kate Sutton – see above).
Sefton Museum, Sefton, Merseyside - 14.00-17.00 (contact: Frances McIntosh – see above).
Woodbury Castle &amp; Common, Woodbury, Devon – times tbc (contact: Danielle Wootton – see above).]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Portable Antiquities Scheme database: it’s a mystery to me!</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/19/the-portable-antiquities-scheme-database-its-a-mystery-to-me/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 May 2007 14:58:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/290</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This article aims to lay to rest some of the gripes that many people have with the Portable Antiquities Scheme database. Since I joined the Scheme in April 2003 from an Investment Bank, I have been responsible for the development of the Scheme’s IT infrastructure. Compared to the budget of the projects on which I previously worked, we’d spend the same amount as we’ve spent on the Scheme’s IT on just 60 personal computers (a trading floor has thousands!) The majority of my work is based on web technology and in this I am entirely self-taught from the web and various books. I currently build and maintain the Scheme’s main website (www.finds.org.uk), the children’s website (<a href="http://www.pastexplorers.org.uk">www.pastexplorers.org.uk</a>), the All Party Parliamentary Archaeology Group website (<a href="http://www.appag.org.uk">www.appag.org.uk</a>) and several others that are numismatic based. The other aspect of my job involves project managing the development of our much-criticised database (<a href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk">www.findsdatabase.org.uk</a>), which is maintained by Oxford ArchDigital.

The database has now been online since the 1st week of April 2003 (indeed it was formulated before I was appointed, and therefore a legacy was left for me to deal with.) It is designed to:

•	Allow for centralised collection of object and numismatic data
•	Allow public access to these data
•	Allow for transfer of these data to the relevant Historic Environment Records
•	Store high resolution images
•	Manipulate spatial data to allow for study
•	Provide a lasting record of highly mobile artefacts – quite often it is the one and only chance the Scheme has to record them.

<strong>How much did this facility cost and is it cost effective?</strong>

Cost per unit added to the database, when plotted against total IT spending demonstrates a fall with every object recorded. Figure 2 below demonstrates the annual IT outlay by the Scheme between 2003 and 2006 and the cost per find recorded.
<table border="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Financial Year</td>
<td>Expenditure</td>
<td>Running total</td>
<td>Number of finds recorded</td>
<td>Running finds total</td>
<td>Running cost

per find recorded</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2003 – 2004</td>
<td>£106,278.25</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>29,344</td>
<td>n/a</td>
<td>£3.62</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2004 – 2005</td>
<td>£18,570.89</td>
<td>£124,849.14</td>
<td>39,851</td>
<td>69,195</td>
<td>£1.80</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2005 - 2006</td>
<td>£4,050.36</td>
<td>£128,899.50</td>
<td>57,417</td>
<td>126,612</td>
<td>£1.02</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2006 – 2007</td>
<td>£33,017.52</td>
<td>£161,917.02</td>
<td>65,705</td>
<td>192,317</td>
<td>£0.84</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
The falling cost for recording items on the Scheme’s database.

The usual cost efficiency argument that is discussed in many quarters, factors in the costs added for recording each object by using staff salary and associated costs divided by the number of finds recorded. I, for one, believe that this is a false measure of the Scheme’s workings. How does one attach a cost element to the extra work that the average FLO carries out? For example, the local society talks, finds days, school visits, gallery talks and local Museum or authority duties. There is never 100% of the FLO’s time spent on pure data entry; nor should there be. Therefore, I believe that the above figure demonstrates that the Scheme is performing a very cost effective recording process. Are there comparable figures for the rest of the Heritage sector? Not that I can find!

The database is my biggest headache in my working life, and I get various complaints regarding the workings of the interfaces. Below is a sample of the usual comments that I have to contend with:

I, and the Scheme itself, recognise that the user interface is not especially user friendly. However, over the coming weeks, steps have been made to rectify this and a new search facility should be unveiled shortly.  This is not an easy thing for us to implement. The annual budget for IT improvements is miniscule. With an extra £40,000 a year, we could have an interface as slick as any on the Internet. However, the new improvements should go some way towards making your experiences better.
Before I discuss the tips for using the database, I think it is best to detail what improvements have come online since the Scheme launched its online presence.

1.	High-resolution image viewer (this allows you to zoom and pan around the image and view details.)
2.	Expanded record details – more on this in the tips.
3.	Workflow indicators – as a non-recording user, you see 2 traffic lights (yellow for a unchecked record, green for a checked record.) A finds adviser has checked not every record you see with a green light. However these do have a warning message on them about their quality.
4.	Finds of note list – this makes our staff decide whether finds should be drawn to your attention.
5.	Larger thumbnail on records.
6.	Redesign of aesthetics (I would still like it to look nicer.)
7.	Simplification of periods used (removed late and early and now just use broad terms such as Roman.)
8.	Implemented a thesaurus to aid searching.
9.	Introduced RSS feeds to allow you to reuse or be alerted to our latest records in pre-defined searches.
10.	Introduced self-registration (this is extremely important, more later in this article.)
11.	Allowed HER officers to download records directly and use them for Development Control.
12.	Introduced Reece recording periods and enhanced numismatic recording facilities to lessen mistakes made on data entry.

<strong>What’s still to come?</strong>

In the next few weeks, we expect the following to be put online by Oxford Arch Digital (OAD):

1.	New search engine (for further details visit our blog and read this article - <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/274">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/274</a>
2.	New mapping client – based around either Google maps or the open layers client.
3.	Enhanced visibility of RSS feeds.

As and when we can access more funds, the system will be migrated to the newer and far more intuitive (it is believed) second-generation system that OAD have created.

<strong>But I still can’t use it!</strong>

I hear this from various users, including our staff (Michael Lewis especially!) and it is something that needs some explaining for many. To begin with, I believe the best thing for you to do is register with the database. This opens up some of the more useful features to you. To do this, visit:
<a href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/hms/registration.php">http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/hms/registration.php</a>
Fill in your details, and then by return email, you will be activated. This email expires after 24 hours, so if it doesn’t arrive, check your spam box. Once activated, you can now access the following:

1.	Save your searches (either for reuse on the system each time you visit, or as an RSS feed that you can use as an alert system – this needs some special feed reading software, or for reuse in your own website – see Corinne Mills’ excellent website <a href="http://www.ourpasthistory.com">http://www.ourpasthistory.com</a>)
2.	Change preferences, such as viewing thumbnails in search lists, changing the number of thumbnails that you can view, changing the number of records per page.
3.	Enable tracking of your experience. I can see what people want to search upon and therefore identify problems. You cannot be identified by name as it just logs searches by auto-registered groups.

<a title="The results set with expanded information" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/expanded.jpg"><img class="dec flow" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/expanded.thumbnail.jpg" alt="The results set with expanded information" /></a>

Once registered, you might need some help searching the database to get the best out of it.

There are 3 main areas for searching the database:

•	Quick search – via the box in the header or the single search box from the search menu.
•	Advanced search – most popular across all user groups and requires a modicum of effort to construct a search.
•	Image search – perhaps most useful for quick searching for visual recognition.

The fourth type of search – “visual” – is to become obsolete soon as so few people use it. The quick search box in the header  is limited on the fields that can be searched within the database. These fields are:

•	Object type – for example coin, brooch, axe
•	Period – for example Roman, Early Medieval
•	Ascribed culture – this is only used for Early Medieval objects

If you use the quick search menu option, check the radio button for which type of object you want to search for. For example if you check coins, then you could enter the ruler’s name and  get back all coins for Trajan.

<strong>How do I make an advanced search actually work?</strong>

Well this is a frequently asked question, and quite simple to answer. With the current interface you need to do the following as shown in the examples below.  Before you begin, determine what you would like to retrieve. One caveat that has to be remembered; we don’t pluralise objects types. We record everything in the singular; therefore coins are incorrect – coin is correct. Brooches are incorrect; brooch is correct.
Let’s do a search for Roman coins from Lincolnshire recorded by Adam Daubney our Midlands rock star.

Step 1: choose object type is exactly coin and then press the more button.

Choose AND as the operator term.

Step 2: choose county is exactly Lincolnshire and then press the more button.

Choose AND as the operator term.

Step 3: choose broadperiod is exactly ROMAN and then press the more button.

Choose AND as the operator term.

Step 4: choose created by is exactly adaubney.

Now press search.

<a title="The search screen set up" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/search.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/search.thumbnail.jpg" alt="The search screen set up" /></a>

This will allow you to find all records that meet these search terms. If you have registered and logged in, you could save this search and access this from the saved search menu every time you login to the site. Another hint to save you getting page expired message is this: right click on a link and open in a new window.

When the new advanced search facility launches, the above steps should be rendered obsolete, as the steps will be far more obvious.

<strong>How do I search the image bank?</strong>

This is very simple and requires very little input to gain lots of output. However, it is hampered by the labelling terms entered by our recorders. To find coins of Trajan, enter Trajan in the filter box and press filter as shown below. You can then scroll through pages of anything attributed to Trajan. More often than not, you’ll get mostly coins back for that particular search.

<strong>How do I use RSS feeds?</strong>

These are perhaps the most powerful feature of the database and also the most underused feature. RSS stands for Really Simple Syndication, and it is a way for one to share content easily. You need to download some software (see <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/news/rss.php">http://www.finds.org.uk/news/rss.php</a> for more information) and then create and save a search as an RSS feed. I currently use some software called “Feedreader”, simple and easy to install from <a href="http://www.feedreader.com">http://www.feedreader.com</a>.

<a title="Feedreader in action" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/feedreader.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/feedreader.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Feedreader in action" /></a>

Once you save the search as an RSS feed you can paste the address you are presented with into your feed reader. Every time a new find that meets your search criteria is added to the database, the software alerts you to its existence. Lazy man’s surfing! If you don’t fancy creating your own feeds, try some of the ones that I have already created. You can also get RSS feeds from a whole range of other sites, for example the BBC, Google’s news pages and many more.

The other advantage of RSS, is that these feeds can be reused in your own website. If you want to do this, email me at the British Museum for more details. It could invigorate your web site with finds for your parish, county or even your own finds!

<strong>How are these data used?</strong>

These data that we collect are used all over the globe by archaeologists and the layman. Example projects include:

1.	English Heritage funded Night-hawking study conducted by Oxford Archaeology
2.	VASLE based at the University of York (AHRC)
3.	The Tribal Hidage project at University College London (Leverhulme)
4.	AHRC funding for 3 PhDs in 2006-2007
5.	Over 50 individuals completing research for higher level degrees worldwide (Japan, Australia, USA and of course the United Kingdom)

As more people start to study these data, our understanding of the archaeology of England and Wales will be radically altered. The set of maps below demonstrate how quickly the Scheme has started to collect data all over the area that it covers.  In sequence, these maps demonstrate all finds from 2003, 2003 – 2004, 2003 – 2005 and 2003 – 2006.

<a title="Finds from 2003" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Finds from 2003" /></a> <a title="Finds from 2003 - 2004" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_4.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_4.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Finds from 2003 - 2004" /></a> <a title="Finds from 2003 - 2005" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_5.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_5.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Finds from 2003 - 2005" /></a> <a title="Finds from 2003 - 2006" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_6.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/2003_5.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Finds from 2003 - 2006" /></a>

However, these data are useless when studied in isolation. Therefore it is imperative that these PAS generated data are compared with other institutions data. The next two maps show PAS data compared with data from Oxford University’s Celtic Coin Index and then PAS Roman coin finds from Peter Guest’s recently published database of Roman coin finds in Wales against the PAS generated Roman coins data. This highlights discrepancies in recording areas and allows archaeologists to try and identify biases and trends. The analysis of these data and HER data will be fundamental in writing the early archaeological texts of the 21st Century.

<a title="CCI data set plotted over PAS data set" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/conference.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/conference.thumbnail.jpg" alt="CCI data set plotted over PAS data set" /></a> <a title="Guest and Wells’ dataset over PAS" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/guest.jpg"><img src="http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/guest.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Guest and Wells’ dataset over PAS" /></a>
<strong>Can I get more help?</strong>

Yes of course! Speak to your FLO or call the Central Unit on 0207 323 8611 or email us at <a href="mailto:info@finds.org.uk">info@finds.org.uk</a> Don’t forget to register! You’ll get more from the database!]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Dan, all very interesting, what then is the number of "all finds" that appears on http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/hms/unilister.php?show=finds&amp;reset=1&amp;expand=50, at the moment its 159 554, so what's the relationship between this and your running total of 192,317 for the [financial?] year 2006/7?  I quoted the figure from here in something I wrote a couple of weeks back, so did I get it wrong and why?

			<wp:comment_id>78</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Daniel Pett]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>danielpett@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.7pillarsofwisdom.co.uk</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>195.194.86.1</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-05-23 17:28:22</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-05-23 16:28:22</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Paul
The records running total is now 181,000. The workflow mechanism means that the public user only sees the records we have allowed on view. There are a variety of reasons why some records are hidden from all and sundry. For example privacy of landowner or finder, sensitive spots, record unfinished, FLO not ready for all to read it.....
Not every record is 1:1, some have 10 objects or more held within the record. For exampe a 100 fragments from a flint scatter. Therefore, the current running total for all finds ever recorded is 271,000. The figures are always fluid as the records are made daily and so totals are surpassed as I write. This year 1st Jan onwards, has seen 38,000 objects recorded. Stats, bendy aren't they....

Dan]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Paul Barford]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>pbarford@pro.onet.pl</wp:comment_author_email>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Dan, sorry to come back to this but I am now even more confused about these “bendy stats”. All the PAS generated material (including the PAS Annual reports) suggests that there is a two tier database. The upper - generally visible -  tier consists of the information available to the public and as we all know does not contain finder or landowner data nor detailed findspot information precisely (we are told) to protect “privacy of landowner or finder, and sensitive spots”. The second tier, available to a select few such as PAS-permitted researchers, HER staff etc does contain this information.

Now you are saying there is a THIRD tier of whole entries containing “sensitive” information like this  not available to either? And its got as many as 21 000 objects in it? That’s one-eighth of the database contents!

I really don’t understand this. For the last couple of Annual Reports, PAS has been packaged and presented primarily as a public resource, making its data available to the general public for education and information. This is how the later Ann. Reports all begin. All good and commendable, and yet in the tables at the back (and executive summaries) there is no presentation of the amount of information that IS available for use in this manner compared to that which is collected but not available in this form.  Surely if one eighth of the material that is being gathered is as you suggest simply inaccessible for use in the same manner as the other seven eighths, this should get some attention in its own right in the Annual Reports, and in the description of "what the database is" on this website?    “The combinations are endless, totally flexible and extremely powerful” but not powerful enough to tell us at a glance how many objects are in the database as a whole?

I hope you are not seriously telling me that PAS is including “unfinished records” in those annual statistics are you? So when is a record a record for annual report purposes?

&gt; This year 1st Jan onwards, has seen 38,000 objects recorded.)
Paul]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-05-25 08:10:17</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Paul
I think you're slightly confused over your tier system for the database. The records that the public user sees is the same set of records as the registered user sees, minus the sensitive data.
There is a workflow model that exists, it stops incomplete records being produced and sent into SMRs as we transfer the information to them. The unfinished nature of the record could be that it is missing an image or the finder is qualifying grid references.
The artefact has been recorded, so why not include it in the stats. We do include it and we will keep on doing it. They aren't spurious, they are real records with real information. If you really want to be nit picky, look through museum cataloging systems.

Go find me a single SMR that can produce information on demand with as much artefact information as we have. Thought not.

If you had taken up my offer of an account extended over 2 years ago, then maybe you would have more comprehension. If you want the full story, surely you should look at the wider picture and not be blinkered.

I get the feeling that all you want to do is pick holes. Got anything positive to say about anything in archaeology? What have you done to aid our knowledge today? Give me some positive suggestions about how the Scheme could improve.
You've caught me in a bad mood.

D]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Nigel
Aimed at Paul. Although your counter figures are rather speculative. Stating that the Scheme is making little headway is blatantly untrue. Look at the number of finds recorded, it is constantly increasing. Look at the number of research projects that this Scheme facilitates, it is increasing. Look at the number of eminent archaeologists using our data, its increasing.
You tell me another organisation that is as open about publishing its figures with regards to archaeology. I can't think of any.

A constant pressure tirade by you and Paul is not helping what we do or our relationship with metal detectorists or archaeologists.

I have not heard from you both a decent suggestion of how we can improve. Have you got any? Any at all? Even something positive to say about our work. I know there are weaknesses in what we do, but forcing detecting underground like Ireland is totally naive. The whole jist of Schadla-Hall's talk at the conference highlighted what happens when detecting is banned.

Dan
PS
I will not join HA or MA sites to discuss this. I have better things to do, such as my work which facilitates research, recording and promotion of good practice.

PPS
Paul &amp; Nigel, if you're going to quote me elsewhere, please refer to this:
The content contained within the Blog's pages do not represent an official position from any of the organisations associated with the Portable Antiquities Scheme. They are solely those of the post's author. Which is found at the foot of every page on the blog.

And this before doing so:

You may not reproduce part or all of the contents of the Web Site in any form unless it is for personal, non commercial use or unless We give our written permission. Which is found in our disclaimer.
At least cite your sources. This is shut as we're upgrading our databases.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>Data sans frontiere conference presentation</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/25/data-sans-frontiere-conference-presentation/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 24 May 2007 23:01:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/298</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today I'm presenting a paper at a CBA organised conference on databases, portals and web 2.0 technology at the British Museum. The paper I am giving will present more about work that we're implementing at the moment on the Scheme's database and also on the revamped CCI.

The CCI is still in beta test and needs some more work done to it before it can go mainstream. If you want a look send me an email. Other than that, the Scheme is due to release revamped geo spatial tools on its database shortly. There are only a few more things to implement and then usability should be much improved.

Any questions? I'll post the presentation tomorrow after the talk.

D

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/tmw.pdf' title='Tell me what'>Tell me what</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>New English Heritage chairman</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/25/new-english-heritage-chairman/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 25 May 2007 06:57:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/300</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Lord Bruce-Lockhart has been appointed Chair of English Heritage, the Government’s statutory advisor on the historic environment, Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell announced today.

<a href="http://www.culture.gov.uk/Reference_library/Press_notices/archive_2007/dcms058_07.htm">New chairman announcement</a>

The press release lists the following as his biographical background:



<blockquote>Lord Bruce-Lockhart is currently Chair of the Local Government Association.  Having qualified at the Royal Agricultural College, he has farmed in Kent since 1968 with his wife and three children.  He has held a variety of leader and chair roles in local government, the public and voluntary sectors since 1986 - most notably he was chair of the Weald of Kent Preservation Society Committee, co-chair of the Thames Gateway Forum and chair of the Environment Committee and led Kent County Council from 1997 – 2005.  His current positions also include Trustee of Leeds Castle Foundation, chair of Rochester Cathedral Council, president of Kent Thameside Development Board and trustee for East Malling Trust for Horticultural Research.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Culture, participation and the web</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/25/culture-participation-and-the-web/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 25 May 2007 07:06:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/301</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The think tank "Demos" published their study entitled '<a href="http://www.demos.co.uk/publications/loggingon">Culture, participation and the web</a>' which their website refers to as:

<blockquote>an interesting case study, bringing together lessons learnt about how to organise online engagement, and a point of departure for asking questions about future directions.</blockquote>

I've downloaded the copy and it is interesting to note that the document is published under creative commons. One of the things that stood out for me on page 58 was:

<blockquote>Now,‘culture on the web’ encompasses many forms: information sources, portals, digitised collections, interactivity, social software, RSS feeds, personal curation, filesharing, community-generated interpretation and even cyborgs.</blockquote>

I haven't managed to read the entire document so far, but there does seem an emphasis on the earning potential that the web can generate. It is also interesting to note on page 64, the large budgets that a lot of the case study websites had for building their resources. Makes our budget look like my pocket money.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Google developer day</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/31/google-developer-day/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 May 2007 22:08:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/305</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://code.google.com/events/developerday/images/logo-square.gif" alt="Developer day logo">I've just got back from Google's developer day at the Brewery in Chiswell Street, London. The sessions I was most interested in were the mapping applications. Ed Parsons, formerly of the Ordnance Survey gave an overview of what they are up to and highlighted the usefulness of KML and geoRSS files for indexing site content.
I've built these into the very heart of the new <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/CCI/">CCI</a> website that is currently in test phase. Some of the stuff I have used only got released in the last few weeks and I'm looking forward to trying to build mapplet ideas based around geographical data from our databases. The new features that they have added to their mapping interface can be seen at either <a href="http://maps.google.co.uk/preview">http://maps.google.co.uk/preview</a> or <a href="http://maps.google.com/preview">http://maps.google.com/preview</a> (this one is better as it allows you to view street level imagery and traffic data on the maps interface.

<a href="http://www.andreweland.org/">Andrew Eland</a>'s presentation focussed on the construction of mapplets and the extension of the Google Maps api. I'll try and take advantage of as much as we can for the Scheme's website. More exciting is the world of KML as highlighted by Paul Burch. There's all sorts of possibilities there for the Museum. Imagine visualising on a map where all 7 million objects in the Museum came from, doing advanced Sketch up models of monuments that we have parts of in the collection. We could really engage with the web community!

Other things that were talked about were of less interest for me, but probably of great interest to other developers (I still maintain that I only dabble in computers!) such as Google Gears for offline working. The details of this can be found at <a href="http://code.google.com">http://code.google.com</a>. For pictures of the events and streaming video from the day, you can visit the dedicated website at <a href="http://code.google.com/events/developerday/index.html">http://code.google.com/events/developerday/index.html</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>The Museum - BBC2</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/31/the-museum-bbc2/</link>
