		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/images/museum_inthemedia.jpg" alt="The museum logo">For anyone watching the BBC Wales series entitled the Museum, you might be interested by the following talks:

<ol>
	<li>Thursday 31 May 	13.00  	Gods and symbols in the Assyrian reliefs </li>

	<li>Thursday 14 June 	13.00 	The mystery of Michelangelo's last drawing </li>

	<li>Wednesday 20 June 	13.00 	Shopping for money: acquiring modern coins and banknotes </li>

	<li>Tuesday 26 June 	13.00 	The British Museum in Pentonville Prison </li>

	<li>Wednesday 18 July 	13.00 	Wedges into words: messages from antiquity</li>

	<li>Thursday 19 July 	13.00 	Life, land and water in the Andes: deciphering Nasca iconography</li>

	<li>Monday 23 July 	13.00 	19th- century plaster casts from ancient Iran </li>

	<li>Thrusday 2nd August  	13.00 	Living devotion: contemporary Hindu festival and ritual</li></ol>




The <a href="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/whats_on/in_the_media.aspx">Museum website</a> features a list of the programmes in sequence and the series seems to be received quite well by the media and audience. Even the Museum facebook group seems quite happy!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Heritage Gateway and other projects</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/31/heritage-gateway-and-other-projects/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 May 2007 22:47:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/308</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of the projects demonstrated at the Data Sans Frontieres conference last week was the English Heritage and ALGAO backed project known as Heritage Gateway. This is intended to be:

<blockquote>A prototype website was first made available in April 2006 after a year of planning and development.  This provided access to a boundary map of England's Historic Environment Records, with contact information and news articles as well as local education and outreach project information.

A mechanism to cross-search live local and national datasets has been developed for the website from May 2007. More datasets are being linked to this search as the project progresses.</blockquote>

The website is slowly adding more HERs to it's cross search mechanism, and is mostly East Anglian at present.
I think that the Scheme should also be signed up to it, and I'll be working on this shortly if I can get the details from Cat at EH. There has to be a one stop shop for searching the Historic Environment, it seems stupid that we are the only archaeological organisation with a data snapshot of England &amp; Wales!

<img src="http://www.britarch.ac.uk/HEIRNET/images/dsf-small-logo.png" alt="DSF logo" />Other things that were quite cool at the Conference included LP Archaeology's work on the Fasti project of Mediterranean archaeological projects, the fantastic SWISH project in Scotland and the various theoretical talks that were talked through during the day. Definitely one of the more interesting conferences I have been to for a while and it was nice to meet people such as Tom Goskar, Mia Rudge and of course all the HER people.

If Crispin reads this from Exegesis, let's talk about transferring data.....]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Scheme research projects</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/05/31/scheme-research-projects/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 May 2007 22:56:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/309</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The British Museum website now features more information on the Scheme and its activities and the information held within the <a href="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/the_museum/departments/portable_antiquities_treasure/research/projects.aspx">research register</a> is probably of interest to some of our readers. We currently have 4 major projects on the go for Central Unit staff and over 60 for external students and Universities. Sam Moorhead is interviewing candidates for a PhD on Roman coins this week coming, which could dramatically change our understanding of ruralised England.


If you would like to do more research on PAS data, please don't hesitate to get in touch with the finds adviser for the period you are interested in. We have some suggested research projects and we would love someone to start doing stuff with these. If only the Scheme existed when I was a student!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>309</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2007-05-31 23:56:29</wp:post_date>

	<item>
		<title>Celtic Coin Index - work in progress</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/06/01/celtic-coin-index-work-in-progress/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Jun 2007 16:42:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/302</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/CCI/' title='The Celtic Coin Index'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/the-celtic-coin-index.thumbnail.png' alt='The Celtic Coin Index'></a>Since March 2007, I have been engaged with the construction of a new <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/CCI/">Celtic Coin Index</a> (CCI). This is a project that has been running at Oxford University since 1960 and records all known examples of Iron Age coins found. It was previously put online by <a href="http://www.writer2001.com/cciwriter2001/">Hooker and Perron</a> and has been available since 2001. This has not been updated since, but has quite rightly been cited as a wonderful resource for numismatists and the layman.

<img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/05/iron-age-coins-mapped.thumbnail.png' alt='Iron Age coins mapped' class='dec flow' />The Scheme was approached to build on the work of the CCI in early 2005, however, my programming skills were not really up to the task and we did not have any money (neither did they!) to engage a development team. Since then, I have taught myself more about PHP programming and interactive design and have now built a new version of the CCI. This is still in beta phase for a few more months, I want to get feedback, clean up the code and enhance certain aspects of the site. It is the most complex thing I have built, and there will be some bugs inevitably. There's a few CSS discrepancies, but they will be ironed out shortly. I need a better testing environment at work!

So what is different to the old CCI?

<ol>
	<li>Built on LAMP platform (linux, apache, MySQL and php</li>
        <li>Revised database schema, with new data incorporated</li>
	<li>Uses AJAX  to enhance user experience</li>
	<li>Uses google sitemaps to tell Google what to index</li>
	<li>Uses an integrated Google map to visualise the distributed findspots of these coins</li>
        <li>Dynamic image generation from searches - typology can be done on the fly</li>
	<li>Variety of layers added to map to demonstrate distribution of other artefacts</li>
	<li>Allows users to use social web techniques such as bookmarking and voting</li>
	<li>Permission based browsing for researchers</li>
	<li>Multiple download formats for data XML (<a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/DCN/">DCN</a> &amp; <a href="http%3A%2F%2Fheritage-standards.org%2Fmidas%2Fdocs">MIDAS</a>), RSS, <a href="http://georss.org/">geoRSS</a> (simple - thinking about GML), CSV, JSON, txt and KML</li>
        <li>Graphs can be drawn for data comparisons</li>
	<li>Images can be downloaded for academic use</li>
	<li>PAS data is incorporated</li>
	<li>Grid references have been cleaned and coins relocated on dry land</li>
	<li>Data entry system for adding new coins</li>
	<li>Tagging introduced for user classification of coins</li>
	<li>Integrated with a wordpress blog for discussion articles on Iron Age coins to be posted.</li>
        <li>Incorporates <a href="http://microformats.org/">microformats</a></li>
        <li>An OAI interface has been implemented so that external organisations can consume these data for other services</li>
        <li>A documented RESTful API has been built - details available on demand - so that these data could be mashed up on other sites. Please do!!!! Fully ready by the end of June.</li>
</ol>

There are a few other things being considered for inclusion within the database's framework, but perhaps most prominently, the ability to record your own coin on the database if it is not recorded elsewhere.

So what has been the cost for creating this resource; my time (approx 1 hour a day) and £3000 for an intern to clean the data for spatial analysis and to teach her GIS. The fruits of this work will be written up in a separate paper.

I hope that the new resource proves useful to academics, numismatists and anyone interested in coins.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>302</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2007-06-01 17:42:45</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2007-06-01 16:42:45</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

I urge you to try out the new Celtic Coin Index website. Dan Pett has built the website for this fabulous resource from scratch, and it's packed with modern features such as Google Maps, RSS, GeoRSS, tag clouds, and even an API (coming soon).
Th...]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type>trackback</wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>87</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Geoff]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>cottamg@tiscali.co.uk</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>88.105.55.16</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-07-07 11:08:02</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-07-07 10:08:02</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Dan
Sorry to be less positive than some, but your database structure suggests that people actively engaged in research on Iron Age coins have not been asked what their requirements are. It may be that the database would admirably suit a coin series which has been researched and accurately catalogued, but it is fair to say that none of the British Iron Age series have been sufficiently researchede, catalogued AND PUBLISHED to enable coins to be entered into the database in such a way that a researcher can access a group of coins without downloading every possible coin that MIGHT be relevant.
The reason that the current CCI web site is so food is it is possible to scan thumbnails of groups of coins to pick out ones with relevant features.
As it stands, the database is effectively useless to anyone involved in research into these coins.
Why, when the current format has received such praise, has a different format been used. Clearly you think you can do better, but from my experience in industry sorting out factories database problems, the world is littered with the results of such thougnts. Generally they arise from a lack of real understanding of the requirements of key users, and I would be interested to hear which active researchers in this area (of more than a couple of years experience) have been consulted to generate the user requirements document before work started in designing the database.
Geoff]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>88</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Daniel Pett]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>danielpett@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.7pillarsofwisdom.co.uk</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>81.1.89.49</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-07-08 17:57:17</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-07-08 16:57:17</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Geoff,
Sorry, I have never come across you before, so I can't say who you know of standing in Iron Age coin research. The people who have been involved:
Philip de Jersey, Ian Leins, Sam Moorhead, Roger Bland, Barry Cunliffe a range of finds liaison officers, staff at the British Museum's department of coins and medals and a whole swathe of other people have all said what they wanted.

The database structure has been slightly modified from the original postGRES database that Philip de Jersey has been working on for the last few years.

As I document in the blog of the CCI, the dataset is forming the research basis for Ian Leins' PhD that is hoping to do more for the publication of these coins.

I think you may have missed the point of what the new database is meant to do. It is there for others to reuse the data within their own research and analyse against various datasets. I'm an archaeologist and not a numismatist and I see coins as only one part of the archaeological record.

Why don't you tell me what you would have liked to have seen? Have you browsed the thumbnails or tried out any of the other features? There's new features being added slowly - such as tagging that will document prominent features such as iconography, positions etc
The new database is shortly to include all coins reported from 2001 onwards to Philip and the Portable Antiquities Scheme - perhaps another 5000 coins? This will further increase sampling sizes from where better research can be generated. I've just attempted to do something in a different manner, with different techniques and some cutting edge web technology. I don't mind the comments but I would like to know more about why you find it unusable.

Regards

Dan]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>Rome Reborn 1.0</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/06/17/rome-reborn-10/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 17 Jun 2007 21:12:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/311</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I found this on the technorati rss feed today, and I think it might be of interest to our Romanist following. It is exactly the sort of thing that we should do at the BM with regards to excavated sites etc. I haven't gone in depth into this to find out how it was created, but I wonder if the models could be geo referenced and if they are in sketch up (which indeed they look to be), dumped into Google Earth. Would be a fantastic resource if so! Apologies if this has been done already!

<a href="http://www.romereborn.virginia.edu/">Rome Reborn 1.0</a>

And if you're really into Rome, the series starts again on BBC 2 this Wednesday, can't wait....]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Cleatham cemetery write up online</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/06/18/cleatham-cemetery-write-up-online/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 18 Jun 2007 12:07:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/312</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of our Finds Advisers, Kevin Leahy, has just had one of his major pieces of research and excavation work released for access by all on the <a href="http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/archive/cleatham_cba_2007/index.cfm?CFID=71235&amp;CFTOKEN=77580081">Archaeological Data Service website</a>.



<blockquote>Kevin Leahy's report on the excavation, Interrupting the Pots; Excavation of Cleatham Anglo-Saxon Cemetery was published in 2007 as Council for British Archaeology Research Report, 155. This digital resource is intended to make the data upon which the report was based available. It includes the full catalogues as a relational database together with images and the meta-data defining the terms used. While it can be used by itself it is best understood as being complementary to the hard copy synthesis. </blockquote>

I'm not sure, but I think this is the work that Kevin won a major prize for earlier this year....Kevin?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Peter Ucko obituary</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/06/21/peter-ucko-obituary/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 21 Jun 2007 10:52:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/313</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Some of the people who read this site might have studied at the Institute of Archaeology, UCL or at various other institutions where Peter Ucko taught. He unfortunately passed away last week and several obituaries are now being published.

<blockquote>Peter John Ucko, archaeologist: born London 27 July 1938; Lecturer in Anthropology, University College London 1962-72, Director, Institute of Archaeology and Professor of Comparative Archaeology 1996-2006 (Emeritus); Principal, Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies 1972-81; Professor of Archaeology, Southampton University 1981-96; died London 14 June 2007. ......

In 1996, he was appointed director of the Institute of Archaeology at UCL, Britain's leading centre of teaching and research. There were grumbles from crusty colleagues. But the maverick Ucko was now, beyond challenge, the most creative figure in British archaeology. In 1997, he launched the first courses in Public Archaeology, typically redefining it as a critical audit of the profession's ethics in areas as diverse as the handling of the indigenous dead and archaeology in the media.

</blockquote>

The Independent obituary, written by Neal Ascherson, can be <a href="http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article2686806.ece">read online now</a>.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Archaeology and Poker - an unlikely combo</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/06/21/archaeology-and-poker-an-unlikely-combo/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 21 Jun 2007 11:31:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/314</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The latest edition of Archaeology magazine from America has just run a story relating to the US military trying to raise the awareness of it's troops towards archaeology in the territories that they are currently occupying.

To read more about this intiative, there's two webpages that expand on this idea:

<a href="http://www.archaeology.org/0707/trenches/solitaire.html">Archaeology magazine</a>
<a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/18/AR2007061801277.html">Washington Post</a>


<img src="http://www.archaeology.org/0707/trenches/thumbnails/solitaire.gif" alt="Solitaire cards - US military copyright" class="dec flow" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Site upgrades</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/06/29/site-upgrades/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 Jun 2007 15:45:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/315</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the last week, I've been adding some new features to the Scheme's main website - http://www.finds.org.uk - and I hope that these prove to be useful additions. These include:

<ol>
	<li><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/involved/contacts.php">New Google map</a> for showing regional recording areas and locations of FLOs</li>	<li><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/people/profile.php?personID=61">Upgraded profiles</a>, now showing recording districts, local coroners locations and FLO location, quarterly recording stats and overall periodic statistical breakdowns</li>
<li><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/treasure/coroners.php">List of coroners offices</a> - useful for Treasure queries</li>
<li>Created KML files for <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/includes/coronKML.php">Coroners</a> and <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/includes/floKML.php">FLO</a>s - please feel free to reuse these!</li></ol>

<dl><dt><a href="http://maps.google.com/?z=7&amp;ll=52.2,0.2&amp;om=5">Center of map</a></dt><dt><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/includes/floKML.php" title="kml">FLO</a></dt><dd>Finds Liaison Officers</dd></dl>

I have plans for expanding the FLO pages, with more statistics and presentations that they give to their local finders, MLA groups and other interested parties. Soon I'll be adding RSS feeds of their latest finds and adding geoRSS overlays to the maps to give some spatial context. I'm also toying with introducing Wordpress MU for all our staff to write their own blogs if they want to. These posts can then be integrated into our system.

I'm also wondering if the menu system needs overhauling as we're adding more and  more content..... Any comments out there?]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Congress lecture</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/02/congress/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Jul 2007 09:55:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/317</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/blandsm.jpg' title='Roger Bland and Peter Tompka'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/blandsm.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Roger Bland and Peter Tompka'></a>In the last week, the Scheme's head (Roger Bland) <a href="http://accg.us/issues/news/bland">lectured in Washington</a> and addressed Congressional members and members of the Cultural Property Advisory Committee, U.S. State Department of Iraqi cultural affairs, the National Park Service, the American Numismatic Society, the Cypriot and Turkish embassies, the Archaeological Institute of America President, members of the press and other interested parties.

If you want to read Roger's presentation then download it in <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/congress.zip">zip format</a> (it's 6MB).]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Portable Antiquities Scheme: New procedure for reporting finds in North Wales</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/03/wales/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Jul 2007 10:26:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/318</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the last couple of years the PAS has gone from strength to strength recording metal detecting finds. There have, however, been a number of holes in our coverage and North Wales is an example of this. The way that the PAS operates in Wales is different to England and the PAS representatives working with the Welsh Trusts have sometimes struggled to offer the same level of service.

Due to there now being three large metal detecting clubs operating in North Wales, the FLOs in adjacent counties will help with recording. Therefore, from this summer: Jeff Spencer (Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust) will liaise directly with the Wrexham Heritage Society, Peter Reavill (FLO for Herefordshire &amp; Shropshire) with Wrexham Metal Detecting Club and Frances McIntosh (FLO for Cheshire &amp; the North West) with Mold Historical Search Society. We hope to attend each club at least once a quarter and be in regular contact with the officers of the club. What does this mean for club members? Hopefully it will provide a better and more convenient way to record your finds and also provide more help in reporting Treasure finds.

In addition to the service already offered by Jeff Spencer, Mark Lodwick (PAS Co-ordinator Wales) will hold regular finds days at museums in North Wales every 6 months. This will enable independent detectorists to record their finds more easily with the PAS. If detectorists want to continue reporting their finds to their usual FLO, there is no problem with this. Each FLO will be able to record archaeological finds regardless of whether they are found in Wales or England.

We hope with your support to be able to deliver a much better and ‘joined up’ recording service for North Wales.

Mark Lodwick
PAS Co-Ordinator Wales
Tel: 02920 573226
Email: mark.lodwick@nmgw.ac.uk

Jeff Spencer
HER Officer, CPAT
Tel: 01938 553 670
Email: <a href="mailto:jeff@cpat.org.uk">jeff@cpat.org.uk</a>

Frances McIntosh
FLO Cheshire Greater Manchester and Merseyside
Tel: 0151 478 4259
Email: <a href="mailto:frances.mcintosh@liverpoolmuseums.org.uk">frances.mcintosh@liverpoolmuseums.org.uk</a>

Peter Reavill
FLO Herefordshire and Shropshire
Tel: 01584 813 641
Email: <a href="mailto:peter.reavill@shropshire-cc.gov.uk">peter.reavill@shropshire-cc.gov.uk</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Shield boss</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/03/boss/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Jul 2007 16:51:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/319</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The <a href="http://www.24hourmuseum.org.uk">24 Hour Museum</a> recently picked up on a shield boss that <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/people/profile.php?personID=71">David Williams</a>, our Finds Liaison Officer for Surrey, had recorded. This object was reported in the local paper and the website featured it on their front page. The object's full report can be found by looking on our database for <a href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/hms/pas_obj.php?type=finds&amp;id=001468A099201671">SUR-A033A8</a>.

<img src="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/view/onfly-large.php/imageID__143290/image.jpg" alt="Shield boss">

David has associated this object with:
<blockquote>Henry Duke of Buckingham was heavily involved in the Wars of the Roses and was a key supporter of Richard III who came to the throne on 26th June 1483. Buckingham soon attempted a rebellion in the Midlands and Wales. Richard moved against him on 11 October and Buckingham's support deserted him (down to even his servants). He was executed in Salisbury on November 2nd 1483. Henry is also one of the prime suspects in the murder of the two Princes in the Tower of London. He appears prominently in Shakespeare's Richard III.
</blockquote>

For further information on this discovery, you can read more at the 24 Hour Museum.....]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The long shadow of slavery</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/12/slavery/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Jul 2007 23:01:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/322</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/24hrmuseum11707.jpg' title='24hrmuseum11707.jpg'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/24hrmuseum11707.thumbnail.jpg' alt='24hrmuseum11707.jpg'></a>In the year of the bicentenary of the parliamentary abolition of slavery a rare Roman figurine has come to light near Andover, Hampshire.  This small figure cast in bronze crouches with his elbows and knees drawn together, and with a rope starting around the neck also binding his wrists and ankles.

A recent study (Jackson 2005) has catalogued only sixteen other ‘bound captive’ figurines from the Roman Empire, ten of which are from Britain.  As the study argues, the posture of the figure and the manner of his shackling strongly suggests that it represents an enslaved man.  Elsewhere, there is mounting evidence for the Romano-British slave trade which involved both natives and others from within the empire.

The artefact has a number of distinctive features, including the man’s ‘Celtic’ stylised hair and the vertical and horizontal perforations which travel through his body.  These holes were clearly for mounting, but the context in which these figurines were displayed is less certain.  Might this artefact have been looked upon by someone connected with the slave trade living in Hampshire in the 2nd or 3rd century AD?

This is the third bound captive figurine reported to by the Portable Antiquities Scheme to date; all three can be viewed via <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk">www.finds.org.uk</a>.  In 2007, with our thoughts, correctly, focused on transatlantic slavery we should also spend a moment contemplating British associations with slavery both more recent and ancient.


Rob Webley, PAS Finds Liaison Officer (Hampshire)

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/hamp-378231boundcaptivefigurine.jpg' title='Bound captive'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/hamp-378231boundcaptivefigurine.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Bound captive'></a>
Image copyright – Winchester Museums Service/Portable Antiquities Scheme

An extract from the record <a href="http://www.findsdatabase.org.uk/hms/pas_obj.php?type=finds&amp;id=00146837B6701D19">HAMP-378231</a> follows below:


<blockquote>A small Roman copper-alloy anthropomorphic figurine representing a bound captive. The naked captive is crouching with his legs drawn up and together and his elbows on his knees. His arms are flexed with the hands clasped together. The posture is dictated by the shackles the captive bears: a rope connects his neck, hands and feet, with a loop around these three areas. The fibres of the rope are delineated by diagonal mouldings. The legs are at an angle of 65 to 75 degrees. The area between the legs, arms and stomach is soldily cast, with the limbs moulded....</blockquote>

For further reading on this topic - Jackson, R (2005) ‘Roman bound captives: symbols of slavery’, in Crummy, N (ed.) Image, Craft and the Classical World, 143-156 (Montagnac: Éditions monique mergoil)]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>slavery</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>National Archaeology Week at the BM</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/11/national-archaeology-week-at-the-bm/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Jul 2007 15:29:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/327</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As part of National Archaeology Week, the BM is hosting a lecture by Julian Richards. Staff from the Scheme will be present to talk to attendees about their work. This will include a demo of the database and the new CCI and various other bits and pieces. Details about the event are below:

<img src="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/images/stonehenge_150a.jpg" alt="Julian Richards">Stonehenge: the story so far - A lecture by Julian Richards

Thursday 19 July 2007, 18.30 - Stevenson Lecture Theatre

£5, concessions £3

Archaeologist and broadcaster Julian Richards' new book gathers together the accumulated understanding of Stonehenge, developed over centuries of investigation, experimentation and speculation. He asks (and attempts to answer) questions about what Stonehenge is, and when, why and by whom it was built.

There will be displays of work carried out by the Portable Antiquities Scheme from 17.30 in the Clore Education Centre.

There is no booking fee for events.

In person at the Box Office
By telephone on +44 (0)20 7323 8181
By email: <a href="mailto:boxoffice@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk">boxoffice@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk</a>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>_utw_tags_0</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[s:377:"a:7:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:11:"archaeology";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:14:"british-museum";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:3:"CBA";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:25:"national-archaeology-week";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:3:"NAW";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:20:"portable-antiquities";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:10:"stonehenge";}}";]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Ancient British cult of Totatis discovered in Lincolnshire</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/12/ancient-british-cult-of-totatis-discovered-in-lincolnshire/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 Jul 2007 13:53:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adam daubney</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/329</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/tot.thumbnail.jpg' alt='Greg Dyke’s Tot ring'>Staff from the Portable Antiquities Scheme, the Briitish Museum and dozens of metal detectorists have been working together to uncover the mystery of a long-lost cult to the Celtic god Totatis in Lincolnshire, dating to the late Iron Age and Roman period. For many years metal detectorists have been finding gold, silver and bronze Roman finger rings that all bear an enigmatic inscription containing three letters, reading ‘ToT’, and the majority of these come from Lincolnshire. Roman finger rings are sometimes inscribed with the name of a god who the wearer was devoted to, such as Mars, Minerva and Jupiter. The identity of the deity only known as ‘ToT’ remained a mystery to scholars however, because there was no Roman or Celtic deity whose name began with the letters Tot, although scholars presumed that it was an mis-spelt abbreviation of the god Toutates, who was one of the principal deities of the Celtic world. Toutatus is known from a number of stone inscriptions in Britain and on the continent, and his name is often spelt in a variety of ways, including Teutates, Toutiorix and Teutanus. The rings are very Roman in style but contain a native inscription, which shows that the Romans were tolerant of native religion and allowed tribes to continue to worship them.

<img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/tot_map.jpg' alt='Map of Totatis rings' />

Adam Daubney, Lincolnshire Finds Liaison Officer for the Portable Antiquities Scheme has been keeping a close eye on the rings for a number of years, hoping that one day someone would find a ring with a complete inscription.  Years of research and liaison with metal detectorists brought the number of rings known to fourty-four, including two elaborate gold examples, and very recently, one ring was eventually found by metal detectorist Greg Dyer which bore the inscription DEO TOTAT, confirming the deity as Totatis. The inscription translates as ‘To the god Totat(is), and on one shoulder is the word ‘FELIX’, meaning ‘happy’.  The other shoulder of the ring is missing, however there is a common Roman phrase ‘Vtere felix’, which basically means ‘use (this and be) happy’, and so the ring reads ‘To the God Totatis, use this and be happy’. Although it is unclear whether the ring is the object dedicated to the god, or whether it relates to the wearer of the ring, what is clear is that in the 2nd and 3rd century AD in Lincolnshire there was a strong tribal cult worshipping the deity, perhaps even attracting more followers than the traditional Roman gods such as Mars and Minerva.

There are very few ancient documents that mention Toutatis, however those that do paint a picture of a fearful warrior god who demanded human sacrifices. According to a document written in the 9th century, Worshippers of Toutatis used to plunge his victims headfirst into a vat of liquid until drowned.

What is furthermore fascinating about the rings is that their distribution highlights the tribal territory of the Iron Age tribe that existed at the time of the Roman conquest. The tribe known from inscriptions were called the ‘Corieltauvi’, and they covered the region east of the River Trent through Lincolnshire, Nottinghamshire and Leicestershire.

<dl>
<dt><a href="http://maps.google.com/?z=8&amp;ll=53.2,-0.7&amp;om=5">Center of map</a></dt><dt><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/CCI/functions/georss.php?&amp;tribe=Corieltavi" title="kml">Coins</a></dt><dd>Coins of the Corieltauvi</dd>
<dt><a href="http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?ie=UTF8&amp;hl=en&amp;msa=0&amp;msid=116306886908374624744.000001131f2ea67503eff&amp;om=1&amp;output=nl" title="kml">Rings</a></dt><dd>Rings of Totatis</dd>
<dt><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/kml/EastMidlands.kml" title="kml">East Midlands outline</a></dt><dd>East Midlands outline map</dd>
</dl>
<strong>The map above shows some of the coins recorded on the <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/CCI/">CCI</a> for the tribe of the Corieltauvi, plotted vs rings of Totatis. The yellow line signifies the outline of the East Midlands.</strong>

This evidence shows us that the native British population in the region were still acting and moving as a unified tribe well in to the Roman period. The old thought that the Romans invaded, conquered and ruled is now further under question based on this new evidence.

It seems that the cult died out with the Saxon invasions of the 5th century and was later replaced by Christianity, whose god recommended people love each other rather than plunge them headfirst into vats of liquid.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_id>93</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Ancient British cult of Totatis &laquo; Antiquarian's Attic]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email></wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://saesferd.wordpress.com/2007/07/17/ancient-british-cult-of-totatis/</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>72.232.131.4</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-07-17 17:17:52</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-07-17 16:17:52</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[[...] British cult ofTotatis  in Lincolnshire:  For many years metal detectorists have been finding gold, silver and bronze Roman finger rings [...] ]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type>pingback</wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>94</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Nick Ford]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>marcodubnos@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>81.174.171.230</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-07-19 19:16:20</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-07-19 18:16:20</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Does no-one seem to have entertained the possibility that the inscription reads, fully in Latin: DEO TOTA (M), meaning 'To the god, the whole'?

There is no god whose proper name is 'Toutatis': this is a Gallo-Brythonic epithet meaning 'of the people/the tribe' ('touta' (cf. Old Irish 'Tuatha'), hence, perversely, modern derivatives for
such assumed non-Celtic peoples as 'Teuton', 'Deutsch', etc.). 'Toutorix', mentioned in the blog, is not a variant spelling but a different epithet, meaning 'King of the People'.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>95</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Adam]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>adam.daubney@lincolnshire.gov.uk</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.finds.org.uk</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>62.172.185.126</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-07-20 12:43:25</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-07-20 11:43:25</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I did think about that, but 'To the god the whole' doesn't really make sense, and furthermore contemporary rings bearing abbreviations show that they are dedicatory ~ i.e. to specific gods.

There is a god whose proper name is Toutatis, shown by plenty of inscriptions. For example:

1. The silver votive plaque from Barkway, Herts is inscribed (RIB 219); MARTI TOVTATI TI CLAVDIVS PRIMVS ATTI LIBER VSLM (For Mars Toutatis. Titus Claudius Primus Atticus, freedman, willingly and deservedly fulfils a vow);

2. Bronze ansate plaque from the Hadrian’s Wall area is inscribed; MARTI TOVIATL[S] S[acrvm] VINOMA V[otvm] L[ibens] S[olvit] (Sacred Mars Toutatis. Vinoma willingly paid a vow);

3. The Graffito from Kelvedon, Essex is inscribed: (RIB 2503.131) TOVTATIS (Toutatis);

and even if you wanted to interpret those three as reading '...Mars, king of the tribe'... the Cumberland inscription brings the bacon home.

4. The Sandstone altar from the Cumberland Quarries, Cumberland (RIB 1017) is inscribed: RIOCALAT ET TOVTAT MAR COCIDO VOTO FECIT VITALIS (To Riocalatis and Toutatis, Mars Cocidius, Vitalis made this vow).

The rings therefore must read DEO TOTAT (To the god Toutatis), rather than DEO TOTAT (To the god the king of the tribe)

An inscription from Austria also reads:

MARTI LATOBIO MARMOGIO TOUTATI SINATI MOG[et]IO C[aius] VAL[erius] [V]ALERINVS EX VOTO (To Mars Latobius, Marmogius, Toutatis, Sinatis, Mogetius. Caius Vaerius Valerinus offers this in fulfilment of his vows).

Lucan seems pretty confident he's talking about a god too.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>Portable Antiquities request for rally help!</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/16/rallyhelp/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Jul 2007 10:38:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/332</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Portable Antiquities Scheme for the North and East Yorkshire Region is recruiting volunteers to assist with finds recording and identification at two metal-detecting rally weekends. Please contact <a href="mailto:rallies@ymt.org.uk">rallies@ymt.org.uk</a> if you are interested in learning more about metal-detecting and archaeology, or if you would like (or if you have!) object-handling/recording experience. We welcome you if you can offer a day or a whole weekend; post-rally assistance is also appreciated!

The rallies are taking place in North Yorkshire. Transportation to and from the sites will be provided if required.

Snape: 25th, 26th, 27th of August 2007
Ripon: 14th, 15th, 16th of September 2007

If you have any questions, or if you would like to volunteer, please contact:

<a href="mailto:rallies@ymt.org.uk">rallies@ymt.org.uk</a>

Yorkshire Museum
Museum Gardens
York, YO1 7FR
Tel: 01904 687 668]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Several of the country's leading news sources report on the publicity stunt at Cerne Abbas pushing the new Simpsons movie. A massive pictures of Homer and his beloved doughnuts has been painted next to the possibly Antiquarian created <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cerne_Abbas_Giant">Cerne Abbas priapic giant</a>. This picture from the Sun was the best I could find:
<img src="http://images.thesun.co.uk/picture/0,,2007321730,00.jpg" alt="Simpsons Cerne Abbas" />
This shows changing ideologies to some extent, do the people of the Western World now worship or idolise different things to the ancients? I think the answer is probably yes. The Pagans are predictably not happy....although it will probably be gone by the end of today as rain is forecast and it is painted on with bio-degradable paint. You can read more here:

<ol>
	<li><a href="http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2007320865,00.html">The Sun</a></li>

	<item>
		<title>All Party Parliamentary Archaeology Group (APPAG) inquiry relating to pay and conditions in archaeology</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/17/payproperly/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Jul 2007 08:47:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/335</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.appag.org.uk/images/emblem.gif" alt="APPAG logo">This has been pinched directly from a Britarch post by Mike Heyworth, particularly relevant as archaeology is indeed a poor relation to many other graduate professions. Out of my contemporaries at UCL, there's only a few I know of who have stayed in the archaeological sector.

The APPAG report 'The Current State of Archaeology in the United Kingdom' (2002) states:


<blockquote>"There is an urgent need to improve pay and conditions for employment in field archaeology so that they are commensurate with graduate entry level in allied professions such as local authority planning officers, civil engineers and university lecturers. The IFA, working with English Heritage (EH) and the other national heritage agencies and Prospect, should create a structure for training and qualifications related to career development that will set standards for best practice in archaeological work, one in which employers are obliged to support the continuing professional development of staff. Only those contractors that meet these standards should be eligible to bid for developer-funded work. In the longer term, the current fragmented commercial unit system which has resulted from competitive tendering should be replaced with a more stable regional, or more local framework of archaeological organisations."</blockquote>

Five years on APPAG is aware that there are initiatives under way to implement some of its recommendations and to improve the pay and conditions of archaeologists. To assess how far they have got and how fast they are being acted upon, APPAG intends to hold a short inquiry.

Initially APPAG is seeking brief written submissions from those taking an active role in seeking to improve pay and conditions, setting out what they are doing and how they intend to implement any reforms. APPAG is interested in information and comment on what is being done, not on the present position. Submissions of up to 1000 words should be sent to <a href="mailto:inquiry@appag.org.uk">inquiry@appag.org.uk</a> by 30 September 2007.

Thereafter APPAG will invite organisations or individuals to provide oral evidence at inquiry hearings during the autumn. After considering the evidence, APPAG will produce a report making targeted recommendations, and may organise debates in Parliament.
<a href="http://www.appag.org.uk">
www.appag.org.uk</a>

The Scheme is one of the better paying divisions of the Archaeological world, excavators get paid peanuts for hard labour. Others doing sterling work for raising pay include BAJR and the IFA.]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="mike-heyworth"><![CDATA[Mike Heyworth]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[s:245:"a:5:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:5:"APPAG";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:11:"archaeology";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:10:"employment";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:8:"heritage";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:3:"pay";}}";]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Making History: Antiquaries in Britain, 1707 - 2007</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/17/ra/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Jul 2007 10:59:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/336</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://static.royalacademy.org.uk/static/site/graphics/logo.gif" alt="RA logo">A new exhibition will be opening at the RA shortly, details below:

(15 September – 2 December 2007)
Royal Academy of Arts
Adult ticket price £8
Concession rate for Groups (+ 10) £6.50

Making History: Antiquaries in Britain, 1707 – 2007 will explore the work and achievement of the Society of Antiquaries of London over the past three hundred years since its foundation in the early eighteenth century to the present day.

The exhibition, which will consist of 190 works, will showcase for the first time treasures from Britain’s oldest Learned Society concerned with the study of the past. It will feature unique works of art, antiquities and manuscripts of national historical importance, from one of the oldest museum collections in this country, including a Yorkist processional cross recovered from the battlefield of Bosworth (1485), the inventory of Henry VIII’s possessions at the time of his death and an early copy of Magna Carta. Also on show will be paintings of ancient sites and landscapes by Constable, Turner, Blake and an extraordinary collection of English royal portraits from Henry VI to Mary Tudor. In addition there will be the only surviving visual records of objects long since lost or destroyed.

Making History: Antiquaries in Britain, 1707 – 2007 will explore key stages in the creation of Britain’s historical narrative, from the earliest archaeological discoveries of the early modern age to the rise of the professional historians and archaeologists in the 20th century and insights into
how we might study the past in the future. The exhibition will culminate with a special study of Stonehenge, arguably Britain's best known monument, revealing how our understanding of its
history keeps on changing over time thanks to the process of research and to new discoveries such as a recently unearthed late medieval drawing of the megaliths, never before seen in this
country.

The exhibition’s guest curator, the celebrated historian Dr David Starkey FSA, says:
<blockquote>“For me, history has always been as much about things – buildings, paintings, jewels – as written documents. So this Exhibition won’t simply be a display of the Society’s treasures – wonderful though they are – it’s also an opportunity to show how history is made and why it matters”.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Temple of Mithras</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/19/slaythebull/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Jul 2007 09:53:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/338</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/lond42.jpg' alt='Bust of Mithras'>Scanning the DCMS rss feed, I came across this <a href="http://www.culture.gov.uk/Reference_library/Press_notices/archive_2007/dcms014_07.htm">announcement</a> for the listing of the Temple of Mithras on London Wall. Then yesterday, the Evening Standard ran a story about the relocation of the temple to its original site under a new building with proper viewing facilities. I've not managed to find an online link to this in their website (awful search engine!) However there is a reference to the <a href="http://www.london.gov.uk/mayor/planning_decisions/2006/20060830.jsp#11">planning application</a> to relocate the remains at Bucklersbury House, Walbrook Square. This would be designed by Norman Foster's architectural practise and be on behalf of Legal and General. The proposal states:

<blockquote>The development also returns and reconstructs the remains of the Temple of Mithras in their original location in a publicly accessibly display chamber, which will be accessed through a pavilion in the new public square.</blockquote>

Could be a good thing....and for more on Mithras read the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mithras">wikipedia</a> entry.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Most important Viking Treasure in 150 years found by metal detectorists in North Yorkshire</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/19/most-important-viking-treasure-in-150-years-found-by-metal-detectorists-in-north-yorkshire/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Jul 2007 13:36:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/339</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today the following announcement was made at the British Museum, regarding a fantastic discovery made by 2 metal detectorists. It was the first Treasure case that local finds liaison officer <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/people/profile.php?personID=68">Amy Cooper</a> was presented with, from now on, what will beat the experience of this one? This is another story highlighting best practise by finders and is very topical as this is <a href="http://www.britarch.ac.uk/naw/">National Archaeology Week</a>. Most pertinent in this case, is the fact that it has only been declared Treasure today and has to undergo valuation and the entire <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/treasure">Treasure process</a> associated with it. It is not on display to the public at present.

This is the third story to make the front page of 24 Hour Museum in the last week, and we have seen a 4000% increase in visitors from their site in that period compared to the usual average referrals. Photos can be viewed under our <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/10257668@N04/sets/72157600901237459/">flickr profile</a>.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-x-ray-detail.jpg' title='An X ray detail from the hoard’s containing vessel'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-x-ray-detail.thumbnail.jpg' alt='An X ray detail from the hoard’s containing vessel'></a>

The official press release is below and the objects will be recorded within the Scheme's database after the Treasure process is completed.

A major Viking hoard was discovered in the Harrogate area in January 2007 by metal-detectorists David and Andrew Whelan. The size and quality of the hoard is remarkable, making it the most important find of its type in Britain for over 150 years. The father and son detecting team promptly reported the hoard to their local Finds Liaison Officer, and displayed exemplary behaviour in not unpacking all the objects from the bowl, but keeping the find intact. As a possible Treasure find, it was then transferred to the British Museum where conservators have carefully excavated each find to avoid damaging the individual objects or losing important contextual information.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-all-contents.jpg' title='The excavated vessel contents'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-all-contents.thumbnail.jpg' alt='The excavated vessel contents'></a>
The conservation work has revealed that like other Viking hoards of the period, it contains a mixture of different precious metal objects, including coins, complete ornaments, ingots (bars) and chopped-up fragments known as hack-silver. The hoard also shows the diversity of cultural contacts in the medieval world, with objects coming from as far apart as Afghanistan in the East and Ireland in the West, as well as Russia, Scandinavia and continental Europe.

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-x-ray.jpg' title='The vessel xray'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-x-ray.jpg' alt='The vessel xray' /></a>

The most spectacular single object is a gilt silver vessel, made in what is now France in the first half of the ninth century. It was apparently intended for use in church services, and was probably either looted from a monastery by Vikings, or given to them in tribute. Most of the smaller objects were hidden inside this vessel, which was itself protected by some form of lead container. As a result, the hoard was extremely well-preserved. Other star objects include a rare gold arm-ring, and over 600 coins, including several new or rare types. These provide valuable new information about the history of England in the early tenth century, as well as Yorkshire’s wider cultural contacts in the period. Interestingly, the hoard contains coins relating to Islam and to the pre-Christian religion of the Vikings, as well as to Christianity.

The hoard was probably buried for safety by a wealthy Viking leader during the unrest that followed the conquest of the Viking kingdom of Northumbria in AD 927 by the Anglo-Saxon king Athelstan (924-39).

<a href='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-half-way-down.jpg' title='The hoard vessel partly unpacked, halfway through conservation'><img src='http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/images/2007/07/harrogate-h-half-way-down.jpg' alt='The hoard vessel partly unpacked, halfway through conservation' /></a>

The Harrogate hoard was declared to be Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act (1996) by Mr Fell, HM Coroner for North Yorkshire, on 19th July 2007. The find is of global importance, as well as having huge significance for the history of North Yorkshire. York Museum Trust, Harrogate Borough Council's Museums &amp; Arts Service and the British Museum are committed to working together to acquire, interpret and exhibit the hoard, and to making it accessible to the widest possible public, both in the region and elsewhere.

The next stage of the Treasure process is for the hoard to be valued for the Department of Culture, Media and Sport by the independent Treasure Valuation Committee. In the meantime the museums will continue to develop more detailed plans to raise money for the acquisition, and to exhibit the hoard once it is acquired.

Margaret Hodge, Culture Minister said:

<blockquote>Finds such as this are invaluable in teaching us about our history. This remarkable discovery highlights the contribution both the Treasure Act and the Portable Antiquities Scheme continue to make towards our knowledge of the past. I commend David and Andrew Whelan for their prompt and responsible reporting of this hugely significant find, which will enrich our understanding of the Vikings.</blockquote>

Mr Fell, Coroner, commented:

<blockquote>Treasure cases are always interesting, but this is one of the most exciting cases that I have ever had to rule on. I'm delighted that such an important Viking hoard has been discovered in North Yorkshire. We are extremely proud of our Viking heritage in this area.</blockquote>

Mary Kershaw, Director of Collections at York, said:

<blockquote>York’s new partnership with the British Museum has focused on sharing collections for display, such as the Warren Cup and Roman collections for the Constantine exhibition at the Yorkshire Museum.  It would be wonderful to work together on the joint purchase of such a stunning and important group of material.</blockquote>

Gina Lane Director of Operations, Museums, Libraries and Archives Council said:

<blockquote>Thanks to the continuing responsible behaviour of metal detectorists, another fantastic find has been made available for everyone to enjoy, either online or in museums. This is also thanks to successful partnership working between the local museum services and the British Museum.</blockquote>

For further information or images please contact Hannah Boulton at the British Museum on 020 7323 8522 or <a href="mailto:hboulton@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk">hboulton@thebritishmuseum.ac.uk</a>

<h4>Notes to Editors</h4>

<ol>
	<li>The hoard contains a total of 617 silver coins and 65 other objects, as well as a gold-arm-ring and the gilt silver vessel. Several fragments of lead found with the hoard appear to come from some sort of container. </li>

	<li>The largest Viking hoard in western Europe was found at <a href="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/t/the_cuerdale_hoard.aspx">Cuerdale</a> in Lancashire in 1840. Objects from the Cuerdale hoard are now on display in several museums around the UK, with the largest group housed in the British Museum. The Harrogate hoard is the largest Viking and most important hoard from Britain since the Cuerdale.</li>
<li>A Viking army conquered the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Northumbria in AD 869. The area remained under Viking control until it was conquered by Athelstan in 927. The area had another brief period of independence following Athelstan’s death in 939, which lasted until the death of the Viking ruler Eric Bloodaxe in 954.</li>
<li>Vikings made a lasting impact in Britain, including place-names, sculpture and influence on the English language, as well as archaeological remains. Yorkshire is one of the areas which shows the strongest Viking influence. For more information see the BM's <a href="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/explore/world_cultures/europe/vikings.aspx">Viking pages</a></li>
<li>British Museum and the York Museums Trust work closely together as under the banner of Partnership UK, the strategic framework for the British Museum’s programme of engagement with audiences throughout the country. </li>
<li>All finders of gold and silver objects, and groups of coins from the same finds, over 300 years old, have a legal obligation to report such items under the Treasure Act 1996. Prehistoric base-metal assemblages found after 1st January 2003 also qualify as Treasure. Treasure finds must be reported by law to the local coroner, which is normally done through the finders local PAS Finds Liaison Officer. More information is available on <a href="http://www.culture.gov.uk">www.culture.gov.uk</a> or <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk">www.finds.org.uk</a></li>
<li>The Portable Antiquities Scheme has a national network of 36 Finds Liaison Officers who record all archaeological finds made by members of the public and assist with the reporting of potential Treasure finds, as required by the Treasure Act. The Scheme is run by the BM on behalf of MLA. The online database, <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk">www.finds.org.uk</a>, contains details over 280,000 objects</li></ol>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Fascinating find!  I will look forward in the future to reading more about what can be determined by such a magnificent find.  I have an interest in coins, and metal detecting, and this particular find makes me want to get back out in the field and do some digging.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Publicity from the hoard</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/20/webresponses/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 20 Jul 2007 14:36:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/345</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Harrogate hoard has generated heaps of column inches and various websites have picked up the news over the last 24 hours. Great for the British Museum and the Scheme, we saw a doubling of our visitors yesterday all looking for these details. You can find these references (reproduced below) all with different degrees of journalistic spin! Shame there is no more direct mention of the Scheme, as Amy was the reason why it came here after the responsible actions of the finder's. I am actually surprised that it didn't break earlier after the metal detecting magazines ran some articles by Peter Spencer a few months ago.....

<strong>Broadcast:</strong>

BBC One o' clock news
BBC 10 o' clock news
Channel Four lunch time bulletin
<a href="http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/arts_entertainment/art/unearthing+viking+treasure/611252">Channel Four evening bulletin</a>
Five News
Newsround
ITN News
Sky News
<a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/arts/frontrow/past_programmes.shtml">BBC Radio 4 Front Row</a>
BBC Radio 4 Six o' clock news
BBC World Service
BSN
Radio 5 Live (to go out very early on Monday morning) - thanks to Win Scutt

<strong>Print</strong>

<a href="http://arts.guardian.co.uk/art/heritage/story/0,,2130832,00.html">Guardian</a>
<a href="http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article2106130.ece">Times</a>
<a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/07/20/nviking120.xml">Telegraph</a>
<a href="http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/this_britain/article2785479.ece">Independent</a>
Evening Standard
London Paper

<a href="http://news.google.co.uk/news?hl=en&amp;ned=uk&amp;ie=UTF-8&amp;ncl=1118330009">Google news search</a> reveals over 45 references and this is growing daily with stories popping up on our rss feed constantly. The blogosphere is also getting in on the act rapidly, with <a href="http://www.technorati.com/posts/tag/viking+hoard">Technorati</a> showing up plenty of comments and posts. I apologise in advance for some of the Blog names....can't do much about that! Amazing how one find can generate so many column inches. Treasure items still count for less than 1% of our yearly records - we now have over 280,000 objects online for the public to peruse and our database is going to get slicker over the coming months. Promise.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Revamped section and new feature</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/24/salve/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Jul 2007 16:16:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/346</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the last couple of days, I have been revamping one of the resources I built with our old Roman Coins Finds Adviser <a href="http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/the_museum/about_us/staff/coins_and_medals/ian_leins.aspx">Ian Leins</a>. He has since moved on to become a Curator within Coins and Medals in the British Museum with responsibility for Iron Age coins and their study and interpretation. Since then, <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/people/profile.php?personID=87">Sam Moorhead</a> has come into his role and we've revamped the Scheme's database numismatics substantially. I've used the basis of this work to complete some major additions to the facilities we have for the identification of Roman coins. So this week, I have added:
<ol>
	<li><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/romancoins/mintmap.php">Google map</a> with <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/geo/mints-rome.php">KML layer</a> for Roman Mints (shown below)</li>
	<li>Added a <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/romancoins/reece.php">Reece periodisation</a> guide</li>
	<li>Enhanced the mint information to demonstrate under <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/romancoins/mint.php?ID=1">which Emperor</a> these issuing places were active</li>
	<li>Enhanced the <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/romancoins/obverse.php?emperorID=1">emperor information</a> pages so that you can now see what denominations they issued, which Reece period they fit into, mints active, most recently recorded coins by our staff, and a county breakdown</li>
<li>Tidied up the <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/romancoins/high_res/early_denoms.php">high resolution pages</a> that make use of the free zoomify viewer (I'd forgotten to add the Google code to these pages!!)</li>
</ol>

<dl>
<dt><a href="http://maps.google.com/?z=4&amp;ll=41.9,12.48&amp;om=5">Center of map</a></dt><dt><a href="http://www.finds.org.uk/geo/mints-rome.php" title="kml">Roman mints</a></dt><dd>Roman mints map</dd>
</dl>

To come within this section:
<ol>
	<li>Enhanced biographical data</li>	<li>Thumbnail images of most recently recorded coins</li>	<li>Scrolling image carousel to aid identifications</li><li>Later Roman emperors</li><li>Check the code for validity</li></ol>

This section is far and away our most popular area of our site. Google Analytics, shows that the average weekly traffic to our website is 10-15% of our total and visitors look at over 30 pages and have an average visit length of 15 minutes. It's now the top ranked tool for coin identification on Google.

In terms of new features, I've added Google's Cooperative search to our site. It seems to work quite well and indexes the following sites (seems to be quite comprehensive):
<ol>
	<li>finds.org.uk</li>	<li>pastexplorers.org.uk</li>	<li>findsdatabase.org.uk</li></ol>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>PAS and oral questions</title>

	<item>
		<title>PAS flickr feed made public</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/25/pas-flickr-feed-made-public/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2007 15:32:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/348</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We used to have a very active photo gallery based on the opensource <a href="http://gallery.menalto.com">gallery</a> software; however this seemed to suffer from a variety of archiving robots that caused the site to seize up regularly. To combat this, I've decided to move our photo system across to <a href="http://www.flickr.com">flickr</a> and see if we can get some user driven content onto the site relating to events and meetings run by the Scheme. Our id is "portable antiquities" and you can access these photos directly under an "attribution" <a href="http://www.creative-commons.org">Creative Commons</a> Licence. If you want to get an <a href="http://api.flickr.com/services/feeds/photos_public.gne?id=10257668@N04&amp;lang=en-us&amp;format=rss_200">RSS feed</a> of these, you can also do this.

The <a href="http://www.finds.org.uk">Scheme's homepage</a> now features a feed of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/10257668@N04/">images</a> directly from the flickr site and updates automatically and uses the class wrapper provided by <a href="http://phpflickr.com">phpflickr</a> to compile the images on screen. The code is below and also makes use of caching to speed up the rendering of the images.

[php]
enableCache(
    "db",
    "mysql://userid:password@server/database"
);$i = 0;
 {
    // Find the NSID of the username inputted via the form
    $person = $f-&gt;people_findByUsername('flickr username');

    // Get the friendly URL of the user's photos
    $photos_url = $f-&gt;urls_getUserPhotos($person['id']);

    // Get the user's first 15 public photos
    $photos = $f-&gt;people_getPublicPhotos($person['id'], NULL, 15);

    // Loop through the photos and output the html
    foreach ((array)$photos['photo'] as $photo) {
        echo "<a href="$photos_url$photo[id]">";
        echo "<img alt='$photo[title]'>buildPhotoURL($photo, "Square") . "&gt;";
        echo "</a>";
        $i++;
        // If it reaches the third photo, insert a line break
        if ($i % 3 == 0) {
            echo "<br />\n";
        }
    }
}
?&gt;
[/php]

You can adapt the script quite easily to your own needs, or go for different flavours of output such as JSON - I've used that on <a href="http://www.bips.ac.uk/flickr/">another site</a>. If you want to add photos to flickr that relate to the Scheme, perhaps use the tag "portable antiquities" and I'll set up a feed of user driven content on the site. I'm thinking about setting up a page that draws in content from <a href="http://www.technorati.com/posts/tag/%2522portable%2Bantiquities%2522">technorati</a>, del.icio.us, digg, <a href="http://www.theyworkforyou.com/search/?s=%22portable+antiquities%22">They work for you</a> and various other sources that aggregates comments relating to the Scheme.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>348</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>pas-flickr-feed-made-public</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>50,000 objects recorded for 2007</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2007/07/26/stats/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 26 Jul 2007 12:14:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>daniel pett</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.finds.org.uk/wordpress/index.php/349</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Since the 1st January, the Scheme has recorded 50,000 objects offered to our staff and volunteer recorders for the benefit of archaeological researchers, planning offices and other interested parties. In the previous year, we recorded 56,438 in the 12 month period beginning Jan 1st 2006  and ending on New Year's Eve. So we're on course for a record year of object information being made available. Some of the objects recorded this year have brought some interesting publicity to the fore - for example the Harrogate Hoard, Adam's work on Tot rings and the slave figurine to name but a few. There's no doubt some more interesting stories to tell as the year unfolds.

<a href="http://www.swivel.com/graphs/show/21088068"><img alt="Objects" src="http://www.swivel.com/graphs/image/21088069" title="Click to play with this data at Swivel" /></a>

The graph above shows the increases, and the last year is only partial so shows a dip so far. By year end this will be a lot higher. Obviously these stats are quite emotive and will cause comments about archaeological record erosion, but these arguments will always linger.

For those that don't know, the Scheme is also going to be 10 years old in September and there should be some special publicity to mark the occasion.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>349</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2007-07-26 13:14:12</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2007-07-26 12:14:12</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>stats</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="adam"><![CDATA[Adam]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="new-years-eve"><![CDATA[New Year\'s Eve]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_utw_tags_0</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[s:118:"a:2:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:20:"portable-antiquities";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:10:"statistics";}}";]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_utw_tags_</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[s:118:"a:2:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:20:"portable-antiquities";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:3:"tag";s:10:"statistics";}}";]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>98</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Paul Barford]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>pbarford@pro.onet.pl</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>87.207.132.90</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2007-07-27 10:14:15</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2007-07-27 09:14:15</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[This is all very interesting, but there are a couple of things here I do not understand.

1) The figures do NOT represent “archaeological record erosion” (sic) – the PAS database constitutes part of the archaeological record. Many of PAS’ finds are recorded accidental finds – it would be really helpful if you’d separate these on a year by year basis from those that are the product of artefact hunting and collecting. Arguments tend to "linger" especially where there is a lack of clarity what we are discussing.

2) I also do not see why after nearly a decade of counting finds according to a reporting period of a financial year, suddenly PAS decide to count them in a totally different way. This can only lead to confusion. Will this new way of counting be reflected in the 2006/7 Annual Report?

3) Try as I might, I cannot see how the figures presented in your graph relate to those given in the Annual Reports which we have all been using and discussing up till now.  The 1999 report for example states a further 31,783 objects were recorded in that year, your graph now says 8000. The 2000 report states 37517 objects were recorded, your graph says 18000. But the Annual Report for 2001-3 says 49000 objects were recorded, your graph gives 16+12+21= 49, so now the same (despite the one being calculated for the financial year, the other calendar year so this cannot be the only explanation of the discrepancy in other years’ figures). In the figures for the next year however there is another discrepancy; according to the annual report in 2004 a further 67,213 objects were recorded, but your new graph tells us it was just 39 000. So perhaps those 28 000 objects were added to the database 1st Jan – 31st March 2005? Well, no because the discrepancy between THAT year’s Annual Report figures and your revised ones is ‘only’ 5500 objects. The reports of annual progress have pretty consistently given higher values than the ones now being presented. Why?

Indeed if we add up all the figures from your graph (and adding the missing values for 1997-8 from the annual reports) according to my maths we get a total of 306 000 objects. If however we total the figures given in the annual reports (and add the figures from your graph for 2006 and 2007), it seems to me we get a total of 382,900 objects. Well, they can’t both be right can they? The difference of 76000 objects is about a QUARTER of the lower total ! But to add a further discrepancy, on May 23rd you wrote here that “the current running total for all finds ever recorded is 271,000” and since then (figures from same source) you say some 12000 finds have been added – so that would mean the maximum figure should now be 283 000. Are we dealing perhaps with different definitions of the term "objects recorded on the database" maybe?


Paul Barford]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
