	<item>
		<title>Access levels and what you can view</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/05/14/access-levels-and-what-you-can-view/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 May 2010 16:27:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=837</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Following our Portable Antiquities Advisory Group meeting, I was asked what levels of detail people are privy to on the Scheme's database. The below outlines what these account levels can do/see and what geo information is displayed.
<h3>Public user - not logged in</h3>
The public user level is the most basic of all our levels of access. This gives you access to:
<ul>
	<li>Finds awaiting validation (denoted by the yellow flag)</li>
	<li>Finds that have been validated and published by our finds advisers (denoted by green flag)</li>
	<li>Low level mapping
<ul>
	<li> no dots on maps</li>
	<li>findspot to 1km grid square level and slight obfuscation of findspot by randomised subtraction/addition of 10ths of a degree to the degraded findspot</li>
	<li>limited zoom level.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>No access to personal data</li>
	<li>Can add comments but has to fill in reCaptcha</li>
</ul>
<h3>Registered user - most basic level of login</h3>
<ul>
	<li>Finds awaiting validation (denoted by the yellow flag)</li>
	<li>Finds that have been validated and published by our finds advisers (denoted by green flag)</li>
	<li>They can create their own records of their objects and get full mapping capabilities for only these objects which is enhanced over the below low level grade map.</li>
	<li>Low level mapping
<ul>
	<li>no dots on maps,</li>
	<li>findspot to 1km grid square level and slight obfuscation of findspot by randomised subtraction/addition of 10ths of a degree to the degraded findspot,</li>
	<li>limited zoom level.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Cannot see maps or retrieve finds by parish for any record with the findspot form's "to be known as" field completed</li>
	<li>No access to personal data</li>
	<li>Can add comments without having to fill in reCaptchas</li>
	<li>Can add/edit their own records</li>
	<li>Can save searches</li>
</ul>
<h3>Researchers</h3>
<ul>
	<li>Finds awaiting validation (denoted by the yellow flag)</li>
	<li>Finds that have been validated and published by our finds advisers (denoted by green flag)</li>
	<li>Cannot view finds that are still in progress (quarantine/review)</li>
	<li>As above, they can create their own records of their objects and get full mapping capabilities forthese objects.</li>
	<li>High level mapping
<ul>
	<li>findspot plotted with a dot on the map</li>
	<li>full precision for findspot</li>
	<li>Flickr shapefile outline for parishes</li>
	<li>Access to Scheduled Ancient Monument proximity search</li>
	<li>Full zoom capabilities</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>No access to personal data</li>
	<li>Can add/edit their own records</li>
	<li>Enhanced spreadsheet downloads</li>
</ul>
<h3>Historic Environment Officers</h3>
<ul>
	<li>Finds awaiting validation (denoted by the yellow flag)</li>
	<li>Finds that have been validated and published by our finds advisers (denoted by green flag)</li>
	<li>Cannot view finds that are still in progress (quarantine/review)</li>
	<li>As above, they can create their own records of their objects and get full mapping capabilities forthese objects.</li>
	<li>High level mapping
<ul>
	<li>findspot plotted with a dot on the map</li>
	<li>full precision for findspot</li>
	<li>Flickr shapefile outline for parishes</li>
	<li>Access to Scheduled Ancient Monument proximity search</li>
	<li>Full zoom capabilities</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>No access to personal data</li>
	<li>Can add/edit own records</li>
	<li>Enhanced spreadsheet download</li>
	<li>Special download of csv for import into exeGesis HBSMR (if you don't know what that is, don't worry!)</li>
</ul>
<h3>Treasure &amp; Finds Liaison Officers</h3>
<ul>
	<li>Finds in quarantine - records that need more data (reminds them to do so!)</li>
	<li>Finds on review - current working versions</li>
	<li>Finds awaiting validation (denoted by the yellow flag)</li>
	<li>Finds that have been validated and published by our finds advisers (denoted by green flag)</li>
	<li>As above, they can create their own records of their objects and get full mapping capabilities forthese objects.</li>
	<li>High level mapping
<ul>
	<li>findspot plotted with a dot on the map</li>
	<li>full precision for findspot</li>
	<li>Flickr shapefile outline for parishes</li>
	<li>Access to Scheduled Ancient Monument proximity search</li>
	<li>Full zoom capabilities</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Full access to personal data</li>
	<li>Can add/edit own records</li>
	<li>Can edit records made by member, HERO and research users</li>
	<li>Can edit any records they made when working in other counties</li>
	<li>Can edit records made by anyone at their institution</li>
	<li>Enhanced spreadsheet download</li>
	<li>Special download of csv for import into exeGesis HBSMR</li>
</ul>
<h3>Find Advisers</h3>
<ul>
	<li>Finds in quarantine - records that need more data (reminds them to do so!)</li>
	<li>Finds on review - current working versions</li>
	<li>Finds awaiting validation (denoted by the yellow flag)</li>
	<li>Finds that have been validated and published by our finds advisers (denoted by green flag)</li>
	<li>As above, they can create their own records of their objects and get full mapping capabilities forthese objects.</li>
	<li>High level mapping
<ul>
	<li>findspot plotted with a dot on the map</li>
	<li>full precision for findspot</li>
	<li>Flickr shapefile outline for parishes</li>
	<li>Access to Scheduled Ancient Monument proximity search</li>
	<li>Full zoom capabilities</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Full access to personal data</li>
	<li>Can add/edit own records</li>
	<li>Can edit any records created by any user and can publish finds</li>
	<li>Enhanced spreadsheet download</li>
	<li>Special download of csv for import into exeGesis HBSMR</li>
</ul>
<h3>Admin</h3>
Now that would be telling.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author_url>http://dartproject.info/WPBlog/?p=151</wp:comment_author_url>

			<wp:comment_date>2010-06-12 09:49:34</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-06-12 09:49:34</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[[...] Whatever the answer the point remains: archaeologists, for right or wrong, consider the implications of placing fine grained data in the public domain and “Ethical considerations” have been identified as a “barrier” to deposition. However, there appears to be limited guidance as to how to resolve these issues. This means that many archaeologists are re-inventing the wheel. The challenge is to provide some supporting “thing” that makes it easy for individuals and organisations to get to a clear, and hopefully unambiguous, ethical position. Such a “thing” will reduce uncertainty thereby removing one of the barriers to data sharing. The current default position is the equivalent of doing nothing: surely this must change. Supporting “stuff” which is recognised and approved by national heritage organisations and standards bodies will act as important lubricant to help individuals and groups to release data through informal channels. It should be recognised that the relationship between the “citizen”, the archaeologists and heritage data will change: citizen science and citizen data, will play more of a role in heritage than ever before. Hence, a focus on the informal is important: we don’t want more grey data do we? The Portable Antiquities Scheme is the “poster boy” for archaeological approaches to citizen science &#8211; although they do have a range of different user access levels. [...] ]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Leveraging geodata for enriched records</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/09/30/leveraging-geodata/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 14:04:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=748</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This post discusses how I've been using various geodata tools (principally Yahoo!, but also Flickr shapefiles, Google's maps and geocoder apis, Geonames, OSdata and I'm now exploring the Unlock project from Edina to see what they can offer as well), for the enrichment of our database. I started writing this post back in May, but as I've just spoken at the <a href="http://www.w3gconf.com/">W3G unconference</a> in Stratford-on-Avon, I thought I'd finish it and get it out. Gary Gale and his helpers produced a very good un-conference, at which I met some very interesting people (shame TW Bell couldn't come!) and saw some good examples of what other people are up to.

My presentation from that conference is embedded here:
[slideshare id=5321797&amp;doc=w3gconfsafer-100930030931-phpapp01]

Most of us realise the power of maps and I've made them a very central cog of the new Scheme website that we soft launched at the end of March 2010. Hopefully this isn't too long and boring and has some technical stuff that may be of some use to others. As always, the below is CC-NC-SA.

<a class="flow" href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/09/allfinds.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium img-fluid 1026" title="allfinds" src="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/09/allfinds-212x300.jpg" alt="A map showing all finds recorded by the Scheme" width="212" height="300" /></a>At the Scheme, we've been collecting data on the provenance of archaeological discoveries made by the public and publishing it online for 13 years now (much longer than I've worked for the Scheme!), and these are collated on our database and provide the basis for spatial interrogation of where and when these objects have been discovered. Many researchers are using the database for a variety of geomatics, for example patterning, cluster analysis etc. A few of our recent AHRC funded PhD candidates have been implementing GIS techniques as one of the integral parts of their research - for example:
<ol>
	<li><a title="Outline of Tom's research" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/research/projects/project/id/12">Tom Brindle</a>, KCL</li>
	<li><a title="Outline of Philippa's work" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/research/projects/project/id/19">Philippa Walton</a>, UCL</li>
	<li><a title="Outline of Ian's research" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/research/projects/project/id/13">Ian Leins</a>, Newcastle University</li>
	<li><a title="Outline of Katie's research" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/research/projects/project/id/31">Katie Robbins</a>, Southampton University</li>
</ol>
They are all incidentally <a title="A list and stats for our alumni" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/contacts/alumni">alumni of the Scheme</a> (and one has rejoined recently!), and have been inspired with their research from working on these data that we collate.  I won't be discussing the philosophical arguments of provenance and its meaning within this article, but demonstrating how we're using third-party tools to enhance find spot data on our site and talk about some of the problems we face to make use of them. Some of the post will have some code examples, but you can gloss over them if you're not into that (which the majority of our readers will probably be!)
<h4>Find spot data</h4>
Our <a href="http://finds.org.uk/contacts">Find Liaison Officers</a> record the majority of objects that we are shown onto our database and ask the finder to provide us with the most accurate National Grid Reference (OSGB36) that they can produce. Many of our finders are now using GPS units to produce grid references (we're aware of the degree of accuracy/precision they provide, but as most objects aren't from secure archaeological contexts, the variance won't affect work that much.) We encourage people to provide these figures to a level of 8 figures and above and this proportion is growing every year. The list below shows the precision of each grid reference length:
<ul>
	<li>0 figure [SP] = 100 kilometre square</li>
	<li>2 figure [SP11] = 10 kilometre square</li>
	<li>4 figure [SP1212] = 1 kilometre square</li>
	<li>6 figure [SP8123123] = 100 metre square</li>
</ul>
Then we get the figures that are actually of some archaeological use:
<ul>
	<li>8 figure [SP812341234] = 10 metre square</li>
	<li>10 figure [SP1234512345] = 1 metre square</li>
	<li>12 figure [SP123456123456] = 10 centimetre square</li>
</ul>
This find spot data is given to us in confidence by the finders and landowners and we therefore have to protect this confidence. We have an agreement with the main providers of our data - the metal detecting community - representative body (<a href="http://www.ncmd.co.uk/">The National Council for Metal Detecting</a>), that we won't publish on-line find spots at a precision higher than a 4 figure national grid reference or to parish level. These grid references can be obscured from public view completely by asking the Finds Liaison Officer to enter a to be "<strong>known as</strong>" alias on the find spot form at the time of recording (or subsequently).
<h4>Converting OSGB36 grid references to Latitude and Longitude pairs</h4>
Most of the web mapping programs out there, make use of Latitude and Longitude pairs for displaying point data on their mapping interfaces. Therefore, we now convert all our NGRs to LatLng on our database and these are stored as floats in two columns in our find spots table. Whilst processing these grid references to the LatLng pairs, I also do some further manipulations to produce and insert into our spatial data table:
<ol>
	<li>Grid reference length</li>
	<li>Accuracy of grid reference as shown above</li>
	<li>Four figure grid reference</li>
	<li>1:25k map reference</li>
	<li>1:10k map reference</li>
	<li>Findspot elevation</li>
	<li>Where on Earth ID</li>
</ol>
The PHP code functions to do this are based around some written by the original Oxford ArchDigital team and has some additions by me. There are publicly available code examples by <a title="Geograph php code" href="http://www.nearby.org.uk/downloads.html">Barry Hunter</a> or <a title="Jeff Stott's phpcoord code" href="http://www.jstott.me.uk/phpcoord/">Jeff Stott</a> or some other versions out there on the web! My code is used as either a service or view helper in my Zend Framework project and bundles together a variety of functions. I'm not a developer, I've just taught myself bits and pieces to get the PAS website back on the road; if you see errors, do let me know or suggest ways to improve the code.
<h4>Using Yahoo! to geo-enrich our data</h4>
Several years ago, the great <a href="http://twitter.com/twbell">Tyler Bell</a> (formerly of Oxford ArchDigital and Yahoo!) gave a paper at an archaeological computing conference at UCL's Institute of Archaeology, where he broke his joke about XML being like high school sex (won't elaborate on this, ask him) whilst some toe-rags were trying to steal my push bike (they came off badly as I was standing behind them!) Tyler's paper gave me much food for thought, and it is over the last year or so, that this idea has really come to fruition with our data. The advent of Yahoo!'s suite of geoPlanet tools has allowed us to do various things to our data set and present it in different ways. Below, I'll show you some of things their powerful suite of tools has allowed us to do.
<h4>Putting dots on maps for finds with just a parish name</h4>
Prior to 2003, we often received the majority of our finds with a very vague find spot, often just to parish level. As everyone loves maps and would like to see where these finds came from, I wanted to get a map on every page that needed one.. Previously, our FLOs would be asked to centre a find on the parish for these find spots; this is now such a waste of time when you can use geoPlanet to get a latitude and longitude, Postcode, type of settlement, bounding box and a WOEID to enhance the data that we hold. To do this is pretty simple with the aid of YQL.

I first heard about YQL from <a href="http://eatyourgreens.org.uk/">Jim O'Donnell</a> (formerly NMM's web wizard) and then more at the Yahoo! Hack day in London, when I pedalled round London with Andrew Larcombe on the <a href="http://pppp.andrewl.net/">Purple Pedals bikes</a>. Yahoo describe YQL as <strong>SELECT * FROM Internet</strong>, which is indeed pretty true. Building opentables to use with their system is pretty easy - I'll write more about some Museum tables in another post soon. So all my geo extraction is performed using YQL and the examples below show how. All of these are done with the public endpoint. If you run a high traffic site, it is definitely worth changing your code to use Oauth and authenticate your YQL calls for the non-public endpoint (better rate limits etc). It is slightly tricky and you do need to work out how to refresh your Yahoo token, but it is worth the effort.

For example, I grew up in Stapleford, Cambridgeshire and you can search for that with the following YQL call:

[html]select * from geo.places where text=&quot;stapleford,cambridgeshire&quot;[/html]

Which maps to this REST url of:
<a title="REST call to geoplanet for Stapleford" href="http://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql?q=select%20*%20from%20geo.places%20where%20text%3D%22stapleford%2Ccambridgeshire%22">http://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql?q=select%20*%20from%20geo.places%20where%20text%3D%22stapleford%2Ccambridgeshire%22</a>
producing an XML or JSON response like below (diagnostics omitted):

[xml toolbar="true"]
&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;UTF-8&quot;?&gt;
&lt;query xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot; yahoo:count=&quot;1&quot; yahoo:created=&quot;2010-05-05T11:12:49Z&quot; yahoo:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;&gt;
    &lt;results&gt;
        &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://where.yahooapis.com/v1/schema.rng&quot; xml:lang=&quot;en-US&quot; yahoo:uri=&quot;http://where.yahooapis.com/v1/place/35984&quot;&gt;
            &lt;woeid&gt;35984&lt;/woeid&gt;
            &lt;placeTypeName code=&quot;7&quot;&gt;Town&lt;/placeTypeName&gt;
            &lt;name&gt;Stapleford&lt;/name&gt;
            &lt;country code=&quot;GB&quot; type=&quot;Country&quot;&gt;United Kingdom&lt;/country&gt;
            &lt;admin1 code=&quot;GB-ENG&quot; type=&quot;Country&quot;&gt;England&lt;/admin1&gt;
            &lt;admin2 code=&quot;GB-CAM&quot; type=&quot;County&quot;&gt;Cambridgeshire&lt;/admin2&gt;
            &lt;admin3/&gt;
            &lt;locality1 type=&quot;Town&quot;&gt;Stapleford&lt;/locality1&gt;
            &lt;locality2/&gt;
            &lt;postal type=&quot;Postal Code&quot;&gt;CB22 5&lt;/postal&gt;
            &lt;centroid&gt;
                &lt;latitude&gt;52.145329&lt;/latitude&gt;
                &lt;longitude&gt;0.151490&lt;/longitude&gt;
            &lt;/centroid&gt;
            &lt;boundingBox&gt;
                &lt;southWest&gt;
                    &lt;latitude&gt;52.127220&lt;/latitude&gt;
                    &lt;longitude&gt;0.133460&lt;/longitude&gt;
                &lt;/southWest&gt;
                &lt;northEast&gt;
                    &lt;latitude&gt;52.164879&lt;/latitude&gt;
                    &lt;longitude&gt;0.176640&lt;/longitude&gt;
                &lt;/northEast&gt;
            &lt;/boundingBox&gt;
            &lt;areaRank&gt;3&lt;/areaRank&gt;
            &lt;popRank&gt;1&lt;/popRank&gt;
        &lt;/place&gt;
    &lt;/results&gt;
&lt;/query&gt;
[/xml]

By parsing the XML or JSON response (I tend to use the JSON response),  a Latitude and Longitude pair can be retrieved for placing the object onto the map. It isn't the true find spot, but can at least give a high level overview of the point of origin. Whilst doing this, I also take the postcode, woeid, bounding box etc to reuse again. Parsing data is pretty simple once you have got your response and decoded the JSON, for example:

[php]
 $place = $place-&gt;query-&gt;results-&gt;place;
 $placeData = array();
 $placeData['woeid'] = (string) $place-&gt;woeid;
 $placeData['placeTypeName'] = (string) $place-&gt;placeTypeName-&gt;content;
 $placeData['name'] = (string) $place-&gt;name;
 if($place-&gt;country){
 $placeData['country'] = (string) $place-&gt;country-&gt;content;
 }
 if($place-&gt;admin1) {
 $placeData['admin1'] = (string) $place-&gt;admin1-&gt;content;
 }
 if($place-&gt;admin2){
 $placeData['admin2'] = (string) $place-&gt;admin2-&gt;content;
 }
 if($place-&gt;admin3){
 $placeData['admin3'] = (string) $place-&gt;admin3-&gt;content;
 }
 if($place-&gt;locality1){
 $placeData['locality1'] = (string) $place-&gt;locality1-&gt;content;
 }
 if($place-&gt;locality2){
 $placeData['locality2'] = (string) $place-&gt;locality2-&gt;content;
 }
 if($place-&gt;postal){
 $placeData['postal'] = $place-&gt;postal-&gt;content;
 }
 $placeData['latitude'] = $place-&gt;centroid-&gt;latitude;
 $placeData['longitude'] = $place-&gt;centroid-&gt;longitude;
 $placeData['centroid'] = array(
 'lat' =&gt; (string) $place-&gt;centroid-&gt;latitude,
 'lng' =&gt; (string) $place-&gt;centroid-&gt;longitude
 );
 $placeData['boundingBox'] = array('southWest' =&gt; array(
 'lat' =&gt; (string) $place-&gt;boundingBox-&gt;southWest-&gt;latitude,
 'lng' =&gt; (string) $place-&gt;boundingBox-&gt;southWest-&gt;longitude),
 'northEast' =&gt; array(
 'lat' =&gt; (string) $place-&gt;boundingBox-&gt;northEast-&gt;latitude,
 'lng' =&gt; (string) $place-&gt;boundingBox-&gt;northEast-&gt;longitude)
 );
 return $placeData;
[/php]

The image below shows an autogenerated findspot and a parish boundary (see below for flickr shapefile use) and adjacent places.

<a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/09/autogenerated.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium img-fluid 1045" title="autogenerated" src="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/09/autogenerated-210x300.jpg" alt="An autogenerated findspot" width="210" height="300" /></a>

Within our database, I have a certainty field for where the co-ordinates originate from. This table has the following content:
<ol>
	<li>From a map</li>
	<li>From finder verbally</li>
	<li>GPS from the finder</li>
	<li>GPS from the FLO</li>
	<li>Centred on the parish via a paper map</li>
	<li>Recorded at a rally (so certainty could be dubious)</li>
	<li>Produced via webservice</li>
</ol>
Therefore researchers are appraised of where the findspot comes from and whether we can treat it (if at all) as useful.
<h4>Getting elevation (via Geonames)</h4>
The woeid or the LatLng can be used to get elevation of the find spot. This can be achieved by a combination of reverse geocoding against Flickr place names (for woeid) and the Geonames api call for 'Elevation - Aster Global Digital Elevation Model'. So for example, I want to get the elevation for the centre of Stapleford. You can query the geonames api with the following YQL:

[html wraplines="true"]select * from json where url=&quot;http://ws.geonames.org/astergdemJSON?lat=52.145329&amp;lng=0.151490&quot;;[/html]

Which when executed produces this <a href="http://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql?q=select%20*%20from%20json%20where%20url%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Fws.geonames.org%2FastergdemJSON%3Flat%3D52.145329%26lng%3D0.151490%22%3B&amp;env=store%3A%2F%2Fdatatables.org%2Falltableswithkeys">response</a>:

[xml]
&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;UTF-8&quot;?&gt;
&lt;query xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot;
    yahoo:count=&quot;1&quot; yahoo:created=&quot;2010-09-30T12:26:00Z&quot; yahoo:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;&gt;
     &lt;results&gt;
        &lt;json&gt;
            &lt;astergdem&gt;17&lt;/astergdem&gt;
            &lt;lng&gt;0.15149&lt;/lng&gt;
            &lt;lat&gt;52.145329&lt;/lat&gt;
        &lt;/json&gt;
    &lt;/results&gt;
&lt;/query&gt;
[/xml]

So I now have the elevation of 17 metres above sea level. Great! I've been experimenting a bit with this against some findspots that we know elevation for. One high profile object, the Crosby Garrett Helmet was pinpointed to 1 metre difference in the GPS elevation and the Geonames sourced one.

By providing an elevation for each of our findspots, researchers can then do <a title="Viewshed analysis how to" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GIS_Viewshed_Analysis">viewshed analysis</a>; I don't think anyone has really done this yet for the artefact distributions that we record, but I could be proved wrong!
<h4>Reverse geocoding from Latitude and Longitude with Yahoo!</h4>
At present, the GeoPlanet suite doesn't provide this feature, but you can still manage to do this via YQL and using the following query:

[html]select * from flickr.places where lon={Longitude} and lat={latitude}[/html]

So for example using Stapleford's LatLng as the YQL parameters gives you:

[xml wraplines="true"]
&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;UTF-8&quot;?&gt;
&lt;query xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot; yahoo:count=&quot;1&quot; yahoo:created=&quot;2010-05-05T01:27:47Z&quot; yahoo:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;&gt;
    &lt;results&gt;
        &lt;places accuracy=&quot;16&quot; latitude=&quot;52.145329&quot; longitude=&quot;0.151490&quot; total=&quot;1&quot;&gt;
            &lt;place latitude=&quot;52.145&quot; longitude=&quot;0.151&quot; name=&quot;Stapleford, England, United Kingdom&quot; place_id=&quot;m2G8tyiaBJVjFQ&quot; place_type=&quot;locality&quot; place_type_id=&quot;7&quot; place_url=&quot;/United+Kingdom/England/Stapleford/in-Cambridgeshire&quot; timezone=&quot;Europe/London&quot; woeid=&quot;35984&quot;/&gt;
        &lt;/places&gt;
    &lt;/results&gt;
&lt;/query&gt;
[/xml]

You'll notice a couple fo useful things in the Flickr XML returned, for example the place_url, in this case: /united+kingdom/england/stapleford/in-cambridgeshire  which when appended to Flickr's root URL for photos can give you <a title="Photos on Flickr from Stapleford, Cambridgeshire" href="http://www.flickr.com/places/united+kingdom/england/stapleford/in-cambridgeshire">http://www.flickr.com/places/united+kingdom/england/stapleford/in-cambridgeshire</a> which in turn gives you access to feeds in various flavours from that page.

One of the other cool things available in Flickr's api is placeinfo. I'd love a boundary map of how Flickr views the parish of Stapleford. As I previously obtained and gave my findspot a WOEID, I can see if Flickr has this data. So perform this YQL query:

[html]select * from flickr.places.info where woe_id='35984'[/html]

And execute it to obtain the following XML:

[xml wraplines="true"]
&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;UTF-8&quot;?&gt;
&lt;query xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot;
    yahoo:count=&quot;1&quot; yahoo:created=&quot;2010-09-30T12:34:50Z&quot; yahoo:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;&gt;
    &lt;results&gt;
        &lt;place has_shapedata=&quot;1&quot; latitude=&quot;52.145&quot; longitude=&quot;0.151&quot;
            name=&quot;Stapleford, England, United Kingdom&quot;
            place_id=&quot;m2G8tyiaBJVjFQ&quot; place_type=&quot;locality&quot;
            place_type_id=&quot;7&quot;
            place_url=&quot;/United+Kingdom/England/Stapleford/in-Cambridgeshire&quot;
            timezone=&quot;Europe/London&quot; woeid=&quot;35984&quot;&gt;
            &lt;locality latitude=&quot;52.145&quot; longitude=&quot;0.151&quot;
                place_id=&quot;m2G8tyiaBJVjFQ&quot;
                place_url=&quot;/United+Kingdom/England/Stapleford/in-Cambridgeshire&quot; woeid=&quot;35984&quot;&gt;Stapleford, England, United Kingdom&lt;/locality&gt;
            &lt;county latitude=&quot;52.373&quot; longitude=&quot;0.007&quot;
                place_id=&quot;pVJUVwKYA5qQZa9wqQ&quot;
                place_url=&quot;/pVJUVwKYA5qQZa9wqQ&quot; woeid=&quot;12602140&quot;&gt;Cambridgeshire, England, United Kingdom&lt;/county&gt;
            &lt;region latitude=&quot;52.883&quot; longitude=&quot;-1.974&quot;
                place_id=&quot;pn4MsiGbBZlXeplyXg&quot;
                place_url=&quot;/United+Kingdom/England&quot; woeid=&quot;24554868&quot;&gt;England, United Kingdom&lt;/region&gt;
            &lt;country latitude=&quot;54.314&quot; longitude=&quot;-2.230&quot;
                place_id=&quot;DevLebebApj4RVbtaQ&quot;
                place_url=&quot;/United+Kingdom&quot; woeid=&quot;23424975&quot;&gt;United Kingdom&lt;/country&gt;
            &lt;shapedata alpha=&quot;0.00015&quot; count_edges=&quot;16&quot;
                count_points=&quot;44&quot; created=&quot;1248244568&quot; has_donuthole=&quot;0&quot; is_donuthole=&quot;0&quot;&gt;
                &lt;polylines&gt;
                    &lt;polyline&gt;52.155731201172,0.17115999758244 52.158447265625,0.17576499283314 52.159084320068,0.18161700665951 52.159244537354,0.18208900094032 52.15747833252,0.18410600721836 52.153221130371,0.18645000457764 52.151500701904,0.17897999286652 52.14905166626,0.17045900225639 52.136436462402,0.15260599553585 52.135303497314,0.14247800409794 52.140232086182,0.13955999910831 52.145477294922,0.14135999977589 52.145721435547,0.14150799810886 52.145240783691,0.14707000553608 52.154125213623,0.16043299436569 52.155731201172,0.17115999758244&lt;/polyline&gt;
                &lt;/polylines&gt;
                &lt;urls&gt;
                    &lt;shapefile&gt;http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3483/shapefiles/35984_20090722_6d95b5e27e.tar.gz&lt;/shapefile&gt;
                &lt;/urls&gt;
            &lt;/shapedata&gt;
        &lt;/place&gt;
    &lt;/results&gt;
&lt;/query&gt;
[/xml]

Brilliant, the polylines can be used draw an outline shapefile on the map.
<h4>Extracting place data from find descriptions</h4>
<a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/05/ygeo.png"><img class="alignnone size-full img-fluid 823 flow " title="ygeo" src="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/05/ygeo.png" alt="Y!Geo tags" width="178" height="144" /></a>Many of our objects are tied by descriptive prose to various places around the World. By using Yahoo's Placemaker, we can now extract the entities from the finds data and allow for cross referencing of all objects that have Avon, England within their description. The image below shows you where you'll see the tags displayed on the finds record, as I'm into Classics, you'll notice I label these with lower case Greek letters for bullets. Probably pretentious!  To get these tags is really very straightforward and can use another pretty simple YQL call, for example, this text is from the famous Moorlands Patera.

[html toolbar="true" wraplines="true"]
SELECT * FROM geo.placemaker WHERE documentContent = &quot;Only two other vessels with inscriptions naming forts on Hadrian’s Wall are known; the ‘Rudge Cup’ which was discovered in Wiltshire in 1725 (Horsley 1732; Henig 1995) and the ‘Amiens patera’ found in Amiens in 1949 (Heurgon 1951). Between them they name seven forts, but the Staffordshire patera is the first to include Drumburgh and is the only example to name an individual. All three are likely to be souvenirs of Hadrian’s Wall, although why they include forts on the western end of the Wall only is unclear&quot; AND documentType=&quot;text/plain&quot;[/html]

Which then produces this output in XML:

[xml toolbar="true"]
&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;UTF-8&quot;?&gt;
&lt;query xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot; yahoo:count=&quot;1&quot; yahoo:created=&quot;2010-05-05T04:26:57Z&quot; yahoo:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;&gt;
    &lt;results&gt;
        &lt;matches&gt;
            &lt;match&gt;
                &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeId&gt;575961&lt;/woeId&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;Town&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Amiens, Picardie, FR]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                    &lt;centroid&gt;
                        &lt;latitude&gt;49.8947&lt;/latitude&gt;
                        &lt;longitude&gt;2.29316&lt;/longitude&gt;
                    &lt;/centroid&gt;
                &lt;/place&gt;
                &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeIds&gt;575961&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                    &lt;start&gt;177&lt;/start&gt;
                    &lt;end&gt;183&lt;/end&gt;
                    &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                    &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Amiens]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                &lt;/reference&gt;
                &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeIds&gt;575961&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                    &lt;start&gt;201&lt;/start&gt;
                    &lt;end&gt;207&lt;/end&gt;
                    &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                    &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Amiens]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                &lt;/reference&gt;
            &lt;/match&gt;
            &lt;match&gt;
                &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeId&gt;12602186&lt;/woeId&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;County&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Wiltshire, England, GB]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                    &lt;centroid&gt;
                        &lt;latitude&gt;51.3241&lt;/latitude&gt;
                        &lt;longitude&gt;-1.9257&lt;/longitude&gt;
                    &lt;/centroid&gt;
                &lt;/place&gt;
                &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeIds&gt;12602186&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                    &lt;start&gt;123&lt;/start&gt;
                    &lt;end&gt;132&lt;/end&gt;
                    &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                    &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Wiltshire]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                &lt;/reference&gt;
            &lt;/match&gt;
            &lt;match&gt;
                &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeId&gt;12602189&lt;/woeId&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;County&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Staffordshire, England, GB]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                    &lt;centroid&gt;
                        &lt;latitude&gt;52.8248&lt;/latitude&gt;
                        &lt;longitude&gt;-2.02817&lt;/longitude&gt;
                    &lt;/centroid&gt;
                &lt;/place&gt;
                &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeIds&gt;12602189&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                    &lt;start&gt;276&lt;/start&gt;
                    &lt;end&gt;289&lt;/end&gt;
                    &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                    &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Staffordshire]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                &lt;/reference&gt;
            &lt;/match&gt;
            &lt;match&gt;
                &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeId&gt;23509175&lt;/woeId&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;LandFeature&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Hadrian's Wall, Bardon Mill, England, GB]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                    &lt;centroid&gt;
                        &lt;latitude&gt;54.9522&lt;/latitude&gt;
                        &lt;longitude&gt;-2.32975&lt;/longitude&gt;
                    &lt;/centroid&gt;
                &lt;/place&gt;
                &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                    &lt;woeIds&gt;23509175&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                    &lt;start&gt;418&lt;/start&gt;
                    &lt;end&gt;432&lt;/end&gt;
                    &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                    &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Hadrian’s Wall]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                    &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                    &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                &lt;/reference&gt;
            &lt;/match&gt;
        &lt;/matches&gt;
    &lt;/results&gt;
&lt;/query&gt;
[/xml]

In the above XML response, you can now see the matches that Placemaker has found in the text sent to their service. You can now parse this data and use it for tagging or any other purpose that you want to put the data to.  YQL has the added benefit of caching at the Yahoo! end and you can do multiple queries in one call as demonstrated by Chris Heilmann in his <a title="Geoplanet explorer" href="http://isithackday.com/geoplanet-explorer">Geoplanet explorer.</a>
<h4>A YQL Multiquery example</h4>
For example, I want to combine a placemaker call and also get some spatial information for a find spot where I only have the placename. To do this, I write this YQL query:

[html toolbar="true" wraplines="true"]
select * from query.multi where queries='
select * from geo.placemaker where documentContent = &quot;Only two other vessels with inscriptions naming forts on Hadrian’s Wall are known the Rudge Cup which was discovered in Wiltshire in 1725 (Horsley 1732, Henig 1995) and the Amiens patera found in Amiens in 1949 (Heurgon 1951). Between them they name seven
forts, but the Staffordshire patera is the first to include Drumburgh and is the only example to name an individual. All three are likely to be souvenirs of Hadrian’s Wall, although why they include forts on the western end of the Wall only is unclear&quot; and documentType=&quot;text/plain&quot; and appid=&quot;&quot;;
select * from geo.places where text=&quot;staffordshire moorlands, staffordshire,uk&quot; '
[/html]

The base url to call this is the public version - http://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql and as we are using one of the community tables, the call needs to be made with &amp;env=store://datatables.org/alltableswithkeys appended (urlencoded).
This can be run in the <a href="http://y.ahoo.it/fx4bG5fJ">console</a> and produces the following <a href="http://query.yahooapis.com/v1/public/yql?q=select%20*%20from%20query.multi%20where%20queries%3D'%20select%20*%20from%20geo.placemaker%20where%20documentContent%20%3D%20%22Only%20two%20other%20vessels%20with%20inscriptions%20naming%20forts%20on%20Hadrian%E2%80%99s%20Wall%20are%20known%20the%20Rudge%20Cup%20which%20was%20discovered%20in%20Wiltshire%20in%201725%20(Horsley%201732%2C%20Henig%201995)%20and%20the%20Amiens%20patera%20found%20in%20Amiens%20in%201949%20(Heurgon%201951).%20Between%20them%20they%20name%20seven%20forts%2C%20but%20the%20Staffordshire%20patera%20is%20the%20first%20to%20include%20Drumburgh%20and%20is%20the%20only%20example%20to%20name%20an%20individual.%20All%20three%20are%20likely%20to%20be%20souvenirs%20of%20Hadrian%E2%80%99s%20Wall%2C%20although%20why%20they%20include%20forts%20on%20the%20western%20end%20of%20the%20Wall%20only%20is%20unclear%22%20and%20documentType%3D%22text%2Fplain%22%20and%20appid%3D%22%22%3Bselect%20*%20from%20geo.places%20where%20text%3D%22staffordshire%20moorlands%2C%20staffordshire%2Cuk%22%20'&amp;env=store%3A%2F%2Fdatatables.org%2Falltableswithkeys">XML response</a> - 4 place matches and the geo data for Staffordshire Moorlands.

[xml toolbar="true" wraplines="true"]
&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;UTF-8&quot;?&gt;
&lt;query xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot;
    yahoo:count=&quot;2&quot; yahoo:created=&quot;2010-09-30T11:44:08Z&quot; yahoo:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;&gt;
    &lt;results&gt;
        &lt;results&gt;
            &lt;matches&gt;
                &lt;match&gt;
                    &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeId&gt;575961&lt;/woeId&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;Town&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Amiens, Picardie, FR]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                        &lt;centroid&gt;
                            &lt;latitude&gt;49.8947&lt;/latitude&gt;
                            &lt;longitude&gt;2.29316&lt;/longitude&gt;
                        &lt;/centroid&gt;
                    &lt;/place&gt;
                    &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeIds&gt;575961&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                        &lt;start&gt;196&lt;/start&gt;
                        &lt;end&gt;202&lt;/end&gt;
                        &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                        &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Amiens]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                    &lt;/reference&gt;
                &lt;/match&gt;
                &lt;match&gt;
                    &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeId&gt;12602186&lt;/woeId&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;County&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Wiltshire, England, GB]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                        &lt;centroid&gt;
                            &lt;latitude&gt;51.3241&lt;/latitude&gt;
                            &lt;longitude&gt;-1.9257&lt;/longitude&gt;
                        &lt;/centroid&gt;
                    &lt;/place&gt;
                    &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeIds&gt;12602186&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                        &lt;start&gt;120&lt;/start&gt;
                        &lt;end&gt;129&lt;/end&gt;
                        &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                        &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Wiltshire]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                    &lt;/reference&gt;
                &lt;/match&gt;
                &lt;match&gt;
                    &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeId&gt;12602189&lt;/woeId&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;County&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Staffordshire, England, GB]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                        &lt;centroid&gt;
                            &lt;latitude&gt;52.8248&lt;/latitude&gt;
                            &lt;longitude&gt;-2.02817&lt;/longitude&gt;
                        &lt;/centroid&gt;
                    &lt;/place&gt;
                    &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeIds&gt;12602189&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                        &lt;start&gt;271&lt;/start&gt;
                        &lt;end&gt;284&lt;/end&gt;
                        &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                        &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Staffordshire]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                    &lt;/reference&gt;
                &lt;/match&gt;
                &lt;match&gt;
                    &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeId&gt;23509175&lt;/woeId&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;LandFeature&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;name&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Hadrian's Wall, Bardon Mill, England, GB]]&gt;&lt;/name&gt;
                        &lt;centroid&gt;
                            &lt;latitude&gt;54.9522&lt;/latitude&gt;
                            &lt;longitude&gt;-2.32975&lt;/longitude&gt;
                        &lt;/centroid&gt;
                    &lt;/place&gt;
                    &lt;reference xmlns=&quot;http://wherein.yahooapis.com/v1/schema&quot;&gt;
                        &lt;woeIds&gt;23509175&lt;/woeIds&gt;
                        &lt;start&gt;413&lt;/start&gt;
                        &lt;end&gt;427&lt;/end&gt;
                        &lt;isPlaintextMarker&gt;1&lt;/isPlaintextMarker&gt;
                        &lt;text&gt;&lt;![CDATA[Hadrian&amp;rsquo;s Wall]]&gt;&lt;/text&gt;
                        &lt;type&gt;plaintext&lt;/type&gt;
                        &lt;xpath&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/xpath&gt;
                    &lt;/reference&gt;
                &lt;/match&gt;
            &lt;/matches&gt;
        &lt;/results&gt;
        &lt;results&gt;
            &lt;place xmlns=&quot;http://where.yahooapis.com/v1/schema.rng&quot;
                xml:lang=&quot;en-US&quot; yahoo:uri=&quot;http://where.yahooapis.com/v1/place/12696078&quot;&gt;
                &lt;woeid&gt;12696078&lt;/woeid&gt;
                &lt;placeTypeName code=&quot;10&quot;&gt;Local Administrative Area&lt;/placeTypeName&gt;
                &lt;name&gt;Staffordshire Moorlands District&lt;/name&gt;
                &lt;country code=&quot;GB&quot; type=&quot;Country&quot;&gt;United Kingdom&lt;/country&gt;
                &lt;admin1 code=&quot;GB-ENG&quot; type=&quot;Country&quot;&gt;England&lt;/admin1&gt;
                &lt;admin2 code=&quot;GB-STS&quot; type=&quot;County&quot;&gt;Staffordshire&lt;/admin2&gt;
                &lt;admin3/&gt;
                &lt;locality1/&gt;
                &lt;locality2/&gt;
                &lt;postal/&gt;
                &lt;centroid&gt;
                    &lt;latitude&gt;53.071468&lt;/latitude&gt;
                    &lt;longitude&gt;-1.993490&lt;/longitude&gt;
                &lt;/centroid&gt;
                &lt;boundingBox&gt;
                    &lt;southWest&gt;
                        &lt;latitude&gt;52.916691&lt;/latitude&gt;
                        &lt;longitude&gt;-2.211330&lt;/longitude&gt;
                    &lt;/southWest&gt;
                    &lt;northEast&gt;
                        &lt;latitude&gt;53.226250&lt;/latitude&gt;
                        &lt;longitude&gt;-1.775660&lt;/longitude&gt;
                    &lt;/northEast&gt;
                &lt;/boundingBox&gt;
                &lt;areaRank&gt;6&lt;/areaRank&gt;
                &lt;popRank&gt;0&lt;/popRank&gt;
            &lt;/place&gt;
        &lt;/results&gt;
    &lt;/results&gt;
&lt;/query&gt;
[/xml]
<h4>Concordance with other services</h4>
One of the other things I am interested in, is finding concordance between WOEID and Geonames places. This is quite easy to do using another geo table. For example look up Amiens, Picardie by WOEID:

[html]select * from geo.concordance where namespace=&quot;woeid&quot; and text=&quot;575961&quot;[/html]

Produces:

[xml]
&lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;UTF-8&quot;?&gt;
&lt;query xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot;
    yahoo:count=&quot;1&quot; yahoo:created=&quot;2010-09-30T12:41:28Z&quot; yahoo:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;&gt;
    &lt;results&gt;
        &lt;concordance xml:lang=&quot;en-US&quot;
            xmlns=&quot;http://where.yahooapis.com/v1/schema.rng&quot;
            xmlns:yahoo=&quot;http://www.yahooapis.com/v1/base.rng&quot; yahoo:uri=&quot;http://where.yahooapis.com/v1/concordance/woeid/575961&quot;&gt;
            &lt;woeid&gt;575961&lt;/woeid&gt;
            &lt;geonames&gt;3037854&lt;/geonames&gt;
            &lt;locode&gt;FRAMI&lt;/locode&gt;
        &lt;/concordance&gt;
    &lt;/results&gt;
&lt;/query&gt;
[/xml]

So you now have a WOEID and a geonames ID. Amiens WOEID = 575961 and Geonames = 3037854. You can use the geonames id that is produced for linked data; for example: <a href="http://ws.geonames.org/rdf?geonameId=3037854">http://ws.geonames.org/rdf?geonameId=3037854</a>
<h4>Problems using YQL for geodata</h4>
Even though combining YQL with the power of Geoplanet is awesome, I did run into a few problems. None of these were really insurmountable:
<ol>
	<li>Hit rate limit constantly - Google's indexing of our site was causing our server to make too many requests to YQL; fixed by changing caching model and switching to Oauth endpoint. Also I changed my code to ignore responses when the headers returned were: text/html;charset=UTF-8. The rate limit page thrown up by Yahoo! is html and not an xml response.</li>
	<li>Some places were pulled out of text when they were irrelevant - Copper Alloy, Tamil Nadu is one example. Fixed by creating a stop list</li>
	<li>geonames api sometimes takes a while to respond and made application hang - changed cUrl settings</li>
	<li>Took quite a long time to parse 400,000 records - can't do much with that!</li>
</ol>
However, I'd really recommend using YQL to extract geodata for your application. Hopefully, Yahoo! will maintain YQL and Geo as integral parts of their business model.... In the future, I would love to run the <a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org">British Museum</a> collections data through these functions and see what cross-referencing I could find....]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Ordnance Survey 1:50 000 Gazetteer import and reuse</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/05/24/os150k/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 May 2010 22:35:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=841</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignnone flow" title="Ordanance survey OpenData logo" src="http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/images/products/opendata_logo.png" alt="OS opendata logo" width="215" height="52" />On April Fool's day, the Ordnance Survey opened up its data for people to reuse with less restrictions applied. At the heart of everything we do, place perhap the most important. The Scheme uses National Grid References and place names that you would find on an OS map. The things that these maps depict, often inform where people discover objects; they represent habitation in a past and present form, sometimes concurrently, sometimes from anitiquity. The last word in that sentence is the key to why I wanted to use the 1:50 000 data in our web application (our database). Two categories of place are defined within this dataset:
<ul>
	<li>Roman Antiquity - of which there are 237 instances</li>
	<li>Antiquity - of which there are 5252 instances</li>
</ul>
If you download the 1:50k dataset from the <a title="OS data download" href="http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/opendata/">Ordnance Survey</a> or from the <a title="Mysociety cache" href="http://parlvid.mysociety.org:81/os/">mysociety cache</a> (remember they are charity, so don't abuse their servers), there is a <a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/05/50k_Gazetteer_Tech_Spec.pdf">document</a> that outlines what the fields mean in the dataset. The important one here was the f_code or feature code column. The data is available via SPARQL (see <a title="Exploring the 1:50K dataset with Sparql" href="http://www.ldodds.com/blog/2010/04/a-tour-of-the-os-50k-gazetteer-linked-data/">Leigh Dodd's article</a> on this), but I wanted to keep a local copy of this data on my server so that I could use it and transform it for some other tasks. After downloading and unzipping onto our server (placing it into the /tmp folder will save you getting error 13 codes with the mysqlimport later), I then created the following MySQL table:

[bash toolbar="true"]
CREATE TABLE `osdata` (
`id` int(11) NOT NULL,
`km_ref` char(6) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`name` char(60) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`tile_ref` char(4) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`lat_degrees` int(2) default NULL,
`lat_minutes` float default NULL,
`lon_degrees` int(2) default NULL,
`lon_minutes` float default NULL,
`northing` int(7) default NULL,
`easting` int(7) default NULL,
`gmt` char(1) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`county_code` char(2) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`county` char(20) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`full_county` char(60) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`f_code` char(3) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`e_date` char(11) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`update_code` char(1) collate utf8_unicode_ci default NULL,
`sheet1` int(3) default NULL,
`sheet2` int(3) default NULL,
`sheet3` int(3) default NULL,
PRIMARY KEY  (`id`)
) ENGINE=MyISAM DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 COLLATE=utf8_unicode_ci COMMENT='OSDATA 1:50000';[/bash]

I then needed to import this data, which I accomplished using mysqlimport command in my terminal as below (I use putty at work and OSX terminal at home). Note that I renamed the gazetteer data to the same table name as the mysql table and retained the txt extension. Fields are delimited by a colon and there is no header row.

[bash toolbar="true"]mysqlimport --user={username} --password={password} --fields-terminated-by=&quot;:&quot; {your database name} '/tmp/osdata.txt'[/bash]

The import should run through and insert 259080 rows of data. Even though I am only interested in the antiquity type fields, I have imported the lot in case I want the rest later. Now I have the data installed, I can manipulate it and use it in the way that I want. If you know your grid references, then it is apparent that the data presents at just 1KM square resolution; this is the maximum precision level to which we publicly display our find spots, so it will tie in quite nicely to the public display of information.

However, I wanted decimal degrees for the latitude and longitude within my table. I therefore inserted two new rows into the MySQL table - latitude and longitude (DOUBLE) and then used a php function to convert the 1km square grid reference into lat/lon values. I've also done some further manipulations to get the imprecise centred 1KM grid reference WOEID to get enhanced geographical data.

Now the grid reference has been converted into decimal values, I can now plot these quickly onto a Google Map or use mathematical formulae to get distance from a point; for example the <a title="Wikipedia Haversine" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haversine_formula">Haversine</a>.

[latex]d = R \, {haversin}^{-1}(h) = 2 R \arcsin\left(\sqrt{h}\,\right)[/latex]

There's s some very good discussion and code available on these resources, so there's no point reinventing the wheel:
<ul>
	<li>Haversine formula can be obtained from various sources, and <a title="Code codex" href="http://www.codecodex.com/wiki/Calculate_Distance_Between_Two_Points_on_a_Globe">this page</a> lists 9 scripting language variants.</li>
	<li>Vincenty formula can be found on the Movable Type script pages (via <a title="Chris Heilmann on Twitter" href="http://www.twitter.com/codepo8">@codepo8</a>).</li>
	<li>More detailed explanation can be found at the <a href="http://sgowtham.net/blog/2009/08/04/php-calculating-distance-between-two-locations-given-their-gps-coordinates/">Seventh Sense blog</a></li>
</ul>
For the Scheme's database, I wanted to work out if objects were close to an antiquity or Roman antiquity or whether a MP's constituency or district has them within their bounding box (as found from querying theyworkforyou's api - more on that later.) As I use Zend Framework, I created a model and then used a view helper to render data onto a finds record. If you're interested in my code for this, you're welcome to have it....this one uses the Haversine and is just the model that generates a MySQL query against my database table.

[php toolbar="true"]
&lt;?php
class Osdata extends Zend_Db_Table_Abstract
{
 protected $_name = 'osdata';
 protected $_primary = 'id';

     public function get50KNearby($lat,$long,$distance,)
                {
                $radius = 6378.137; //KM value, swap to 3960.00 for Imperial miles
                $pi = '3.141592653589793';
                $nearbys = $this-&gt;getAdapter();
                $select = $nearbys-&gt;select()
                -&gt;from($this-&gt;_name,array('name','id',  'latitude', 'longitude','distance' =&gt; 'acos((SIN('.$pi.'*'.$lat.'/180 ) * SIN('.$pi.'* latitude /180)) + (cos('.$pi.'*'.$lat.'/180) * COS('.$pi.'* latit$
                -&gt;where($radius . ' * ACOS((SIN('.$pi.'*'.$lat.'/180) * SIN('.$pi.'* latitude/180)) + (COS('.$pi.'*'.$lat.'/180) * cos('.$pi.'* latitude /180 ) * COS('.$pi.'* longitude /180 -'.$pi.'* ( '.$long.$
                -&gt;where('1=1')
                -&gt;where(new Zend_Db_Expr('f_code = &quot;R&quot; OR f_code = &quot;A&quot;'))
            -&gt;order($radius . ' * ACOS((SIN('.$pi.'*'.$lat.'/180 ) * SIN('.$pi.'* latitude/180)) + (COS('.$pi.'*'.$lat.'/180) * cos('.$pi.' * latitude /180 ) * COS('.$pi.'* longitude /180 - '.$pi.'*  ('.$long.'$
        return $nearbys-&gt;fetchAll($select);

                }
}

}
[/php]

Below is a record of an object from the controversial Water Newton rally, which was near the site of the Roman town of Durobrivae, near Chesterton in Cambridgeshire [WOEID: 39263, 1KM NGR - TL1295, Lat: 52.561508 Lon: -0.364190].

<a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/05/duro.png"><img class="alignnone size-full img-fluid 846" title="duro" src="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/05/duro.png" alt="Alert for Durobrivae" width="770" height="358" /></a>

You'll see that there are two Scheduled Monument Alerts - there are actually 5 entries in the National Monuments Record for this SAM - and there is 1:50k OS alert for a Roman antiquity. These SAM alerts aren't shown to users below 'research' level. I can then click through to find all records associated within a certain distance of this OS point, and map them if I have at least 'Research' user rights on our database. In future, I will try and link these place names through to other linked data resources. By tying them to a WOEID, I can find archaeological photos on Flickr for example.

I don't think that this breaches the OS licence and there are probably other ways to accomplish this in php, I just dabble in code, so don't rip me to shreds....]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>841</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-05-24 22:35:04</wp:post_date>

		<title>Roman society celebrations</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/06/03/roman-society-celebrations/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 Jun 2010 23:12:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=885</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4012/4665703333_a6186d6d37.jpg" rel="lightbox"><img class="flow" title="Lurcio, Gladiator and woman" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4012/4665703333_a6186d6d37_t.jpg" alt="Lurcio" /></a>

On the 3rd June, the British Museum hosted the centenary celebrations for the Roman Society, you can listen to
<a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/06/Today-03062010.mp3">Andrew Burnett on R4 Today Programme 3rd June 2010</a> and view images of the day on our <a href="http://www.flickr.com/finds">flickr page</a>. An alternative view can be seen at the <a href="http://timescolumns.typepad.com/stothard/2010/06/mary-beard-throws-a-fig.html">Time Literary Supplement Blog</a>. Somehow, I was convinced to dress up as a gladiator.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Staffordshire Hoard conservation opportunities</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/06/07/staffordshire-hoard-conservation-opportunities/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Jun 2010 22:10:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=893</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a rel="lightbox" href="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2486/3938008638_95ff3d9b83.jpg"><img class="flow" title="Kevin Leahy working on the hoard" src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2486/3938008638_95ff3d9b83_m.jpg" alt="Kevin Leahy photographing a hoard fragment" width="180" height="240" /></a>Birmingham Museums &amp; Art Gallery and Stoke Potteries Museum are seeking expressions of interest for several Conservation opportunities associated with the amazing <a title="Read more about the Staffordshire Hoard" href="http://www.staffordshirehoard.org.uk">Staffordshire Hoard</a>. These would suit experienced conservation professionals and students and allow the successful applicants to influence the future of these objects in a world-class museum setting. Competition will no doubt be very fierce for these posts. Below are the basic details for each role and a pdf of the brief and please note that dates of closing differ for the first post and the second two posts.
<h3>Hoard Conservation Advisory Panel</h3>
For conservation Professionals, Scientists, Archaeologists and related professionals who wish to to join the Hoard Conservation Advisory Panel. The deadline for applications is <strong>June 30th</strong>. Download information on the <a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/06/AdvisoryPanel.pdf">Advisory panel specification</a>.
<h3>Conservation professional placements</h3>
For conservation professionals who wish to take advantage of a unique professional development opportunity through contributing to the conservation of the Staffordshire Hoard as part of a placement. The deadline for applications is <strong>July 30th</strong>. Download information on the <a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/06/ConservationProfessionals.pdf">Conservation professionals specification</a>.
<h3>Student placements</h3>
Student placements to contribute to the conservation of the Staffordshire Hoard. The first deadline for applications is <strong>July 30th</strong>. Download information on the <a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/06/StudentPlacement.pdf">Student placement specification</a>.

If you require any further information please email <a href="mailto:Deborah_Cane@birmingham.gov.uk?subject=Staffordshire%20Hoard%20Conservation%20Opportunities">Deborah Cane</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Using our data to place a google map on your own site (without the api)</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/07/09/embed-map/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Jul 2010 13:32:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=903</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This post is just a short overview of how you can get our data onto your website without being uber-geeky and knowing how to play with our Applications Programming Interface (API - more on this over the next month or so.)  The Scheme's website can now serve up various different flavours of content by means of context switching. You can now get:
<ol>
	<li>RSS</li>
	<li>ATOM</li>
	<li>XML (finds lists and searches are returned in MIDAS format, other pages just plain XML responses)</li>
	<li>JSON</li>
	<li>KML</li>
	<li>CSV</li>
</ol>
To find out what versions of the content you can retrieve for a page is pretty simple. If you scroll towards the foot of any page on our website, look for the text:
<blockquote>This page is available in: {contexts available} representations.</blockquote>
This makes use of the Zend Framework context switch parameter -format. So any url that has an alternative representation just needs appending format/{context}. So for example, you want to view all finds for Essex in ATOM format you would call this url:

<a title="Atom feed for finds" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/database/search/results/county/ESSEX/format/atom">http://www.finds.org.uk/database/search/results/county/ESSEX/format/atom</a>

You can now use this output within your own site using simple software tools such as widgets, simplepie etc. However, what is probably of more interest to many people is getting a map of objects found locally to them. So for example, you run a parish council and you want all objects found in the district. Let's try my home district of South Cambridgeshire. If you go to our advanced search facility and scroll to the bottom and choose county as Cambridgeshire and district as South Cambridgeshire, then submit the form and wait a second for the search to complete.

Now that the results are there, look at the page foot for the representations available and you'll see the letters KML. If you click on this, you can now get data in the format that can be used in many online mapping programmes and Google Earth. So if you want to see this on the map, copy the url generated; in this case:

<a title="South Cambs finds" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/database/search/results/county/CAMBRIDGESHIRE/district/SOUTH+CAMBRIDGESHIRE/format/kml">http://www.finds.org.uk/database/search/results/county/CAMBRIDGESHIRE/district/SOUTH+CAMBRIDGESHIRE/format/kml</a>

<a title="South Cambridgeshire KML" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/database/search/results/county/CAMBRIDGESHIRE/district/SOUTH+CAMBRIDGESHIRE/format/kml"></a>

Now head over to <a title="Google maps" href="http://maps.google.com">http://maps.google.com</a>.

In the search bar, paste the url that you copied and press search.

<img title="search" src="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/07/search-300x20.png" alt="Google maps search bar with url pasted in" width="300" height="20" />

The map should now change to show pins for degraded findspot locations. These pins are only provided when the 'to be known as' field has not been filled in and the actual points are taken from the 1km grid reference (4 figure). So the map should now render like the below image:

<a href="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/07/map.png"><img class="alignnone size-medium img-fluid 909" title="map" src="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/07/map-300x148.png" alt="Google map generated from the KML " width="300" height="148" /></a>

Now you have generated this map, you can grab either the link for the map and send directly to some one, or you can grab the HTML code to embed the map into a webpage. Look in the top corner of the map for the control labelled embed and click this; you then get the layer appearing which looks like the image below:

<img src="http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/files/2010/07/link.png" alt="Link box from google" title="link" width="405" height="176" class="alignnone size-full img-fluid 917" />

As this post deals with embedding the map on your own webpage, it is assumed that you can enter raw html directly. Copy the text which is contained in the box labelled "Paste HTML to embed in website". This looks like:
[sourcecode]
&lt;iframe width=&quot;425&quot; height=&quot;350&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; scrolling=&quot;no&quot; marginheight=&quot;0&quot; marginwidth=&quot;0&quot; 
src=&quot;http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;amp;source=s_q&amp;amp;hl=en&amp;amp;geocode=&amp;amp;q=http:%2F%2Fwww.finds.org.uk%2Fdatabase%2Fsearch%2Fresults%2Fcounty%2FCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fdistrict%2FSOUTH%2BCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fformat%2Fkml&amp;amp;sll=37.0625,-95.677068&amp;amp;sspn=47.885545,114.169922&amp;amp;ie=UTF8&amp;amp;ll=52.257917,-0.000189&amp;amp;spn=0.72983,0.782087&amp;amp;iwloc=lyrftr:kml:cF4oaez0SXhtHIuPUpXMoJUR9uPk2SiORITteHHHGjS0fvow5su0kSjIVdHy4TwDOfCcxM4bseHHEGTe2fPgy5si2VKsJEzIMAg,gf42aba810981b24d,52.065156,0.171661,0,-32&amp;amp;output=embed&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;
&lt;br /&gt;&lt;small&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;amp;source=embed&amp;amp;hl=en&amp;amp;geocode=&amp;amp;q=http:%2F%2Fwww.finds.org.uk%2Fdatabase%2Fsearch%2Fresults%2Fcounty%2FCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fdistrict%2FSOUTH%2BCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fformat%2Fkml&amp;amp;sll=37.0625,-95.677068&amp;amp;sspn=47.885545,114.169922&amp;amp;ie=UTF8&amp;amp;ll=52.257917,-0.000189&amp;amp;spn=0.72983,0.782087&amp;amp;iwloc=lyrftr:kml:cF4oaez0SXhtHIuPUpXMoJUR9uPk2SiORITteHHHGjS0fvow5su0kSjIVdHy4TwDOfCcxM4bseHHEGTe2fPgy5si2VKsJEzIMAg,gf42aba810981b24d,52.065156,0.171661,0,-32&quot; style=&quot;color:#0000FF;text-align:left&quot;&gt;View Larger Map&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/small&gt;
[/sourcecode]

Then once you have pasted this code into your webpage, saved it and if you aren't using a content management system, upload it to your website and then the map will be embedded as shown below:
<iframe width="100%" height="350" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="0" marginwidth="0" src="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;source=s_q&amp;hl=en&amp;geocode=&amp;q=http:%2F%2Fwww.finds.org.uk%2Fdatabase%2Fsearch%2Fresults%2Fcounty%2FCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fdistrict%2FSOUTH%2BCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fformat%2Fkml&amp;sll=37.0625,-95.677068&amp;sspn=47.885545,114.169922&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;ll=52.257917,-0.000189&amp;spn=0.72983,0.782087&amp;iwloc=lyrftr:kml:cF4oaez0SXhtHIuPUpXMoJUR9uPk2SiORITteHHHGjS0fvow5su0kSjIVdHy4TwDOfCcxM4bseHHEGTe2fPgy5si2VKsJEzIMAg,gf42aba810981b24d,52.065156,0.171661,0,-32&amp;output=embed"></iframe><br /><small><a href="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;source=embed&amp;hl=en&amp;geocode=&amp;q=http:%2F%2Fwww.finds.org.uk%2Fdatabase%2Fsearch%2Fresults%2Fcounty%2FCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fdistrict%2FSOUTH%2BCAMBRIDGESHIRE%2Fformat%2Fkml&amp;sll=37.0625,-95.677068&amp;sspn=47.885545,114.169922&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;ll=52.257917,-0.000189&amp;spn=0.72983,0.782087&amp;iwloc=lyrftr:kml:cF4oaez0SXhtHIuPUpXMoJUR9uPk2SiORITteHHHGjS0fvow5su0kSjIVdHy4TwDOfCcxM4bseHHEGTe2fPgy5si2VKsJEzIMAg,gf42aba810981b24d,52.065156,0.171661,0,-32" style="color:#0000FF;text-align:left">View Larger Map</a></small>

In the infowindow bubbles that come up when you click on a findspot location, you will see this text:

<blockquote>This findspot has been produced from the 4 figure reference. It is not the precise findspot.</blockquote>

As mentioned above, due to findspot security/ landowner privacy, and an agreement we have with the major body that gives us artefact spatial information, we cannot publish co-ordinates publicly at a precision greater than parish or 1km square (4 figure grid reference) and we also hold back from view finds that have had the "to be known as" field. Therefore, the map you get from this is not 100% accurate! <strong>This is not something we can change.</strong>

A couple of weeks ago, we sent a mailshot out to all MPs for England and Wales, detailing how they could get finds for their constituency onto their own webpages. This is done in exactly the same way as the above and constituency finds feeds can be obtained from the news section of the website under (and powered by <a href="http://github.com/portableant/yql-tables/tree/master/twfy/">YQL</a> calls of the <a href="http://www.theyworkforyou.com/api/">theyworkforyou</a> api):

<a href="http://finds.org.uk/news/theyworkforyou/constituencies">http://finds.org.uk/news/theyworkforyou/constituencies</a>

Two examples with finds in their constituencies are the coalition leaders (the Roman coin hoard from Frome announced on the 8th July, had a colalition type coin inside). David Cameron's <a href="http://finds.org.uk/news/theyworkforyou/finds/constituency/Witney">constituency of Witney</a>  shows this map:

<iframe width="100%" height="350" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="0" marginwidth="0" src="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;source=s_q&amp;hl=en&amp;geocode=&amp;q=http:%2F%2Ffinds.org.uk%2Fnews%2Ftheyworkforyou%2Ffinds%2Fconstituency%2FWitney%2Fformat%2Fkml&amp;sll=52.242938,0.281525&amp;sspn=0.58273,1.783905&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;ll=51.837225,-1.508125&amp;spn=0.313857,0.436724&amp;output=embed"></iframe>

And Nick Clegg's <a href="http://finds.org.uk/news/theyworkforyou/finds/constituency/Sheffield+Hallam">Sheffield Hallam constituency</a> shows this map:
<iframe width="100%" height="350" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="0" marginwidth="0" src="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;source=s_q&amp;hl=en&amp;geocode=&amp;q=http:%2F%2Ffinds.org.uk%2Fnews%2Ftheyworkforyou%2Ffinds%2Fconstituency%2FSheffield%2BHallam%2Fformat%2Fkml&amp;sll=51.837225,-1.508125&amp;sspn=0.58804,1.783905&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;ll=53.383646,-1.603335&amp;spn=0.098465,0.19546&amp;output=embed"></iframe>

Once geoRSS is enabled and working properly, you can also do the above using any of the feeds for finds where the context switch called is ATOM. This will be done by the middle of next week, alongside ATOM paging.

]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Another milestone reached</title>
		<link>http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/2010/07/26/another-milestone-reached/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2010 20:34:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://finds.org.uk/blogs/centralunit/?p=944</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On the 26th July 2010, the Scheme recorded the 400,000 record on the database; another Roman coins, this time a nummus of the House of Constantine. We had an internal challenge, with the Deputy Head down to buy the person who recorded this object, a bottle of sparkling wine. The landmark object is show below and was recorded by Tom Brindle, our acting FLO for Staffordshire and the West Midlands.

<img style="float: right;" src="http://www.finds.org.uk/images/thumbnails/290816.jpg" alt="WMID-D6D183" /><acronym title="The Portable Antiquities Scheme">PAS</acronym> record number: WMID-D6D183
Object type: Coin
Broadperiod: Roman
County of discovery: Shropshire
Stable url: <a title="WMID-D6D183: a Roman Coin" href="http://www.finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/400298">http://www.finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/400298</a>

Several FLOs expressed dismay, that the object was a Roman coin and a metal detector find, I think they were hoping for a lithic or something else found by a fieldwalker for a change... However, coins and metal detectorists are the best represented on our database....
<table id="table_results" border="0" cellspacing="1" cellpadding="2">
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Records</th>
<th>Finds recorded</th>
<th>Year of recording</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>

</tbody>
</table>
You might wonder why these figures don't always match the Annual Reports; well, the database is constantly being worked on, errors corrected, finds removed if duplicate records  and so on. There's some blips in the figures being recorded - 2002 for example being foot and mouth hit, in 2003 the Scheme went National and we phased in our new database and in March 2010 we imported 2 large datasets from IARCW and CCI (and you might have heard about 52,503 coins found in Somerset - only 1 record of those though - April). However the 2010 figures are encouraging when you look at the statistics for recording since we went live with our new database (shown below with a comparison to 2009, same period).
